questions.explanation: When you're turning right, plan your approach to the junction. Signal and select the correct gear in good time. Just before you turn, take a lifesaver glance for a final check behind and to the side of you.

prashna.text: You're about to turn right. What should you do just before you turn?

options.description: A. Get in position ready for the turn
B. Select the correct gear
C. Give the correct signal
D. Take a lifesaver glance over your shoulder

questions.explanation: This action makes you aware of what’s happening behind and alongside you. The lifesaver glance should be timed so that you still have time to react if it isn’t safe to perform the manoeuvre.

prashna.text: What is the ‘lifesaver’ when riding a motorcycle?

options.description: A. A certificate every motorcyclist must have
B. A final rearward glance before changing direction
C. A part of the motorcycle tool kit
D. A mirror fitted to check blind spots

questions.explanation: Always look for any advance warning of hazards, such as road signs and hazard warning lines. Use this information to plan ahead and to help you avoid the need for late, harsh braking. Your motorcycle should be upright and moving in a straight line when you brake. This will help you keep maximum control when dealing with the hazard.

prashna.text: You see road signs showing a sharp bend ahead. What should you do?

options.description: A. Slow down as you go around the bend
B. Continue at the same speed
C. Slow down as you come out of the bend
D. Slow down before the bend

questions.explanation: If you're dazzled by the headlights of an approaching vehicle, slow down or stop until your eyes have adjusted. A dirty or scratched visor could make the dazzle worse and further impair your vision.

prashna.text: You're riding at night and are dazzled by the headlights of an oncoming car. What should you do?

options.description: A. Slow down or stop
B. Turn your head away
C. Flash your headlights
D. Close your eyes

questions.explanation: It’s essential that you have a clear view all around. Adjust your mirrors to give you the best view of the road behind. If your body obscures the view, try fitting mirrors with longer stems.

prashna.text: When riding, your shoulders can obstruct the view in your mirrors. How can you overcome this?

options.description: A. Indicate earlier than normal
B. Brake earlier than normal
C. Extend the mirror arms
D. Fit smaller mirrors

questions.explanation: It’s important that you’re in full control at all times. Even using a hands-free phone kit can distract your attention from the road. If you need to use a mobile phone, stop in a safe and convenient place before making the call.

prashna.text: When may motorcyclists use a mobile phone?

options.description: A. When they're riding an automatic motorcycle
B. When they're riding on quiet roads
C. When they're parked in a safe place
D. When they're carrying a pillion passenger

questions.explanation: At night, you should dip your headlights to avoid dazzling oncoming drivers or those ahead of you. If you’re being overtaken, dip your headlights as the other vehicle comes past. When you switch to dipped beam, your view of the road ahead will be reduced, so look ahead for hazards on your side of the road before you do so.

prashna.text: You’re riding at night. You have your headlights on main beam. Another vehicle is overtaking you. When should you dip your headlights?

options.description: A. As soon as the other vehicle passes you
B. After the other vehicle pulls in front of you
C. When the other vehicle signals to overtake
D. As soon as the other vehicle moves out to overtake

questions.explanation: Before you move off from the side of the road, you should take a final look over your shoulder to check your blind spot. This will help you to see any road user who isn't visible in your mirrors.

prashna.text: How should you move off safely from a parked position?

options.description: A. Signal if other drivers will need to slow down
B. Look over your shoulder for a final check
C. Leave your motorcycle on its stand until the road is clear
D. Give an arm signal as well as using your indicators

questions.explanation: It can be difficult to keep warm when riding a motorcycle. It's well worth buying good-quality motorcycle clothing, which will help to keep you warm and is essential for your safety. If you become very cold while riding, you'll find it difficult to concentrate on the road.

prashna.text: You become cold when riding your motorcycle. How will this affect you?

options.description: A. You'll lose concentration
B. You'll react more quickly
C. You'll be more alert
D. You'll be more relaxed

questions.explanation: If your view of the road ahead is restricted because you’re being dazzled by approaching headlights, slow down and, if you need to, pull over and stop.

prashna.text: You’re riding at night and are dazzled by the lights of an approaching vehicle. What should you do?

options.description: A. Switch to main beam
B. Flash your headlights
C. Switch off your headlights
D. Slow down and stop if necessary

questions.explanation: Your blind spots are the areas behind and to either side of you that aren't covered by your mirrors. You should always check the relevant side when there's a risk of a hazard that isn't visible in your mirrors.

prashna.text: You should always check your blind spots before doing what?

options.description: A. Slowing down
B. Moving off
C. Changing gear
D. Giving a signal

questions.explanation: The areas that aren't covered by your mirrors are called blind spots. They should always be checked before changing direction. This check is so important that it's called the ‘lifesaver’.

prashna.text: Blind spots should be checked before you do what?

options.description: A. Apply the brakes
B. Give an arm signal
C. Give a signal
D. Change direction

questions.explanation: The areas that aren't covered by your mirrors are called blind spots. Other vehicles may be hidden in these areas. Before changing lanes, you should make sure it's safe by checking the blind spot on the side you intend to move. This is called a lifesaver check.

prashna.text: When should you check the blind spots?

options.description: A. Before slowing down
B. Before changing gear
C. Before changing lanes
D. Before giving signals

questions.explanation: When riding on the road, you need to know as much about following traffic as you can. A mirror fitted on each side of your motorcycle will help give you the best view of the road behind.

prashna.text: Why can it be helpful to have mirrors fitted on each side of your motorcycle?

options.description: A. To judge the gap when filtering in traffic
B. To give protection when riding in poor weather
C. To make your motorcycle appear larger to other drivers
D. To give you the best view of the road behind

questions.explanation: There are areas behind and to either side of you that aren't visible in your mirrors. These are known as blind spots. Just before turning or changing direction, you should look around to check that there's nothing hazardous in the blind spot. This check is known as a 'lifesaver'.

prashna.text: What does the term ‘lifesaver’ mean?

options.description: A. An approved safety helmet
B. A final rearward glance
C. A reflective jacket
D. The two-second rule

questions.explanation: Your passenger may be inexperienced in judging traffic situations, may have a poor view or may not have seen a potential hazard. You're responsible for your own safety and that of your passenger. Always make your own checks to be sure it's safe to pull out.

prashna.text: You're about to emerge from a junction. Your pillion passenger tells you it’s clear. When should you rely on their judgement?

options.description: A. Only when they're a qualified rider
B. Never; you should always look for yourself
C. When the roads are very busy
D. When the roads are very quiet

questions.explanation: Check your mirrors before slowing down or stopping, as there could be vehicles close behind you. If necessary, turn and look behind before stopping.

prashna.text: What must you do before stopping normally?

options.description: A. Move into neutral
B. Use your mirrors
C. Select first gear
D. Put both feet down

questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, make sure there’s a safe gap to move into. Looking over your shoulder allows you to check the area not covered by your mirrors, where a vehicle could be hidden from view. It also warns following drivers that you want to change lanes.

prashna.text: Why should you check over your shoulder before you change lanes in busy, moving traffic?

options.description: A. To avoid having to give a signal
B. So traffic ahead will make room for you
C. Mirrors don't cover blind spots
D. So your balance won’t be affected

questions.explanation: Remember your lifesaver glance before you start to turn. If you’ve been waiting for some time and a queue has built up behind you, a vehicle further back may try to overtake. In this situation, it's especially important to look out for other motorcycles, which may be approaching at speed.

prashna.text: You've been waiting for some time to make a right turn into a side road. What should you do just before you make the turn?

options.description: A. Make a lifesaver check
B. Select a higher gear
C. Move close to the kerb
D. Wave to the oncoming traffic

questions.explanation: Before emerging right onto a dual carriageway, make sure that the central reservation is wide enough to protect your vehicle. If it isn't, you should treat it as one road and check that it’s clear in both directions before pulling out.

prashna.text: You're turning right onto a dual carriageway. What should you do before emerging?

options.description: A. Stop, and then select a very low gear
B. Check the width of the central reservation
C. Check that there's enough room for vehicles behind you
D. Position in the left gutter of the side road

questions.explanation: While control layouts are generally similar, different makes and models have subtle differences in the position and operation of the switches. Before you ride any motorcycle, make sure you’re familiar with the layout of all the controls and switches.

prashna.text: What should you do when riding a motorcycle you've never ridden before?

options.description: A. Make sure you know where all the controls and switches are
B. Just ride, as all the controls and switches are the same
C. Leave your gloves behind, so the switches can be operated more easily
D. Ask someone to ride with you for the first time

questions.explanation: On busy roundabouts, traffic may be moving very quickly and changing lanes suddenly. You need to be aware of what’s happening all around you. Before crossing lanes to the left, make sure you take a lifesaver glance to the left. This gives you time to react if it isn't safe to make the manoeuvre.

prashna.text: You're turning right at a large roundabout. What should you do before you cross a lane to reach your exit?

options.description: A. Cancel the left indicator
B. Take a lifesaver glance over your left shoulder
C. Take a lifesaver glance over your right shoulder
D. Put on your right indicator

questions.explanation: Before you change lane you need to know whether it’s safe to do so. A lifesaver glance in the direction you want to move will allow you to check your mirrors’ blind spots. Your life could depend on knowing where other vehicles are.

prashna.text: You're positioned to turn right on a multi-lane roundabout. What should you do before moving to a lane on your left?

options.description: A. Cancel the left signal
B. Signal to the right
C. Take a lifesaver glance over your left shoulder
D. Take a lifesaver glance over your right shoulder

questions.explanation: The ‘lifesaver’ is essential to motorcyclists and does exactly what it says: it could save your life. Its purpose is to check the blind spot that isn't covered by your mirrors. Learn and understand how and when you should use it.

prashna.text: You’re turning right on a multi-lane roundabout. When should you take a lifesaver glance over your left shoulder?

options.description: A. After moving into the left-hand lane
B. After leaving the roundabout
C. Before moving into the left-hand lane
D. Before signalling to the right

questions.explanation: Always concentrate on the road ahead. Try not to be distracted by an incident on the other side of the road. Many motorway collisions occur due to traffic slowing down because drivers are looking at something on the other side of the road.

prashna.text: You see an incident on the other side of the motorway. What should you do?

options.description: A. Place a warning triangle in the road
B. Stop and cross the carriageway to help
C. Leave the motorway at the next exit
D. Concentrate on what's happening ahead

questions.explanation: If you have to make a U-turn, slow down and ensure that the road is clear in both directions. Make sure that the road is wide enough for you to carry out the manoeuvre safely.

prashna.text: What should you do before making a U-turn?

options.description: A. Check signs to see that U-turns are permitted
B. Select a higher gear than normal
C. Look over your shoulder for a final check
D. Give an arm signal as well as using your indicators

questions.explanation: You should slow down and be cautious. The bridge is narrow and there may not be enough room for you to pass an oncoming vehicle at this point. Also, there's no footpath, so be aware of pedestrians in the road.

prashna.text: What should you do as you approach this bridge?

options.description: A. Move to the right
B. Slow down
C. Keep to 30 mph
D. Change gear

questions.explanation: As you begin to think about overtaking, ask yourself whether it’s really necessary. If you can’t see well ahead, stay back and wait for a safer place to pull out.

prashna.text: In which of these situations should you avoid overtaking?

options.description: A. Approaching a dip in the road
B. In a one-way street
C. On a 30 mph road
D. Just after a bend

questions.explanation: In this picture, the road marking shows that overtaking drivers or riders need to return to the left. These markings show the direction drivers must pass hatch markings or solid double white lines. They are also used to show the route that high vehicles should take under low arched bridge.

prashna.text: What does the curved arrow on the road mean?

options.description: A. The road ahead bends to the left
B. Heavy vehicles should take the next road on the left to avoid a weight limit
C. The road ahead has a camber to the left
D. Overtaking traffic should move back to the left

questions.explanation: It’s illegal to use a hand-held mobile or similar device when driving or riding, except in a genuine emergency. The safest option is to switch off your mobile phone before you set off, and use a message service. If you've forgotten to switch your phone off and it rings, you should ignore it. When you've stopped in a safe place, you can see who called and return the call if necessary.

prashna.text: Your mobile phone rings while you're travelling. What should you do?

options.description: A. Pull up at the nearest kerb
B. Ignore it
C. Answer it immediately
D. Stop immediately

questions.explanation: These lines are often found on the approach to a roundabout or a dangerous junction. They give you extra warning to adjust your speed. Look well ahead and do this in good time.

prashna.text: Why are these yellow lines painted across the road?

options.description: A. To help you choose the correct lane
B. To help you keep the correct separation distance
C. To tell you the distance to the roundabout
D. To make you aware of your speed

questions.explanation: The longer traffic lights have been on green, the sooner they'll change. Allow for this as you approach traffic lights that you know have been on green for a while. They're likely to change soon, so you should be prepared to stop.

prashna.text: What should you do when you're approaching traffic lights that have been on green for some time?

options.description: A. Brake hard
B. Maintain your speed
C. Accelerate hard
D. Be ready to stop

questions.explanation: Before pulling up, check the mirrors to see what's happening behind you. Also assess what's ahead and make sure you give the correct signal if it will help other road users.

prashna.text: What should you do before stopping?

options.description: A. Use the mirrors
B. Flash the headlights
C. Sound the horn
D. Select a higher gear

questions.explanation: If you're following a large vehicle but are so close to it that you can't see its exterior mirrors, the driver won't be able to see you. Keeping well back will also allow you to see the road ahead by looking past on either side of the large vehicle.

prashna.text: You're following a large vehicle. Why should you stay a safe distance behind it?

options.description: A. You'll help the large vehicle to stop more easily
B. You'll allow the driver to see you in their mirrors
C. You'll be able to corner more quickly
D. You'll keep out of the wind better

questions.explanation: You should be constantly scanning the road for clues about what's going to happen next. Check your mirrors regularly, particularly as soon as you spot a hazard. What's happening behind may affect your response to hazards ahead.

prashna.text: When you see a hazard ahead, you should use the mirrors. Why is this?

options.description: A. To assess how your actions will affect following traffic
B. To check what's happening on the road ahead
C. Because you'll need to brake sharply to a stop
D. Because you'll need to accelerate out of danger

questions.explanation: At junctions, your view is often restricted by buildings, trees or parked cars. You need to be able to see in order to judge a safe gap. Edge forward slowly and keep looking all the time. Don’t cause other road users to change speed or direction as you emerge.

prashna.text: You're waiting to turn right at the end of a road. Your view is obstructed by parked vehicles. What should you do?

options.description: A. Move quickly to where you can see so you only block traffic from one direction
B. Stop and then move forward slowly and carefully for a clear view
C. Wait for a pedestrian to let you know when it's safe for you to emerge
D. Turn your vehicle around immediately and find another junction to use

questions.explanation: As you approach a zebra crossing, look out for people waiting to cross and be ready to stop. Some pedestrians may be a little slow to understand that it's safe to cross, so give them time. Be patient and don't rev your engine or surge forward before the crossing is clear.

prashna.text: You're riding towards a zebra crossing. Pedestrians are waiting to cross. What should you do?

options.description: A. Slow down and prepare to stop
B. Use your headlights to signal them to cross
C. Give way to the elderly and infirm only
D. Wave at them to cross the road

questions.explanation: You need to be able to see well down the road and be ready for any hazards. Staying too close to the vehicle will reduce your view of the road ahead and the driver of the vehicle in front may not be able to see you either. Without a safe separation gap, you don't have the time and space you need to react to any hazards.

prashna.text: You're following a large vehicle travelling at 40 mph. Where should you position your motorcycle?

options.description: A. Close behind the vehicle, to make it easier to overtake
B. To the left of the road, to make it easier to be seen
C. Well back, so that you can see past the vehicle
D. Close to the vehicle, to keep out of the wind

questions.explanation: Animals are easily frightened by moving motor vehicles. If you’re approaching horses, keep your speed down and watch to see if the rider has any difficulty keeping control. Always be ready to stop if necessary. When it's safe to pass, give them plenty of room.

prashna.text: You're approaching two riders on horseback. What should you do?

options.description: A. Slow down and be ready to stop
B. Flash your headlights to warn them
C. Change down the gears quickly
D. Continue at your normal speed

questions.explanation: An electronic device will automatically detect when the pedestrians have reached a safe position. Don’t move forward until the green light shows and you've checked that it's safe to proceed.

prashna.text: You're approaching a red light at a puffin crossing. Pedestrians are on the crossing. When will your red light change?

options.description: A. When a driver from the opposite direction reaches the crossing
B. When the pedestrians are clear of the front of your motorcycle
C. When you start to edge forward onto the crossing
D. When the pedestrians have reached a safe position

questions.explanation: Try not to hold up a queue of traffic. This might lead to other road users becoming impatient and attempting dangerous manoeuvres. If you’re riding a slow-moving scooter or small motorcycle and a queue of traffic has built up behind you, look for a safe place to pull in so they can pass safely.

prashna.text: You're riding a motorcycle that has an engine of less than 50 cc. What should you do if you see a queue of traffic building up behind?

options.description: A. Pull in when you can to let faster vehicles behind you overtake
B. Wave vehicles behind you to pass if you think they can overtake
C. Keep well out to stop vehicles overtaking dangerously
D. Give a left signal when it's safe for vehicles to overtake you

questions.explanation:
Aim to ride in the middle of your lane. Avoid riding in the gutter or in the centre of the road, where you might
* obstruct overtaking traffic
* put yourself in danger from oncoming traffic
* encourage other traffic to overtake you on the left.

prashna.text: When you’re riding a motorcycle, what should your normal road position allow?

options.description: A. Other vehicles will be able to pass easily on your left
B. Faster traffic will be able to overtake you easily
C. Drivers at junctions ahead will be able to see you approaching
D. You’ll keep within half a metre (1 foot 8 inches) of the kerb

questions.explanation: Overconfidence, lack of experience and poor judgement can cause a motorcyclist to make poor decisions, which can lead to a collision. It's just as important to make sure you have the right attitude and self-awareness as a rider as it is to develop skilful riding techniques.

prashna.text: Why are young motorcyclists more likely to be involved in crashes?

options.description: A. Because they're inexperienced
B. Because they ride in the middle of lanes
C. Because they're too cautious at junctions
D. Because they ride in groups

questions.explanation: Pelican crossings are signal-controlled crossings operated by pedestrians. Push-button controls change the signals. Pelican crossings have no red-and-amber stage before green; instead, they have a flashing amber light. This means you must give way to pedestrians who are already on the crossing. If the crossing is clear, however, you can continue.

prashna.text: At a pelican crossing, what must you do when the amber light is flashing?

options.description: A. Give way to pedestrians waiting to cross
B. Give way to pedestrians already on the crossing
C. Stop and wait for the red light
D. Stop and wait for the green light

questions.explanation: If people are waiting to use a pedestrian crossing, slow down and be prepared to stop. Don’t wave them across the road, because another driver may not have seen them, may not have seen your signal, and may not be able to stop safely.

prashna.text: Why should you never wave people across at pedestrian crossings?

options.description: A. They may not be looking
B. It's safer for you to carry on
C. Another vehicle may be coming
D. They may not be ready to cross

questions.explanation: ‘Tailgating’ is the term used when a driver or rider follows the vehicle in front too closely. It's dangerous because it restricts their view of the road ahead and leaves no safety margin if the vehicle in front needs to slow down or stop suddenly. Tailgating is often the underlying cause of rear-end collisions or multiple pile-ups.

prashna.text: What does 'tailgating' mean?

options.description: A. Using the rear door of a hatchback car
B. Reversing into a parking space
C. Driving with rear fog lights on
D. Following another vehicle too closely

questions.explanation: Staying back will increase your view of the road ahead. This will help you to see any hazards that might occur and give you more time to react.

prashna.text: Why is it unwise to follow this vehicle too closely?

options.description: A. Your view ahead will be increased
B. Your engine will overheat
C. Your brakes will overheat
D. Your view ahead will be reduced

questions.explanation: Water will reduce your tyres’ grip on the road. The safe separation gap of at least two seconds in dry conditions should be doubled, to at least four seconds, in wet weather.

prashna.text: What's the minimum time gap you should leave when following a vehicle on a wet road?

options.description: A. Three seconds
B. One second
C. Four seconds
D. Two seconds

questions.explanation: A long lorry with a heavy load will need more time to pass you than a car, especially on an uphill stretch of road. Slow down and allow the lorry to pass.

prashna.text: A long, heavily laden lorry is taking a long time to overtake you. What should you do?

options.description: A. Speed up
B. Change direction
C. Slow down
D. Hold your speed

questions.explanation: Emergency vehicles use blue flashing lights. If you see or hear one, move out of its way as soon as it's safe and legal to do so.

prashna.text: Which vehicle will use a blue flashing beacon?

options.description: A. Breakdown recovery
B. Bomb disposal
C. Snow plough
D. Motorway maintenance

questions.explanation: Pull over in a place where the ambulance can pass safely. Check that there are no bollards or obstructions in the road that will prevent it from passing.

prashna.text: You're being followed by an ambulance showing flashing blue lights. What should you do?

options.description: A. Accelerate hard to get away from it
B. Pull over as soon as it's safe to do so
C. Brake harshly and stop well out into the road
D. Maintain your speed and course

questions.explanation: A green flashing beacon on a vehicle means the driver or passenger is a doctor on an emergency call. Give way to them if it’s safe to do so. Be aware that the vehicle may be travelling quickly or may stop in a hurry.

prashna.text: What type of emergency vehicle is fitted with a green flashing beacon?

options.description: A. Ambulance
B. Fire engine
C. Doctor’s car
D. Road gritter

questions.explanation: These signs apply only to tram drivers, but you should know their meaning so that you’re aware of the priorities and are able to anticipate the actions of the driver.

prashna.text: Who should obey diamond-shaped traffic signs?

options.description: A. Bus drivers
B. Tram drivers
C. Lorry drivers
D. Taxi drivers

questions.explanation: The narrow wheels of a bicycle can become stuck in the tram rails, causing the cyclist to stop suddenly, wobble or even lose balance altogether. The tram lines are also slippery, which could cause a cyclist to slide or fall off.

prashna.text: On a road where trams operate, which of these vehicles will be most at risk from the tram rails?

options.description: A. Buses
B. Cars
C. Lorries
D. Cycles

questions.explanation: Your horn mustn't be used between 11.30 pm and 7 am in a built-up area or when you're stationary, unless a moving vehicle poses a danger. Its function is to alert other road users to your presence.

prashna.text: What should you use your horn for?

options.description: A. To signal your annoyance
B. To greet other road users
C. To allow you right of way
D. To alert others to your presence

questions.explanation: When you’re in a one-way street and want to turn right, you should take up a position in the right-hand lane. This will allow other road users, not wishing to turn, to pass on the left. Indicate your intention and take up the correct position in good time.

prashna.text: You're in a one-way street and want to turn right. There are two lanes. Where should you position your vehicle?

options.description: A. In the left-hand lane
B. Just left of the centre line
C. In the right-hand lane
D. In either lane, depending on the traffic

questions.explanation: If you wish to turn right into a side road, take up your position in good time. Move to the centre of the road when it’s safe to do so. This will allow vehicles to pass you on the left. Early planning will show other traffic what you intend to do.

prashna.text: You wish to turn right ahead. Why should you take up the correct position in good time?

options.description: A. To allow drivers to pass you on the right
B. To give a better view into the road that you’re joining
C. To help other road users know what you intend to do
D. To allow other drivers to pull out in front of you

questions.explanation: A toucan crossing is designed to allow pedestrians and cyclists to cross at the same time. Look out for cyclists approaching the crossing at speed.

prashna.text: At which type of crossing are cyclists allowed to ride across with pedestrians?

options.description: A. Puffin
B. Zebra
C. Toucan
D. Pelican

questions.explanation: Don’t enforce the speed limit by blocking another vehicle’s progress. This will only lead to the other driver becoming more frustrated. Allow the other vehicle to pass when you can do so safely.

prashna.text: You're driving at the legal speed limit. A vehicle comes up quickly behind you, flashing its headlights. What should you do?

options.description: A. Accelerate to make a gap behind you
B. Touch the brakes sharply to show your brake lights
C. Allow the vehicle to overtake
D. Maintain your speed to prevent the vehicle from overtaking

questions.explanation: You should only flash your headlights to warn others of your presence. Don’t use them to greet others, show impatience or give priority to other road users, because they could misunderstand your signal.

prashna.text: When should you flash your headlights at other road users?

options.description: A. When showing that you're about to turn
B. When letting them know that you're there
C. When showing that you're giving way
D. When telling them that you have right of way

questions.explanation: Be cautious, especially when your view is restricted by hedges, bushes, walls, large vehicles, etc. In the summer months, these junctions can become more difficult to deal with, because growing foliage may further obscure your view.

prashna.text: You're approaching an unmarked crossroads. How should you deal with this type of junction?

options.description: A. Slow down and look both ways
B. Accelerate and keep to the middle
C. Accelerate and look to the left
D. Slow down and keep to the right

questions.explanation: In good conditions, the 'two-second rule' can be used to check the distance between your vehicle and the one in front. This technique works on roads carrying faster traffic. Choose a fixed object, such as a bridge, sign or tree. When the vehicle ahead passes this object, say to yourself ‘Only a fool breaks the two-second rule.’ If you reach the object before you finish saying this, you’re too close.

prashna.text: The conditions are good and dry. When should you use the 'two-second rule'?

options.description: A. Before using the ‘Mirrors – Signal – Manoeuvre’ routine
B. When traffic lights change to green
C. When checking your gap from the vehicle in front
D. Before restarting the engine after it has stalled

questions.explanation: Puffin crossings have infra-red sensors that detect when pedestrians are crossing and hold the red traffic signal until the crossing is clear. The use of a sensor means there's no flashing amber phase as there is with a pelican crossing.

prashna.text: At a puffin crossing, which colour follows the green signal?

options.description: A. Steady amber
B. Flashing green
C. Steady red
D. Flashing amber

questions.explanation: If the driver behind is following too closely, there’s a danger they’ll collide with the back of your vehicle if you stop suddenly. You can reduce this risk by slowing down and increasing the safety margin in front of you. This reduces the chance that you’ll have to stop suddenly and allows you to spread your braking over a greater distance. This is an example of defensive driving.

prashna.text: You're in a line of traffic. The driver behind you is following very closely. What action should you take?

options.description: A. Signal left and wave the following driver past
B. Move over to a position just left of the centre line of the road
C. Ignore the following driver and continue to travel within the speed limit
D. Slow down, gradually increasing the gap between you and the vehicle in front

questions.explanation: Drive chains are subject to wear and need frequent adjustment to maintain the correct tension. Allowing the drive chain to run dry will greatly increase the rate of wear, so it's important to keep it lubricated. If the chain becomes worn or slack, it can jump off the sprocket and lock the rear wheel.

prashna.text: What could happen if you ride your motorcycle when it has a very loose drive chain?

options.description: A. The front wheel could wobble
B. The ignition could cut out
C. The rear wheel could lock
D. The brakes could fail

questions.explanation: Whenever you use any motorcycle on the road, it must be in a roadworthy condition. Regular maintenance should identify any faults at an early stage and help prevent more serious problems.

prashna.text: What's the most important reason why you should keep your motorcycle regularly maintained?

options.description: A. To keep the machine roadworthy
B. So the motorcycle can carry panniers
C. So the motorcycle can carry a passenger
D. To accelerate faster than other traffic

questions.explanation: New tyres have a shiny finish, which needs to wear off before the tyre will give the best grip. Take extra care if the road surface is wet or slippery.

prashna.text: How should you ride a motorcycle when new tyres have just been fitted?

options.description: A. By braking hard, especially into bends
B. Normally, but with higher tyre pressures
C. Carefully, until the shiny surface is worn off
D. By riding at faster-than-normal speeds

questions.explanation: For your own safety, you need other road users to see you easily. Wearing brightly coloured or fluorescent clothing will help you to achieve this during daylight. At night, wearing clothing that includes reflective material is the best way of helping others to see you.

prashna.text: What will be the effect of wearing brightly coloured clothing while you’re riding?

options.description: A. You'll be able to ride on unlit roads at night with sidelights
B. You'll be seen more easily by other road users
C. You'll dazzle other road users
D. You'll distract other road users

questions.explanation: Always wear your protective clothing, whatever the weather. In very hot weather it’s tempting to ride in light summer clothes, but it isn't worth the risk. If you fall from your motorcycle, you’ll have no protection from the hard road surface.

prashna.text: What should you do when you're riding a motorcycle in very hot weather?

options.description: A. Wear trainers instead of boots
B. Continue to wear protective clothing
C. Ride with your visor fully open
D. Slacken your helmet strap

questions.explanation: Motorcycles are smaller and therefore harder to see than most other vehicles on the road. You need to make yourself as visible as possible to other road users. Fluorescent and reflective clothing will help achieve this. You must be visible from all sides.

prashna.text: Why should you wear fluorescent clothing when riding in daylight?

options.description: A. It prevents injury if you come off the machine
B. It helps other road users to see you
C. It reduces wind resistance
D. It keeps you cool in hot weather

questions.explanation: Fluorescent clothing will help others to see you during the day. At night, however, you should wear clothing that reflects the light. This allows other road users to see you more easily in their headlights. Ask your local motorcycle dealer about fluorescent and reflective clothing.

prashna.text: Why should riders wear reflective clothing?

options.description: A. To be seen better at night
B. To protect them from the cold
C. To protect them from direct sunlight
D. To be seen better in daylight

questions.explanation: Fairings give protection to the hands, legs and feet. They also make riding more comfortable by keeping you out of the wind.

prashna.text: Which fairing would give you the best weather protection?

options.description: A. Windscreen
B. Sports
C. Handlebar
D. Touring

questions.explanation: Your visor protects your eyes from wind, rain, insects and road dirt. It’s important to keep it clean and in good repair. A badly scratched visor can obscure your view and cause dazzle from the lights of oncoming vehicles.

prashna.text: What should you do if your visor becomes badly scratched?

options.description: A. Wash it in soapy water
B. Polish it with a fine abrasive
C. Replace it
D. Clean it with petrol

questions.explanation: The law says that the entire original tread must be visible, with a depth of at least 1 mm in a continuous band across at least three-quarters of the breadth of the tread. However, your tyres are your only contact with the road, so it's recommended that you replace them before they get to this level.

prashna.text: What's the legal minimum depth of tread for motorcycle tyres?

options.description: A. 4 mm
B. 1.6 mm
C. 1 mm
D. 2.5 mm

questions.explanation: Many incidents and collisions involving motorcyclists occur because other road users don't see them. Be aware that you're vulnerable and make yourself as visible as possible by wearing fluorescent clothing and a light or brightly coloured helmet.

prashna.text: What can you wear to make it easier for other road users to see you?

options.description: A. White helmet
B. Grey helmet
C. Tinted visor
D. Black leathers

questions.explanation: If the oil-pressure warning light comes on when the engine is running, pull over as soon as you can, stop the engine and investigate the cause; if you don't, you risk serious engine damage.

prashna.text: What should you do if the oil-pressure warning light comes on while you're riding?

options.description: A. Stop as soon as possible and try to find the cause
B. Go to the nearest garage to ask their advice
C. Ride slowly for a few miles to see if the light goes out
D. Go to a dealer for an oil change

questions.explanation:
Your safety and that of others depends on the condition of your tyres. Before every trip, make sure they
*  are correctly inflated
*  have at least the minimum legal depth of tread
*  have no cuts or bulges.
Do these checks as part of a routine before every journey.

prashna.text: What must you check on both the front and rear motorcycle tyres?

options.description: A. That they’re the same tread pattern
B. That they’re the same make
C. That they’re correctly inflated
D. That they’re the same size

questions.explanation: Check your drive chain regularly; adjust and lubricate it if necessary. It needs to be adjusted until the 'free play' is as it says in the vehicle handbook. If the chain is too loose, it can jump off its sprocket and lock your rear wheel while you're riding.

prashna.text: What could happen if you ride your motorcycle with a slack or worn drive chain?

options.description: A. The tyres could wear more quickly
B. The rear wheel could lock
C. The engine could produce more emissions
D. The engine could misfire

questions.explanation: If a tyre bursts, close the throttle smoothly and slow gently to a stop, holding the handlebars firmly to help you keep a straight course.

prashna.text: When riding your motorcycle, a tyre bursts. What should you do?

options.description: A. Brake firmly to a stop
B. Lower the side stand
C. Slow gently to a stop
D. Change to a high gear

questions.explanation: A badly maintained engine will emit more exhaust fumes than one that's correctly serviced. This is damaging to the environment. The engine will also use more fuel.

prashna.text: What will be the effect of having your motorcycle engine properly maintained?

options.description: A. It will increase your insurance premiums
B. It will reduce your journey times
C. It will have lower exhaust emissions
D. It will use much more fuel

questions.explanation: It's very important to keep your visor or goggles clean. Clean them using warm soapy water. Don't use solvents or petrol.

prashna.text: What should you clean visors and goggles with?

options.description: A. Anti-freeze
B. White spirit
C. Petrol
D. Soapy water

questions.explanation: In cold and wet weather, your visor may fog up. If this happens when you're riding, choose somewhere safe to stop, and wipe it clean with a damp cloth. Special anti-fog products are available at motorcycle dealers.

prashna.text: You’re riding on a quiet road. Your visor fogs up. What should you do?

options.description: A. Build up speed to increase the air flow
B. Continue at a reduced speed
C. Stop as soon as possible and wipe it
D. Close the helmet air vents

questions.explanation: It's important to wear good boots when you ride a motorcycle. Boots protect your feet and shins from knocks, and give some protection in a crash. They also help keep you warm and dry in cold or wet weather.

prashna.text: You're riding in hot weather. What's the safest type of footwear?

options.description: A. Boots
B. Shoes
C. Trainers
D. Sandals

questions.explanation: Some helmet straps have a Velcro tab in addition to the main fastening, which is intended to secure the strap so that it doesn't flap in the wind. It shouldn't be used on its own to fasten the helmet.

prashna.text: Which method of fastening your helmet is unsafe?

options.description: A. Double D-ring fastening
B. Velcro tab
C. Bar and buckle
D. Quick-release fastening

questions.explanation: Catalytic converters reduce the toxic and polluting gases given out by the engine. Never use leaded or lead-replacement petrol in a motorcycle with a catalytic converter; even one tankful can permanently damage the system.

prashna.text: Your motorcycle has a catalytic converter. What does this reduce?

options.description: A. Exhaust noise
B. Fuel consumption
C. Exhaust emissions
D. Engine noise

questions.explanation: After refitting the rear wheel or adjusting the drive chain, you should check your wheel alignment. Incorrect alignment will result in excessive tyre wear and poor roadholding.

prashna.text: What should you check after refitting your rear wheel?

options.description: A. Your side stand
B. Your suspension preload
C. Your wheel alignment
D. Your steering damper

questions.explanation: You should check that all your lights work properly before every journey. If you aren't sure whether your signals can be seen, you can use arm signals as well to make your intentions clear; avoid this if you’re riding at speed because it can upset your stability.

prashna.text: You're checking your direction indicators. How many times per second must they flash?

options.description: A. Between 7 and 8 times
B. Between 5 and 6 times
C. Between 1 and 2 times
D. Between 3 and 4 times

questions.explanation: Always check the rear wheel alignment after adjusting the final drive chain. Marks on the chain adjuster may be provided to make this easy. Incorrect alignment can cause instability and increased tyre wear.

prashna.text: What should you check after adjusting the final drive chain?

options.description: A. The suspension adjustment
B. The rear shock absorber
C. The rear wheel alignment
D. The front suspension forks

questions.explanation: Worn bearings in the steering head can make your motorcycle very difficult to control. They should be checked for wear or correct adjustment and replaced if necessary.

prashna.text: Your steering feels wobbly. Which of these is a likely cause?

options.description: A. Tyre pressure is too high
B. Worn steering-head bearings
C. Incorrectly adjusted brakes
D. A broken clutch cable

questions.explanation: As well as making your motorcycle difficult to control, the leaking oil could find its way onto your tyres and brakes. This could result in a loss of control, putting you and other road users in danger.

prashna.text: You have a faulty oil seal on a shock absorber. Why is this a serious problem?

options.description: A. The motorcycle will be difficult to control
B. It will cause excessive chain wear
C. Your motorcycle will be harder to ride uphill
D. Your motorcycle won't accelerate so quickly

questions.explanation: If an oil seal on your forks or shock absorbers fails, fork oil will leak out, making the suspension ineffective and the motorcycle difficult to control. It can also be very dangerous if the oil gets onto brakes or tyres. Replace faulty oil seals without delay.

prashna.text: Oil is leaking from your forks. Why shouldn't you ride a motorcycle in this condition?

options.description: A. Your steering is likely to seize up
B. The forks will quickly begin to rust
C. Your suspension will be ineffective
D. The motorcycle will become too noisy

questions.explanation: After carrying out drive-chain adjustment, you should always check the rear wheel alignment. Many motorcycles have alignment guides stamped onto the frame to help you do this correctly.

prashna.text: You've adjusted your drive chain. If this isn't done properly, what problem could it cause?

options.description: A. Excessive fuel consumption
B. Inaccurate speedometer reading
C. Loss of braking power
D. Incorrect rear wheel alignment

questions.explanation: A cut in the sidewall can be very dangerous. The tyre is in danger of blowing out if you ride the motorcycle in this condition.

prashna.text: There's a cut in the sidewall of one of your tyres. What should you do about this?

options.description: A. Repair the cut before riding the motorcycle
B. Reduce the tyre pressure before you ride
C. Replace the tyre before riding the motorcycle
D. Check regularly to see if it gets any worse

questions.explanation: Tyre pressures should be checked regularly. Look in your vehicle handbook for the correct pressures to use.

prashna.text: You need to put air into your tyres. How would you find out the correct pressure to use?

options.description: A. It will be shown on the tyre wall
B. By checking the registration document
C. It will be stamped on the wheel
D. By checking the vehicle handbook

questions.explanation: Keeping the clutch cable oiled will help it to move smoothly through its outer casing. This will extend the life of the cable and help prevent the clutch's operation from becoming stiff.

prashna.text: What can you do to prevent a cable-operated clutch from becoming stiff?

options.description: A. Keep the cable oiled
B. Keep the cable dry
C. Keep the cable tight
D. Keep the cable slack

questions.explanation: If a motorcycle’s wheels are incorrectly aligned, tyres may wear unevenly and the motorcycle can become unstable, especially when cornering.

prashna.text: What can incorrect wheel alignment cause?

options.description: A. Reduced ground clearance
B. A serious loss of power
C. Increased tyre wear
D. Reduced braking performance

questions.explanation: If you become cold and wet when riding, this can have a serious effect on your concentration and control of your motorcycle. Proper riding gear can help shield you from the weather, as well as giving protection in the event of a crash.

prashna.text: Why should you wear specialist motorcycle clothing when riding?

options.description: A. Because the law requires you to do so
B. Because it looks better than ordinary clothing
C. Because it will reduce your insurance premium
D. Because it gives the best protection from the weather

questions.explanation: You should always use the steering lock when leaving your motorcycle. Also consider using additional locking devices, such as a U-lock, disc lock or chain. If possible, fasten the motorcycle to an immovable post or another machine.

prashna.text: What should you do when leaving your motorcycle parked?

options.description: A. Use the steering lock
B. Remove the battery lead
C. Leave the parking lights on
D. Pull it onto the kerb

questions.explanation: Theft of motorcycles is a very common crime. If you can, secure your vehicle to a lamppost or other such object, to help reduce the chances of it being stolen.

prashna.text: You're parking your motorcycle. How can you reduce the chances of it being stolen?

options.description: A. Chain it to an immovable object
B. Switch off the engine cut-out switch
C. Leave it on its side stand
D. Park in a space marked for motorcycles only

questions.explanation: To make sure a sidecar outfit doesn’t roll away after you've parked it, you should leave it in a low gear and wedge it against the kerb or place a block behind the wheel.

prashna.text: You’re parking your motorcycle and sidecar on a hill. What's the best way to stop it rolling away?

options.description: A. Leave it in a low gear
B. Put the rear wheel on the pavement
C. Leave it in neutral
D. Park very close to another vehicle

questions.explanation: If you're involved in a collision, using the engine cut-out switch will help to reduce the risk of fire. When stopping the engine normally, use the ignition switch.

prashna.text: When would you use the engine cut-out switch?

options.description: A. To stop the engine in an emergency
B. To stop the engine normally
C. To prevent the motorcycle being stolen
D. To reduce speed in an emergency

questions.explanation: The humps are there to reduce the speed of the traffic. Don’t accelerate harshly between them, as you'll then have to brake sharply to negotiate the next hump. Harsh braking and acceleration uses more fuel, as well as causing wear and tear to your vehicle.

prashna.text: What should you do when you ride along a road where there are road humps?

options.description: A. Maintain a reduced speed throughout
B. Accelerate quickly between each one
C. Ride slowly at school times only
D. Always keep to the maximum legal speed

questions.explanation: As well as the oil, you'll need to check other items. These include fuel, water and tyres.

prashna.text: When should you especially check the engine oil level?

options.description: A. Every 6000 miles
B. Before a long journey
C. When the engine is hot
D. Early in the morning

questions.explanation: Never pour the oil down any drain. The oil is highly polluting and could harm wildlife. Put it in a container and dispose of it properly at an authorised site.

prashna.text: You service your own motorcycle. How should you get rid of the old engine oil?

options.description: A. Tip it into a hole in the ground
B. Take it to a local-authority site
C. Pour it down a drain
D. Put it into your dustbin

questions.explanation: The fuel in your motorcycle can be a dangerous fire hazard. Don't use a naked flame if you can smell fuel, and don't smoke when refuelling.

prashna.text: What safeguard could you take against fire risk to your motorcycle?

options.description: A. Use unleaded petrol
B. Keep water levels above maximum
C. Check out any strong smell of petrol
D. Avoid riding with a full tank of petrol

questions.explanation: Wearing bright or fluorescent clothes will help other road users to see you. Wearing a light or brightly coloured helmet can also make you more visible.

prashna.text: What would make you more visible in daylight?

options.description: A. Wearing a brightly coloured helmet
B. Wearing a dark jacket
C. Switching off your headlights
D. Wearing a black helmet

questions.explanation: A helmet that's incorrectly fastened or not fastened at all is likely to come off in a crash and will provide little or no protection. By law, you must wear a helmet when riding on the road, and it must be correctly fastened. (Members of the Sikh religion who wear a turban are exempt.)

prashna.text: When is it illegal to ride with a helmet on?

options.description: A. When the helmet is more than four years old
B. When you've borrowed someone else’s helmet
C. When the helmet doesn't have chin protection
D. When the helmet isn't fastened correctly

questions.explanation: The vehicle handbook will explain when it's recommended that you increase tyre pressures - for example, when you're carrying extra weight from a passenger or a heavy load.

prashna.text: When should you increase the tyre pressures on your motorcycle?

options.description: A. When riding in wet weather
B. When riding in hot weather
C. When carrying a heavy load
D. After a long journey

questions.explanation: Maintenance is a vital part of road safety. Lights, indicators, reflectors and number plates must be kept clean and clear.

prashna.text: Which of these items must be kept clean?

options.description: A. Number plate
B. Engine
C. Wheels
D. Fairing

questions.explanation: Only use the engine cut-out switch in an emergency. When stopping the engine normally, use the ignition switch. This will remind you to take your keys with you when parking. It could also prevent starting problems if you forget you’ve left the cut-out switch in the ‘off’ position.

prashna.text: For what purpose should you use the engine cut-out switch on your motorcycle?

options.description: A. To stop the engine in an emergency
B. To save wear and tear on the battery
C. To stop the engine for a short time
D. To save wear and tear on the ignition

questions.explanation: Drive chains wear and need frequent adjustment and lubrication. If the drive chain is worn or slack, it can jump off the sprocket and lock the rear wheel. When you've adjusted the chain tension, you need to check the rear wheel alignment. Marks by the chain adjusters may be provided to make this easier.

prashna.text: What should you check after you've adjusted the tension on your drive chain?

options.description: A. Tyre pressures
B. Sidelights
C. Rear wheel alignment
D. Valve clearances

questions.explanation: A second-hand helmet may look in good condition but it could have received damage that isn't visible externally. A damaged helmet could be unreliable in a crash. Don’t take the risk.

prashna.text: A friend offers you a second-hand safety helmet for you to use. Why may this be a bad idea?

options.description: A. It may be a full-face type
B. You'll affect your insurance cover
C. You'll be breaking the law
D. It may be damaged

questions.explanation: When checking tyres, make sure there are no bulges or cuts in the sidewalls. Keeping your tyres correctly inflated and in good condition is a vital part of maintaining your motorcycle.

prashna.text: You're riding a motorcycle with an engine larger than 50 cc. What would make a tyre illegal?

options.description: A. A stone wedged in the tread
B. A large bulge in the sidewall
C. Tread less than 2 mm deep
D. Tread less than 1.6 mm deep

questions.explanation: Cables will stretch with use and need checking and adjusting regularly. They also need lubricating to prevent friction and wear of the cables and pivots. Don’t over-adjust brake cables or the brakes will bind, causing increased fuel consumption, risk of skidding and risk of the brakes overheating.

prashna.text: How should you maintain cable-operated brakes?

options.description: A. By removing all free play at the lever or pedal
B. By lubricating and adjusting them regularly
C. By checking them at normal operating temperature
D. By always fitting new ones for the MOT

questions.explanation: Your motorcycle will run much better and its fuel consumption will be lower if you have it serviced regularly. Check at what intervals you should have your motorcycle serviced - this can vary by model or manufacturer. Keep the service record up to date.

prashna.text: What benefit will you see if you have your motorcycle serviced regularly?

options.description: A. Better fuel economy
B. A refund on your vehicle tax
C. Increased exhaust emissions
D. Lower insurance premiums

questions.explanation: A motorcycle chain will stretch as it wears. It may need frequent checking and adjustment to keep the tension correct. In extreme cases, a loose chain can jump off the sprocket and become wedged in the rear wheel. This could cause serious loss of control and result in a crash.

prashna.text: What could a loose drive chain cause?

options.description: A. A locked rear wheel
B. A braking fault
C. Headlight misalignment
D. Wobbly wheels

questions.explanation: It’s important that other road users can see you clearly at all times. It will help other road users to see you if you use dipped headlights during the day. You must use dipped headlights during the day if visibility is seriously reduced; that is, when you can’t see for more than 100 metres (328 feet).

prashna.text: Your motorcycle isn't fitted with daytime running lights. When must you use dipped headlights during the day?

options.description: A. On country roads
B. On narrow streets
C. In poor visibility
D. When parking

questions.explanation: Sometimes, manufacturers advise you to increase your tyre pressures for high-speed riding and when carrying extra weight, such as a pillion passenger. This information can be found in the vehicle handbook.

prashna.text: When should you consider increasing your tyre pressures?

options.description: A. When riding on a wet road
B. When riding on twisty roads
C. When carrying a pillion passenger
D. When travelling on an uneven surface

questions.explanation: Too much oil in the engine will create excess crankcase pressure. This could damage engine seals and cause oil leaks. Any excess oil should be drained off.

prashna.text: You have too much oil in your engine. What could this cause?

options.description: A. Engine overheating
B. Low oil pressure
C. Chain wear
D. Oil leaks

questions.explanation: When you leave your motorcycle parked and unattended on a road, switch off the engine, use the steering lock and remove the ignition key. Also take any tank bags, panniers or loose luggage with you, set the alarm if the motorcycle has one, and use an additional lock and chain, or cable lock.

prashna.text: You're leaving your motorcycle unattended on a road. When may you leave the engine running?

options.description: A. Not on any occasion
B. If the battery is flat
C. When parking for less than five minutes
D. When in a 20 mph zone

questions.explanation: The engine cut-out switch is used to stop the engine in an emergency. In the event of a crash, this may help to reduce any fire risk.

prashna.text: You're involved in a crash. What should you do to reduce the risk of fire?

options.description: A. Keep the engine running
B. Turn the fuel tap to reserve
C. Open the choke
D. Use the engine cut-out switch

questions.explanation:
At night, you should wear clothing with reflective material, to help other road users to see you. If your jacket doesn’t have reflective patches, you could wear garments that do, such as
*  a hi-visibility vest or tabard
*  a reflective belt.
Also use your headlights on dipped or main beam, as appropriate.

prashna.text: What should you do when riding at night?

options.description: A. Ride in the centre of the road
B. Wear a tinted visor
C. Give arm signals
D. Wear reflective clothing

questions.explanation: Your tyres are your only contact with the road. To prevent problems with braking and steering, keep your tyres free from defects; they must have sufficient tread depth and be correctly inflated. Correct tyre pressures help reduce the risk of skidding and provide a safer and more comfortable drive or ride.

prashna.text: What’s badly affected if the tyres are under-inflated?

options.description: A. Parking
B. Braking
C. Indicating
D. Changing gear

questions.explanation: Every effort must be made to prevent excessive noise, especially in built-up areas at night. Don’t rev your engine or sound the horn unnecessarily. It's illegal to sound your horn in a built-up area between 11.30 pm and 7.00 am, except when another road user poses a danger.

prashna.text: When mustn't you sound your vehicle's horn?

options.description: A. Between 11.30 pm and 7.00 am in a built-up area
B. At any time in a built-up area
C. Between 10.00 pm and 6.00 am in a built-up area
D. Between 11.30 pm and 6.00 am on any road

questions.explanation: Trams are powered by electricity and therefore don't emit exhaust fumes. They ease traffic congestion by offering drivers an alternative to using their car, particularly in busy cities and towns.

prashna.text: What makes the vehicle in the picture 'environmentally friendly'?

options.description: A. It's powered by electricity
B. It's powered by gravity
C. It's powered by diesel
D. It's powered by unleaded petrol

questions.explanation: Inconsiderate parking can obstruct the flow of traffic and so make traffic congestion worse. Red routes are designed to prevent this by enforcing strict parking restrictions. Driving slowly in traffic increases fuel consumption and causes a build-up of exhaust fumes.

prashna.text: Why have 'red routes' been introduced in major cities?

options.description: A. To provide better parking
B. To allow lorries to load more freely
C. To help the traffic flow
D. To raise the speed limits

questions.explanation: Traffic-calming measures help to keep vehicle speeds low in congested areas where there are pedestrians and children. A pedestrian is much more likely to survive a collision with a vehicle travelling at 20 mph than they are with a vehicle travelling at 40 mph.

prashna.text: What's the purpose of road humps, chicanes and narrowings?

options.description: A. To increase traffic speed
B. To allow pedestrians to cross
C. To reduce traffic speed
D. To separate lanes of traffic

questions.explanation: Check the tyre pressures when the tyres are cold. This will give you a more accurate reading. The heat generated on a long journey will raise the pressure inside the tyre.

prashna.text: It's essential that tyre pressures are checked regularly. When should this be done?

options.description: A. After any lengthy journey
B. After travelling at high speed
C. When tyres are hot
D. When tyres are cold

questions.explanation: Check your tyre pressures frequently – normally once a week. If they're lower than those recommended by the manufacturer, there will be more ‘rolling resistance’. The engine will have to work harder to overcome this, leading to increased fuel consumption.

prashna.text: When will your vehicle use more fuel?

options.description: A. When its tyres are new
B. When its tyres are under-inflated
C. When its tyres are over-inflated
D. When its tyres are of different makes

questions.explanation: Batteries contain acid, which is hazardous, and they must be disposed of safely. This means taking them to an appropriate disposal site.

prashna.text: How should you dispose of a used vehicle battery?

options.description: A. Bury it in your garden
B. Put it in the dustbin
C. Leave it on waste land
D. Take it to a local-authority site

questions.explanation: Accelerating and braking gently and smoothly will help to save fuel and reduce wear on your vehicle. This makes it better for the environment too.

prashna.text: What's most likely to cause high fuel consumption?

options.description: A. Poor steering control
B. Staying in high gears
C. Accelerating around bends
D. Harsh braking and accelerating

questions.explanation: Some modern batteries are maintenance-free. Check your vehicle handbook and, if necessary, make sure that the plates in each battery cell are covered with fluid.

prashna.text: The fluid level in your battery is low. What should you top it up with?

options.description: A. Engine oil
B. Distilled water
C. Engine coolant
D. Battery acid

questions.explanation: When parking at night, park in the direction of the traffic. This will enable other road users to see the reflectors on the rear of your vehicle. Use your parking lights if the speed limit is over 30 mph.

prashna.text: You're parked on the road at night. Where must you use parking lights?

options.description: A. Where there are continuous white lines in the middle of the road
B. Where the speed limit exceeds 30 mph
C. Where you're facing oncoming traffic
D. Where you're near a bus stop

questions.explanation: Engines that burn fossil fuels produce exhaust emissions that are harmful to health. The harder you make the engine work, the more emissions it will produce. Engines also use more fuel and produce higher levels of emissions when they're cold. Anything you can do to reduce your use of fossil fuels will help the environment.

prashna.text: How can you reduce the environmental harm caused by your motor vehicle?

options.description: A. Drive faster than normal
B. Only use it for short journeys
C. Don't service it
D. Keep engine revs low

questions.explanation: If you see that parts of the tread on your tyres are wearing before others, it may indicate a brake, steering or suspension fault. Regular servicing will help to detect faults at an early stage and this will avoid the risk of minor faults becoming serious or even dangerous.

prashna.text: What can cause excessive or uneven tyre wear?

options.description: A. A faulty electrical system
B. A faulty gearbox
C. A faulty braking system
D. A faulty exhaust system

questions.explanation: Top up the battery with distilled water and make sure each cell plate is covered.

prashna.text: You need to top up your battery. What level should you fill it to?

options.description: A. Just above the cell plates
B. Halfway up the battery
C. The top of the battery
D. Just below the cell plates

questions.explanation: Planning your journey before you set out can help to make it much easier and more pleasant, and may help to ease traffic congestion. Look at a map to help you do this. You may need maps of different scales, depending on where and how far you’re going. Printing or writing out the route can also help.

prashna.text: Before starting a journey, it's wise to plan your route. How can you do this?

options.description: A. Check your vehicle registration document
B. Look in your vehicle handbook
C. Look at a map
D. Contact your local garage

questions.explanation: Various route planners are available on the internet. Most of them give you several options, allowing you to choose between the most direct route and quieter roads. They may also identify rest and fuel stops. Print off the directions and take them with you.

prashna.text: How can you plan your route before starting a long journey?

options.description: A. Ask your local garage
B. Consult a travel agent
C. Use a route planner on the internet
D. Check your vehicle handbook

questions.explanation: Print or write down your route before setting out. Some places aren't well signed, so including both place names and road numbers in your directions may help you avoid problems en route. Try to get an idea of how far you’re going before you leave. You can also recheck the next stage at each rest stop.

prashna.text: Planning your route before setting out can be helpful. How can you do this?

options.description: A. Look in a motoring magazine
B. Print or write down the route
C. Try to travel at busy times
D. Only visit places you know

questions.explanation: No-one likes to spend time in traffic queues. Try to avoid busy times related to school or work travel.

prashna.text: Why is it a good idea to plan your journey to avoid busy times?

options.description: A. You'll have an easier journey
B. Your journey time will be longer
C. You'll have a more stressful journey
D. It will cause more traffic congestion

questions.explanation: If possible, avoid the early morning, late afternoon and early evening ‘rush hour’. Doing this should allow you to travel in a more relaxed frame of mind, concentrate solely on what you’re doing and arrive at your destination feeling less stressed.

prashna.text: You avoid busy times when travelling. How will this affect your journey?

options.description: A. You’ll travel a much shorter distance
B. You’re more likely to be held up
C. Your journey time will be longer
D. You’re less likely to be delayed

questions.explanation: It can be frustrating and worrying to find your planned route is blocked by roadworks or diversions. If you've planned an alternative, you'll feel less stressed and more able to concentrate fully on your driving or riding. If your original route is mostly on motorways, it’s a good idea to plan an alternative using non-motorway roads. Always carry a map with you just in case you need to refer to it.

prashna.text: It can be helpful to plan your route before starting a journey. Why should you also plan an alternative route?

options.description: A. Your maps may have different scales
B. You may get held up by a tractor
C. Your original route may be blocked
D. You may find you have to pay a congestion charge

questions.explanation: Always allow plenty of time for your journey in case of unforeseen problems. Anything can happen; for example, punctures, breakdowns, road closures, diversions and delays. You'll feel less stressed and less inclined to take risks if you aren't ‘pushed for time’.

prashna.text: You're making an appointment and will have to travel a long distance. How should you plan for the journey?

options.description: A. Avoid roads with the national speed limit
B. Allow plenty of time for the trip
C. Plan to travel at busy times
D. Prevent other drivers from overtaking

questions.explanation: Using the controls smoothly can reduce fuel consumption by about 15%, as well as reducing wear and tear on your vehicle. Plan ahead and anticipate changes of speed well in advance. This will reduce the need to accelerate rapidly or brake sharply.

prashna.text: What can rapid acceleration and heavy braking lead to?

options.description: A. Increased fuel consumption
B. Reduced exhaust emissions
C. Reduced pollution
D. Increased road safety

questions.explanation: You should carry out frequent checks on all fluid levels but particularly brake fluid. As the brake pads or shoes wear down, the brake fluid level will drop. If it drops below the minimum mark on the fluid reservoir, air could enter the hydraulic system and lead to a loss of braking efficiency or even complete brake failure.

prashna.text: Which of these, if allowed to get low, could cause you to crash?

options.description: A. Brake fluid level
B. Anti-freeze level
C. Battery water level
D. Radiator coolant level

questions.explanation: When you're carrying a passenger on a motorcycle, the overall weight will be much more than when you're riding alone. This additional weight will make it harder for you to stop quickly in an emergency, so you'll need to increase the distance between your motorcycle and the vehicle in front.

prashna.text: When will your overall stopping distance be longer?

options.description: A. When you're riding with a passenger
B. When you're riding in fog
C. When you're riding at night
D. When you're riding up a hill

questions.explanation: Motorcyclists need to take extra care when stopping on wet road surfaces. Plan well ahead so that you’re able to brake in good time. For maximum stability, you should use both brakes, and brake when your motorcycle is upright and travelling in a straight line.

prashna.text: What's the safest way to stop on a wet road?

options.description: A. Use the front brake only
B. Use both brakes
C. Use the back brake only
D. Change gear without braking

questions.explanation: If you feel your back wheel beginning to skid as you accelerate, ease off the throttle. This will give your rear tyre the chance to grip the road and stop the skid.

prashna.text: You're riding in heavy rain. Your rear wheel skids as you accelerate. What must you do to regain control?

options.description: A. Change down to a lower gear
B. Put your feet down
C. Ease off the throttle
D. Brake to reduce speed

questions.explanation: Don't ride in snowy or icy conditions unless your journey is essential. If you must go out, try to keep to main roads, which are more likely to be treated and clear.

prashna.text: Before starting a journey in the snow, what should you do?

options.description: A. Try to avoid taking a passenger
B. Plan a route avoiding towns
C. Have a hot drink and a meal
D. Consider whether your journey is essential

questions.explanation: Make yourself as visible as possible, from the side as well as from the front and rear. Having your headlights on, even in good daylight, can help make you more conspicuous.

prashna.text: Why should you ride with dipped headlights on in the daytime?

options.description: A. They mean that you can ride faster
B. So that they’re already on when it gets dark
C. They help other road users to see you
D. Other vehicles will get out of the way

questions.explanation: If your motorcycle is fitted with high-intensity rear fog lights, you must only use them when visibility is seriously reduced. That's when you can see no further than 100 metres (328 feet). This rule about high-intensity rear fog lights applies to all motor vehicles.

prashna.text: When are motorcyclists allowed to use high-intensity rear fog lights?

options.description: A. When a pillion passenger is being carried
B. When they ride a large touring machine
C. When visibility is 100 metres (328 feet) or less
D. When they're riding on the road for the first time

questions.explanation: Your headlights help you to see in the dark, and help other road users to see you. Use your headlights whenever visibility is poor. Using them at other times may also help other road users to see you. On many motorcycles, the headlights are switched on automatically when you start the engine. Most European countries require headlights to be used at all times.

prashna.text: When must you use your headlights?

options.description: A. When carrying a passenger
B. When visibility is poor
C. When riding in a group
D. When parked on an unlit road

questions.explanation: After rain, the reflections from wet surfaces will make it hard to see unlit objects. Make sure that your visor or goggles are clean, so your vision is as clear as possible. Pedestrians will be difficult to see, especially if they're wearing dark clothing.

prashna.text: You're riding in town at night. The roads are wet after rain. How will the reflections from wet surfaces affect you?

options.description: A. They’ll make it easier to stop
B. They’ll make it harder to accelerate
C. They’ll make it harder to see unlit objects
D. They’ll make it easier to see unlit objects

questions.explanation: Water can make your brakes less effective. If they've been affected, ride slowly while gently applying them until normal braking is restored.

prashna.text: You've just ridden through a flood. What should you test when you're clear of the water?

options.description: A. The starter motor
B. The brakes
C. The headlights
D. The steering

questions.explanation: If you have to ride through a flood, ride slowly in a low gear. Keep the engine running fast enough to keep water out of the exhaust. You may need to slip the clutch to do this.

prashna.text: How should you ride through flood water?

options.description: A. Slowly, in a low gear
B. Quickly, in a low gear
C. Quickly, in a high gear
D. Slowly, in a high gear

questions.explanation: If there's other traffic on the road at night, use your headlights on dipped beam. Only switch to main beam when you won't dazzle other road users. At night, don't wear tinted glasses or contact lenses, or use a tinted visor, because these make it more difficult to see the road ahead.

prashna.text: How should you ride at night on a busy main road?

options.description: A. With main-beam headlights on at all times
B. Wearing non-reflective dark clothing
C. Using dipped-beam headlights
D. Wearing tinted glasses or a tinted visor

questions.explanation: You must use your dipped headlights when visibility is seriously reduced. In fog, a film of mist can form over the outside of your visor or goggles. This can further reduce your ability to see. Be aware of this hazard and keep your visor or goggles clear; anti-mist sprays can help.

prashna.text: What should you do to help stay safe when you’re riding in fog?

options.description: A. Keep close to the centre of the road
B. Keep the vehicle in front in view
C. Keep close to the vehicle in front
D. Keep your visor or goggles clear

questions.explanation: Painted lines and road markings can be very slippery, especially for motorcyclists. Try to avoid them if you can do so safely.

prashna.text: You’re riding in heavy rain. Why should you try to avoid this marked area?

options.description: A. The painted lines may be slippery
B. Only emergency vehicles may drive over bus stops
C. It’s illegal to ride over bus stops
D. Cyclists may be using the bus stop

questions.explanation: You need to make yourself as visible as possible - from the front and back, and also from the side. Don’t just rely on your headlight and tail light. Wear clothing with reflective material, as this stands out in other vehicles’ headlights.

prashna.text: What should you do when riding at night?

options.description: A. Always give arm signals
B. Wear a tinted visor
C. Wear reflective clothing
D. Ride in the middle of the road

questions.explanation: Motorcyclists are exposed to the elements and can become very cold when riding in wintry conditions. It’s important to keep warm or your concentration could be affected. The only way to stay warm is to wear suitable clothing. If you do find yourself getting cold, then stop at a suitable place to warm up.

prashna.text: When riding in extremely cold conditions, what can you do to keep warm?

options.description: A. Wear suitable clothing
B. Put one hand on the exhaust pipe
C. Lie flat on the tank
D. Stay close to the vehicles in front

questions.explanation: It's vital to make yourself as visible as you can. Use the correct lights on your motorcycle. Wear reflective clothing and a light or brightly coloured helmet. Fluorescent clothing is effective in daytime but won’t show up as well at night. Most high-visibility clothing will have a combination of fluorescent and reflective materials.

prashna.text: What can you do to be seen more easily when you're riding at night?

options.description: A. Wear waterproof clothing
B. Keep your motorcycle clean
C. Stay well out to the right
D. Wear reflective clothing

questions.explanation: Extra care should be taken in wet weather. Wet roads will affect the time it takes you to stop: your stopping distance could be as much as doubled.

prashna.text: When will your overall stopping distance increase?

options.description: A. When it's windy
B. When it's dark
C. When it's raining
D. When it's sunny

questions.explanation: Some road surfaces can affect the stability of a motorcycle far more than they affect other vehicles. Look out for loose or slippery road surfaces and be aware of any traffic around you. You may need to take avoiding action and change direction quickly.

prashna.text: Which road surface is most likely to reduce the stability of your motorcycle?

options.description: A. Loose gravel
B. Shellgrip
C. Tarmac
D. Concrete
