questions.explanation: When riding past queuing traffic, look out for ‘keep clear’ road markings, which will indicate a side road or entrance on the left. Vehicles may emerge or turn between gaps in the traffic.

prashna.text: You're riding past queuing traffic. Why should you be more cautious when approaching this road marking?

options.description: A. Traffic could be turning here
B. Lorries will be unloading here
C. Pedestrians will be standing in the road
D. Schoolchildren will be crossing here

questions.explanation: You can cause your motorcycle to skid by heavy braking, as well as excessive acceleration, swerving or changing direction too sharply, and leaning over too far.

prashna.text: What can cause your tyres to lose their grip on the road surface and skid?

options.description: A. Heavy braking
B. Giving hand signals
C. Looking over your shoulder
D. Riding one-handed

questions.explanation: If your motorcycle starts to aquaplane, ease off the throttle smoothly. Don't brake or turn the steering until tyre grip has been restored.

prashna.text: When riding in heavy rain, a film of water can build up between your tyres and the road. This is known as aquaplaning. What should you do to keep control when aquaplaning occurs?

options.description: A. Ease off the throttle smoothly
B. Use your rear brakes gently
C. Change up to a higher gear
D. Steer to the crown of the road

questions.explanation: You can help to dry out brakes by riding slowly and applying light pressure to the brake pedal/lever. Don't ride at normal speeds until they're working normally again.

prashna.text: After riding through deep water, you notice your scooter brakes aren't working properly. What would be the best way to dry them out?

options.description: A. Stop and wait for a few minutes
B. Ride quickly, braking harshly
C. Ride slowly, braking lightly
D. Stop and dry them with a cloth

questions.explanation: Only travel in fog if your journey is absolutely necessary. Fog is often patchy and visibility can reduce suddenly, without warning, so use your dipped headlights to help others to see you in these difficult conditions.

prashna.text: What should you do if you have to ride in foggy weather?

options.description: A. Switch on only your sidelights
B. Stay close to the centre of the road
C. Ride in the gutter so you can see the kerb
D. Switch on your dipped headlights

questions.explanation: It's very important that you always leave a safe gap between your motorcycle and any vehicle you’re following. In good conditions, you need to leave at least one metre for every mile per hour of your speed, or a two-second time interval.

prashna.text: Only a fool breaks the two-second rule.' What does this refer to?

options.description: A. The time you should keep your foot down at a junction
B. The time gap when following another vehicle in good conditions
C. The time recommended when using the choke
D. The time you should allow to restart a stalled engine

questions.explanation: Avoid riding over the painted area of a mini-roundabout, as this can become very slippery – especially when wet. At any given moment, only a small part of a motorcycle tyre makes contact with the road, so any reduction in grip can seriously affect stability.

prashna.text: What should a motorcyclist avoid at a mini-roundabout?

options.description: A. Using signals
B. Taking 'lifesavers'
C. The painted area
D. Turning right

questions.explanation: Beware of side winds when riding on exposed stretches of road. Take extra care when overtaking large vehicles. As you pass them, you may emerge from their shelter into a gust of wind that can suddenly blow you off course. Bear in mind that strong winds can affect the stability of other road users too.

prashna.text: You're riding on an exposed stretch of motorway and there’s a strong side wind. When should you take extra care?

options.description: A. As you approach an exit slip road
B. When there’s slow queuing traffic
C. When you overtake a large vehicle
D. As you approach a service area

questions.explanation: Try to anticipate slippery road surfaces. Watch out for oil patches at places where vehicles stop for some time, such as bus stops, lay-bys and busy junctions.

prashna.text: Why should you try to avoid riding over this marked area?

options.description: A. It's illegal to ride over bus stops
B. A bus may have left patches of oil
C. It will alter your machine’s centre of gravity
D. Pedestrians may be waiting at the bus stop

questions.explanation: Various factors – such as weather and road conditions, vehicle condition and loading – affect how long it takes you to stop. You also need to add reaction time to this. The overall stopping distance at 50 mph includes a thinking distance of 15 metres (the reaction time before braking starts) plus your braking distance of 38 metres, giving a typical overall stopping distance of 53 metres (175 feet) in good conditions.

prashna.text: Your overall stopping distance comprises thinking distance and braking distance. You're on a good, dry road surface, with good brakes and tyres. What's the typical braking distance at 50 mph?

options.description: A. 55 metres (180 feet)
B. 24 metres (79 feet)
C. 38 metres (125 feet)
D. 14 metres (46 feet)

questions.explanation: Tyre grip is greatly reduced in icy conditions. For this reason, you need to allow up to ten times the stopping distance you would allow on dry roads.

prashna.text: By how much can stopping distances increase in icy conditions?

options.description: A. Ten times
B. Five times
C. Two times
D. Three times

questions.explanation: Always give cyclists plenty of room when overtaking them. You need to give them even more room when it’s windy. A sudden gust could easily blow them off course and into your path.

prashna.text: In windy conditions, which activity requires extra care?

options.description: A. Passing pedal cyclists
B. Using the brakes
C. Moving off on a hill
D. Turning into a narrow road

questions.explanation: Doing this will give you an earlier view around the bend and enable you to see any hazards sooner. It also reduces the risk of collision with an oncoming vehicle that may have drifted over the centre line while taking the bend.

prashna.text: When approaching a right-hand bend, you should keep well to the left. Why is this?

options.description: A. To improve your view of the road
B. To overcome the effect of the road’s slope
C. To let faster traffic from behind overtake
D. To be positioned safely if you skid

questions.explanation: Water on the brakes will act as a lubricant, causing them to work less efficiently. Using the brakes lightly as you go along will quickly dry them out.

prashna.text: You’ve just gone through deep water. What should you do to make sure your brakes are working properly?

options.description: A. Stop for at least an hour to allow them time to dry
B. Avoid using the brakes at all for a few miles
C. Accelerate and keep to a high speed for a short time
D. Go slowly while gently applying the brakes

questions.explanation: If the road surface becomes very hot, it can soften. Tyres are unable to grip a soft surface as well as they can a firm dry one. Take care when cornering and braking.

prashna.text: In very hot weather the road surface can become soft. What will this affect?

options.description: A. The suspension
B. The fuel consumption
C. The tyre grip
D. The exhaust emissions

questions.explanation: In windy conditions, care must be taken on exposed roads. A strong gust of wind can blow you off course. Watch out for other road users who are particularly likely to be affected, such as cyclists, motorcyclists, high-sided lorries and vehicles towing trailers.

prashna.text: Where are you most likely to be affected by side winds?

options.description: A. On an open stretch of road
B. On a busy stretch of road
C. On a narrow country lane
D. On a long, straight road

questions.explanation: Note that this is the typical stopping distance. It will take at least this distance to think, brake and stop in good conditions. In poor conditions, it will take much longer.

prashna.text: In good conditions, what's the typical stopping distance at 70 mph?

options.description: A. 73 metres (240 feet)
B. 96 metres (315 feet)
C. 60 metres (197 feet)
D. 53 metres (175 feet)

questions.explanation: This distance is the equivalent of 18 car lengths. Try pacing out 73 metres and then look back. It’s probably further than you think.

prashna.text: What's the shortest overall stopping distance on a dry road at 60 mph?

options.description: A. 53 metres (175 feet)
B. 73 metres (240 feet)
C. 96 metres (315 feet)
D. 58 metres (190 feet)

questions.explanation: Wet weather will affect the time it takes for you to stop and can affect your control. Your speed should allow you to stop safely and in good time. If another vehicle pulls into the gap you’ve left, ease back until you’ve regained your stopping distance.

prashna.text: You're following a vehicle at a safe distance on a wet road. Another driver overtakes you and pulls into the gap you've left. What should you do?

options.description: A. Flash your headlights as a warning
B. Drop back to regain a safe distance
C. Stay close to the other vehicle until it moves on
D. Try to overtake safely as soon as you can

questions.explanation: Even in good conditions, it will usually take you further than you think to stop. Don’t just learn the figures; make sure you understand how far the distance is.

prashna.text: You're travelling at 50 mph on a good, dry road. What's your typical overall stopping distance?

options.description: A. 53 metres (175 feet)
B. 96 metres (315 feet)
C. 36 metres (118 feet)
D. 75 metres (245 feet)

questions.explanation: Stopping distances are affected by a number of variables. These include the type, model and condition of your vehicle, the road and weather conditions, and your reaction time. Look well ahead for hazards and leave enough space between you and the vehicle in front. This should allow you to pull up safely if you have to, without braking sharply.

prashna.text: You're on a good, dry road surface. Your brakes and tyres are good. What's the typical overall stopping distance at 40 mph?

options.description: A. 23 metres (75 feet)
B. 36 metres (118 feet)
C. 53 metres (175 feet)
D. 96 metres (315 feet)

questions.explanation: Be aware that this is just the braking distance. You need to add the thinking distance to this to give the overall stopping distance. At 50 mph, the typical thinking distance will be 15 metres (50 feet), plus a braking distance of 38 metres (125 feet), giving an overall stopping distance of 53 metres (175 feet). The stopping distance could be greater than this, depending on your attention and response to any hazards. These figures are a general guide.

prashna.text: Overall stopping distance is made up of thinking distance and braking distance. You're on a good, dry road surface, with good brakes and tyres. What's the typical braking distance from 50 mph?

options.description: A. 14 metres (46 feet)
B. 38 metres (125 feet)
C. 55 metres (180 feet)
D. 24 metres (80 feet)

questions.explanation: On busy roads, traffic may still travel at high speeds despite being close together. Don’t follow the vehicle in front too closely. If a driver behind seems to be ‘pushing’ you, gradually increase your distance from the vehicle in front by slowing down gently. This will give you more space in front if you have to brake, and will reduce the risk of a collision involving several vehicles.

prashna.text: In heavy motorway traffic, the vehicle behind you is following too closely. How can you lower the risk of a collision?

options.description: A. Move onto the hard shoulder and stop
B. Brake sharply
C. Increase your distance from the vehicle in front
D. Switch on your hazard warning lights

questions.explanation: When it’s foggy, use dipped headlights. This will help you see and be seen by other road users. If visibility is seriously reduced, consider using front and rear fog lights if you have them. Keep to a sensible speed and don’t follow the vehicle in front too closely. If the road is wet and slippery, you’ll need to allow twice the normal stopping distance.

prashna.text: You're following other vehicles in fog. You have your lights on. What else can you do to reduce the chances of being in a collision?

options.description: A. Keep close to the vehicle in front
B. Use your main beam instead of dipped headlights
C. Keep up with the faster vehicles
D. Reduce your speed and increase the gap in front

questions.explanation: In a contraflow system, you'll be travelling close to oncoming traffic and sometimes in narrow lanes. You should get into the correct lane in good time, obey any temporary speed-limit signs and keep a safe separation distance from the vehicle ahead.

prashna.text: You're using a contraflow system. What should you do?

options.description: A. Choose an appropriate lane in good time
B. Switch lanes at any time to make progress
C. Increase speed to pass through quickly
D. Follow other motorists closely to avoid long queues

questions.explanation: When riding, make sure you wear suitable clothing for the conditions. Getting cold and wet will make you uncomfortable. This can cause you to lose concentration and considerably slow down your reaction time. Stop in a safe place to have a hot drink and warm up before this happens.

prashna.text: What’s likely to happen if you get cold and wet when riding a motorcycle?

options.description: A. Your visor will freeze up
B. Your reactions will be quicker
C. Your concentration will be impaired
D. Your riding will improve

questions.explanation: Give your signal in good time and return your hand to the handlebars before changing speed or direction. While you’re giving an arm signal you have reduced steering control and you’re unable to operate some controls. If you’re travelling at speed, it’s generally safer to rely on your direction indicators and brake lights.

prashna.text: Which arm signal means ‘I intend to slow down or stop’?

questions.explanation: If you need glasses to bring your eyesight up to the legal standard for driving or riding, you must wear them whenever you ride. Don’t be tempted to ride if you’ve lost or forgotten your glasses; you'll endanger yourself and other road users, and you’ll be breaking the law.

prashna.text: You're about to ride home but you can't find the glasses you need to wear. What should you do?

options.description: A. Borrow a friend’s glasses and use those
B. Ride home slowly, keeping to quiet roads
C. Ride home at night, so that the lights will help you
D. Find a way of getting home without riding

questions.explanation: Even a small amount of alcohol will impair a person’s judgement. It can increase confidence to a point where a person’s behaviour may become ‘out of character’. Someone who normally behaves sensibly may take risks and could endanger themselves and others. Don’t drink and ride, or accept a lift from anyone who’s been drinking.

prashna.text: Which of these is an effect of drinking alcohol?

options.description: A. Colour blindness
B. Increased concentration
C. Faster reactions
D. Poor judgement

questions.explanation: Have your eyesight tested before you start your practical training. Then have checks periodically throughout your riding life, as your vision may change.

prashna.text: You find that you need glasses to read vehicle number plates at the required distance. When must you wear them?

options.description: A. Only in bad weather conditions
B. Only when you think it's necessary
C. At all times when riding
D. Only in bad light or at night time

questions.explanation: Never drink if you’re going to drive or ride. Your judgement can be seriously affected, even if you aren’t over the drink-drive limit. Don’t take risks; it isn't worth it.

prashna.text: How are you likely to be affected by drinking alcohol?

options.description: A. Your judgement of speed will be worse
B. Your awareness of danger will improve
C. You'll be more cautious and perceptive
D. The speed of your reactions will increase

questions.explanation: If you're riding at night or in poor visibility, tinted lenses or a tinted visor will reduce the amount of available light reaching your eyes, making you less able to see clearly.

prashna.text: Which type of glasses shouldn't be worn when riding at night?

options.description: A. Round
B. Tinted
C. Half-moon
D. Bifocal

questions.explanation: Hazard warning lights are an important safety feature. Use them when riding on a motorway to warn following traffic of danger ahead. You should also use them if your motorcycle has broken down and is causing an obstruction.

prashna.text: In which of these circumstances may you use hazard warning lights?

options.description: A. When riding in town, to warn oncoming traffic that you intend to stop
B. When your direction indicators aren't working
C. When riding on a motorway, to warn traffic behind of a hazard ahead
D. When you’re double parked on a two-way road

questions.explanation: The use of ear plugs is recommended to protect your hearing from being damaged by the noise of air turbulence around your helmet. Staying within the national speed limit, a rider may experience noise levels in excess of 100 decibels.

prashna.text: Why should you wear ear plugs when riding a motorcycle?

options.description: A. To help keep you warm
B. To make you less aware of traffic
C. To help prevent hearing damage
D. To make your helmet fit better

questions.explanation: Drinking even the smallest amount of alcohol can affect your judgement and reactions. The safest and best option is to avoid any alcohol at all when riding or driving.

prashna.text: You're going to a social event and alcohol will be available. You'll be riding your motorcycle shortly afterwards. What's the safest thing to do?

options.description: A. Stay just below the legal limit
B. Stick to non-alcoholic drinks
C. Don’t go beyond the legal limit
D. Have soft drinks and alcohol in turn

questions.explanation: Riding while under the influence of drink or drugs can invalidate your insurance. It also endangers yourself and others. The risk isn't worth taking.

prashna.text: You're convicted of riding after drinking too much alcohol. How could this affect your insurance?

options.description: A. Cover will only be given for riding smaller motorcycles
B. You'll only be able to get third-party cover
C. The amount of excess you pay will be reduced
D. Your insurance may become invalid

questions.explanation: Take a check over your shoulder before committing yourself to a manoeuvre. This is especially important when turning right, as other road users may not have seen your signal or may not understand your intentions.

prashna.text: Why should you check over your shoulder before turning right into a side road?

options.description: A. To make sure the side road is clear
B. To confirm your intention to turn
C. To check for overtaking vehicles
D. To check for emerging traffic

questions.explanation: If you’re taking medicine or drugs prescribed by your doctor, check to make sure they won’t make you drowsy. If you forget to ask when you’re at the surgery, check with your pharmacist.

prashna.text: You aren't sure whether your cough medicine will affect your ability to ride safely. What should you do?

options.description: A. Ask your doctor
B. Ask a friend or relative for advice
C. Ride if you feel all right
D. Don't take the medicine

questions.explanation: Hazard warning lights are an important safety feature and should be used if you've broken down and are causing an obstruction. Don’t use them as an excuse to park illegally, even for a short time. You may also use them on motorways to warn following traffic of danger ahead.

prashna.text: When should you use hazard warning lights?

options.description: A. When your direction indicators aren't working
B. When your motorcycle has broken down and is causing an obstruction
C. When you're double-parked on a two-way road
D. When warning oncoming traffic that you intend to stop

questions.explanation: In very hot weather, the road surface can become soft and may melt. Take care when braking and cornering on soft tarmac, as this can lead to reduced grip and cause skidding.

prashna.text: It's a very hot day. What would you expect to find?

options.description: A. Banks of fog
B. Mud on the road
C. Roadworks ahead
D. A soft road surface

questions.explanation: These markers must be fitted to vehicles over 13 metres long, large goods vehicles, and rubbish skips placed in the road. They’re reflective to make them easier to see in the dark.

prashna.text: Where would you expect to see these markers?

options.description: A. On a diversion sign
B. On a motorway sign
C. On a large goods vehicle
D. On a railway bridge

questions.explanation: Look at the picture carefully and try to imagine you’re there. The cyclist in this picture appears to be trying to cross the road. You must be able to deal with the unexpected, especially when you’re approaching a hazardous junction. Look well ahead to give yourself time to deal with any hazards.

prashna.text: What's the main hazard shown in this picture?

options.description: A. Parked cars around the corner
B. Vehicles doing U-turns
C. The cyclist crossing the road
D. Vehicles turning right

questions.explanation:
The car arrowed A is parked within the area marked by zigzag lines at the pedestrian crossing. Parking here is illegal. It also
• blocks the view for pedestrians wishing to cross the road
• restricts the view of the crossing for approaching traffic.

prashna.text: Which road user has caused a hazard?

options.description: A. The parked car (arrowed A)
B. The pedestrian waiting to cross (arrowed B)
C. The car turning (arrowed D)
D. The moving car (arrowed C)

questions.explanation: Look well ahead to see whether any hazards are developing. This will give you more time to deal with them in the correct way. The man in the picture is clearly intending to cross the road. You should be travelling at a speed that allows you to check your mirror, slow down and stop in good time. You shouldn’t have to brake harshly.

prashna.text: What should the driver of the car approaching the crossing do?

options.description: A. Continue at the same speed
B. Drive through quickly
C. Sound the horn
D. Slow down and get ready to stop

questions.explanation: When passing parked cars, there's a risk that a driver or passenger may not check before opening the door into the road. A defensive driver will drive slowly and be looking for people who may be about to get out of their car.

prashna.text: What should the driver of the grey car (arrowed) be especially aware of?

options.description: A. The uneven road surface
B. Traffic following behind
C. Doors opening on parked cars
D. Empty parking spaces

questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road will bend sharply to the left. Slow down in plenty of time and select the correct gear before you start to turn. Braking hard and late, while also sharply changing direction, is likely to cause a skid.

prashna.text: You see this sign ahead. What should you expect?

options.description: A. The road will bend sharply to the left
B. The road will go steeply downhill
C. The road will go steeply uphill
D. The road will bend sharply to the right

questions.explanation: Keep well back and give the cyclist time and room to turn safely. Don’t intimidate them by getting too close or trying to squeeze past.

prashna.text: You're approaching this cyclist. What should you do?

options.description: A. Flash your headlights at the cyclist
B. Slow down and allow the cyclist to turn
C. Overtake the cyclist on the left-hand side
D. Overtake before the cyclist gets to the junction

questions.explanation: You may have to pull forward slowly until you can see up and down the road. Be aware that the traffic approaching the junction can’t see you either. If you don’t know that it’s clear, don’t go.

prashna.text: Why must you take extra care when turning right at this junction?

options.description: A. The road surface is poor
B. The road markings are faint
C. The view is restricted
D. The footpaths are narrow

questions.explanation: A double-deck bus or high-sided lorry will have to take a position in the centre of the road to clear the bridge. There's normally a sign to show this. Look well ahead, past the bridge and be ready to stop and give way to large oncoming vehicles.

prashna.text: Which type of vehicle should you be ready to give way to as you approach this bridge?

options.description: A. Cars
B. Motorcycles
C. Bicycles
D. Buses

questions.explanation: The highest point of the bridge is in the centre, so a large vehicle might have to move to the centre of the road to have enough room to pass under the bridge.

prashna.text: What type of vehicle could you expect to meet in the middle of the road?

options.description: A. Car
B. Motorcycle
C. Lorry
D. Bicycle

questions.explanation: The ‘stop’ sign has been put here because the view into the main road is poor. You must stop because it won't be possible to take proper observation while you're moving.

prashna.text: What must you do at this junction?

options.description: A. Stop only if there's traffic on the main road
B. Stop only if you're turning right
C. Stop behind the line, then edge forward to see clearly
D. Stop beyond the line, at a point where you can see clearly

questions.explanation: Be tolerant if a vehicle emerges and you have to brake quickly. Anyone can make a mistake, so don’t react aggressively. Be alert where there are side roads and be especially careful where there are parked vehicles, because these can make it difficult for emerging drivers to see you.

prashna.text: A driver pulls out of a side road in front of you, causing you to brake hard. What should you do?

options.description: A. Flash your lights to show your annoyance
B. Ignore the error and stay calm
C. Overtake as soon as possible
D. Sound your horn to show your annoyance

questions.explanation: Be tolerant of older drivers. They may take longer to react to a hazard and they may be hesitant in some situations – for example, at a junction.

prashna.text: How would age affect an elderly person's driving ability?

options.description: A. They'll take longer to react to hazards
B. They'll need glasses to read road signs
C. They won't signal at junctions
D. They won't be able to obtain car insurance

questions.explanation: These lights warn that children may be crossing the road to a nearby school. Slow down so that you’re ready to stop if necessary.

prashna.text: You've just passed these warning lights. What hazard would you expect to see next?

options.description: A. A level crossing with no barrier
B. An opening bridge
C. A school crossing patrol
D. An ambulance station

questions.explanation: Try to plan your journey so that you can take rest stops. It’s recommended that you take a break of at least 15 minutes after every two hours of driving or riding. This should help to maintain your concentration.

prashna.text: You’re planning a long journey. Do you need to plan rest stops?

options.description: A. Yes, regular stops help concentration
B. Yes, you should plan to stop every half an hour
C. No, you’ll be less tired if you get there as soon as possible
D. No, only fuel stops will be needed

questions.explanation: At level crossings, the red lights flash before and while the barrier is down. At most crossings, an amber light will precede the red lights. You must stop behind the white line unless you've already crossed it when the amber light comes on. Never zigzag around half-barriers.

prashna.text: The red lights are flashing. What should you do when approaching this level crossing?

options.description: A. Switch on hazard warning lights
B. Go through carefully
C. Go through quickly
D. Stop before the barrier

questions.explanation: When approaching a junction where the traffic lights have failed, you should proceed with caution. Treat the situation as an unmarked junction and be prepared to stop.

prashna.text: You're approaching a crossroads. The traffic lights have failed. What should you do?

options.description: A. Brake sharply to a stop before looking
B. Be prepared to stop for any traffic
C. Brake and stop only for large vehicles
D. Be prepared to brake sharply to a stop

questions.explanation: Some people might take a long time to cross the road. They may be older or have a disability. Be patient and don’t hurry them by showing your impatience. If pedestrians are standing at the side of the road, don’t signal or wave them to cross. Other road users might not have seen your signal and this could lead the pedestrians into a hazardous situation.

prashna.text: What should the driver of the red car (arrowed) do?

options.description: A. Wait for the pedestrian in the road to cross
B. Wave towards the pedestrians who are waiting to cross
C. Quickly drive behind the pedestrian in the road
D. Tell the pedestrian in the road she shouldn't have crossed

questions.explanation: You should never overtake as you approach a junction. If a vehicle emerged from the junction while you were overtaking, a dangerous situation could develop very quickly.

prashna.text: You're following a slower-moving vehicle on a narrow country road. There's a junction just ahead on the right. What should you do?

options.description: A. Only consider overtaking when you're past the junction
B. Overtake after checking your mirrors and signalling
C. Slow down and prepare to overtake on the left
D. Accelerate quickly to pass before the junction

questions.explanation: Oncoming large vehicles may need to move to the middle of the road to pass safely under the bridge. There won't be enough room for you to continue, so you should be ready to stop and wait.

prashna.text: What should you do as you approach this overhead bridge?

options.description: A. Move out to the centre of the road before going through
B. Move across to the right-hand side before going through
C. Be prepared to give way to large vehicles in the middle of the road
D. Find another route; this one is only for high vehicles

questions.explanation: Although a convex mirror gives a wide view of the scene behind, you should be aware that it won't show you everything behind or to the side of your vehicle. Before you move off, you'll need to look over your shoulder to check for anything not visible in the mirrors.

prashna.text: Why are mirrors often slightly curved (convex)?

options.description: A. They make following traffic look bigger
B. They give a wider field of vision
C. They totally cover blind spots
D. They make it easier to judge the speed of following traffic

questions.explanation: This sign is found on slow-moving or stationary works vehicles. If you wish to overtake, do so on the left, as indicated. Be aware that there might be workmen in the area.

prashna.text: A slow-moving lorry showing this sign is travelling in the middle lane of a three-lane motorway. How should you pass it?

options.description: A. Cautiously approach the lorry, then pass on either side
B. Approach with care and pass on the left of the lorry
C. Use the right-hand lane and pass the lorry normally
D. Don't pass the lorry and leave the motorway at the next exit

questions.explanation: Be cautious and don’t attempt to overtake. The driver may be unsure of the location of a junction and may turn suddenly.

prashna.text: You think the driver of the vehicle in front has forgotten to cancel their right indicator. What should you do?

options.description: A. Sound your horn before overtaking
B. Overtake on the left if there's room
C. Flash your lights to alert the driver
D. Stay behind and don't overtake

questions.explanation: If you can do so safely, give way to buses signalling to move off at bus stops. Try to anticipate the actions of other road users around you. The driver of the red car should be prepared for the bus pulling out. As you approach a bus stop, look to see how many passengers are waiting to board. If the last one has just got on, the bus is likely to move off.

prashna.text: What's the main hazard the driver of the red car (arrowed) should be aware of?

options.description: A. The bus may move out into the road
B. The black car may stop suddenly
C. Oncoming vehicles will assume the driver is turning right
D. Glare from the sun may affect the driver’s vision

questions.explanation: Buses which carry children to and from school may stop at places other than scheduled bus stops. Be aware that they might pull over at any time to allow children to get on or off. This will normally be when traffic is heavy during rush hour.

prashna.text: What type of vehicle displays this yellow sign?

options.description: A. A school bus
B. A private ambulance
C. A broken-down vehicle
D. An ice-cream van

questions.explanation: On roads where there are many parked vehicles, you might not be able to see children between parked cars and they may run out into the road without looking.

prashna.text: What hazard should you be aware of when travelling along this street?

options.description: A. Glare from the sun
B. Large goods vehicles
C. Lack of road markings
D. Children running out between vehicles

questions.explanation: When following a cyclist, be aware that they have to deal with the hazards around them. They may wobble or swerve to avoid a pothole in the road or see a potential hazard and change direction suddenly. Don’t follow them too closely or rev your engine impatiently.

prashna.text: What's the main hazard you should be aware of when following this cyclist?

options.description: A. The cyclist may move to the left and dismount
B. The cyclist may wish to turn right at the end of the road
C. The contents of the cyclist’s carrier may fall onto the road
D. The cyclist may swerve into the road

questions.explanation: If you feel yourself becoming tense or upset, stop in a safe place and take a break. Tiredness can make things worse and may cause a different reaction to upsetting situations.

prashna.text: A driver’s behaviour has upset you. What can you do to safely get over this incident?

options.description: A. Stop and take a break
B. Gesture to them with your hand
C. Shout abusive language
D. Follow them, flashing your headlights

questions.explanation: Traffic-calming measures such as road humps, chicanes and narrowings are intended to slow drivers down to protect vulnerable road users. Don't speed up until you reach the end of the traffic-calmed zone.

prashna.text: How should you drive in areas with traffic-calming measures?

options.description: A. At a reduced speed
B. At the speed limit
C. In the centre of the road
D. With headlights on dipped beam

questions.explanation: You should be slowing down and selecting the correct gear in case you have to stop at the level crossing. Look for the signals and be prepared to stop if necessary.

prashna.text: When approaching this hazard, why should you slow down?

options.description: A. Because of approaching traffic
B. Because of the level crossing
C. Because of animals crossing
D. Because it’s hard to see to the right

questions.explanation: The names of towns and cities may be painted on the road at busy junctions and complex road systems. Their purpose is to let you move into the correct lane in good time, allowing traffic to flow more freely.

prashna.text: Why are place names painted on the road surface?

options.description: A. To enable you to change lanes early
B. To restrict the flow of traffic
C. To prevent you changing lanes
D. To warn you of oncoming traffic

questions.explanation: If you intend to overtake, you must consider that approaching traffic could be planning the same manoeuvre. When you've considered the situation and decided it's safe, indicate your intentions early. This will show the approaching traffic that you intend to pull out.

prashna.text: Some two-way roads are divided into three lanes. Why are these particularly dangerous?

options.description: A. Traffic in both directions can use the middle lane to overtake
B. Traffic can travel faster in poor weather conditions
C. Traffic uses the middle lane for emergencies only
D. Traffic can overtake on the left

questions.explanation: An amber flashing light on a vehicle indicates that it's slow-moving. Battery-powered vehicles used by disabled people are limited to 8 mph. It isn't advisable for them to be used on dual carriageways where the speed limit exceeds 50 mph. If they are, then an amber flashing light must be used.

prashna.text: You're on a dual carriageway. Ahead, you see a vehicle with an amber flashing light. What could this be?

options.description: A. An ambulance
B. A fire engine
C. A doctor on call
D. A disabled person’s vehicle

questions.explanation: Police officers may need to direct traffic; for example, at a junction where the traffic lights have broken down. Check your copy of The Highway Code for the signals that they use.

prashna.text: What does this signal from a police officer mean to oncoming traffic?

options.description: A. Turn left
B. Go ahead
C. Turn right
D. Stop

questions.explanation: A stationary bus at a bus stop can hide pedestrians who might try to cross the road just in front of it. Drive at a speed that will enable you to respond safely if you have to.

prashna.text: Why should you be cautious when going past this stationary bus?

options.description: A. The driver may open the door
B. The road surface will be slippery
C. There is traffic approaching in the distance
D. People may cross the road in front of it

questions.explanation: You should overtake only when it's really necessary and you can see it’s clear ahead. Look out for road signs and markings that show it's illegal or would be unsafe to overtake; for example, approaching junctions or bends. In many cases, overtaking is unlikely to significantly improve your journey time.

prashna.text: Where shouldn't you overtake?

options.description: A. On a single carriageway
B. Approaching a junction
C. Travelling up a long hill
D. On a one-way street

questions.explanation:
Alcohol will severely reduce your ability to drive or ride safely and there are serious consequences if you’re caught over the drink-drive limit. It's known that alcohol can
•  affect your judgement
•  cause overconfidence
•  reduce coordination and control.

prashna.text: What’s an effect of drinking alcohol?

options.description: A. Faster reactions
B. Poor judgement of speed
C. Greater awareness of danger
D. A loss of confidence

questions.explanation: If you follow a large vehicle too closely, your view beyond it will be restricted. Drop back. This will help you to see more of the road ahead. It will also help the driver of the large vehicle to see you in their mirrors and will give you a safe separation distance if the lorry needs to stop suddenly.

prashna.text: Why should you keep a large gap between your motorcycle and a lorry in front?

options.description: A. So drivers behind can see you
B. So wind from the lorry won't slow you down
C. So you don't breathe in the lorry’s exhaust fumes
D. So your view ahead isn't obstructed

questions.explanation: Try not to startle the animals. They can be easily frightened by noise or by traffic passing too closely. Slow down, give them plenty of room and be prepared to stop if necessary. Obey any directions given by people in charge of the animals.

prashna.text: You're riding on a country lane. What should you do if you come across cattle on the road?

options.description: A. Give them plenty of room
B. Rev your engine
C. Ride up close behind them
D. Sound your horn

questions.explanation: You should always be looking for vehicles emerging from side roads as you approach them. If you see another vehicle begin to emerge into your path, be ready to slow down or stop if necessary.

prashna.text: A learner driver begins to emerge into your path from a side road on the left. What should you do?

options.description: A. Let them emerge, then ride close behind
B. Brake hard, then wave them out
C. Be ready to slow down and stop
D. Turn into the side road

questions.explanation: Learner drivers might take longer to react to traffic situations, so be patient and give them time. Don’t unnerve them by riding close behind or showing signs of impatience.

prashna.text: The vehicle ahead is being driven by a learner. What should you do?

options.description: A. Sound your horn and overtake
B. Ride close behind
C. Put your headlights on main beam
D. Keep calm and be patient

questions.explanation: By increasing the separation distance between you and the vehicle in front, you have a greater safety margin. If the vehicle in front of you brakes suddenly to avoid a hazard, you'll have time to reduce speed gradually. This will reduce the risk of the close-following vehicle running into you.

prashna.text: You're riding in fast-flowing traffic. The vehicle behind is following too closely. What should you do?

options.description: A. Accelerate to get away from the vehicle behind you
B. Slow down gradually to increase the gap in front of you
C. Apply the brakes sharply to warn the driver behind
D. Slow down as quickly as possible by braking

questions.explanation: As you would with any pedestrian, you should prepare to stop. Don’t wave the person across, as other traffic may not slow down.

prashna.text: You're riding towards a zebra crossing. Waiting to cross is a person in a wheelchair. What should you do?

options.description: A. Continue on your way
B. Wave to the person to wait
C. Wave to the person to cross
D. Be prepared to stop

questions.explanation: On a windy day, be aware that the blustery conditions might blow you or other motorcyclists out of position. Think about this before deciding to overtake.

prashna.text: Why should you allow extra room when overtaking another motorcyclist on a windy day?

options.description: A. The rider may be blown across in front of you
B. The rider may stop suddenly
C. The rider may turn off suddenly to get out of the wind
D. The rider may be travelling faster than normal

questions.explanation: At a pelican crossing, the green light means you may proceed as long as the crossing is clear. If someone hasn’t finished crossing, be patient and wait until the road is clear.

prashna.text: You've stopped at a pelican crossing, where a disabled person is crossing very slowly in front of you. What should you do when the lights change to green?

options.description: A. Edge forward slowly
B. Sound your horn
C. Allow the person to finish crossing
D. Ride behind the person

questions.explanation: Other motorcyclists and cyclists may be difficult to see on the road, particularly at junctions. If your view is blocked by other traffic, you may not be able to see them approaching.

prashna.text: Where should you take particular care to look out for other motorcyclists and cyclists?

options.description: A. On dual carriageways
B. On one-way streets
C. At zebra crossings
D. At junctions

questions.explanation: The lifesaver glance makes you aware of what's happening behind and alongside you before you alter your course. This glance must be timed so that you still have time to react if it isn’t safe to carry out your manoeuvre.

prashna.text: Why is it vital for a rider to make a lifesaver check before turning right?

options.description: A. To check for any overtaking traffic
B. To make sure the side road is clear
C. To confirm that they're about to turn
D. To check that the rear indicator is flashing

questions.explanation: When passing horses, allow them plenty of space and slow down. Animals can be frightened by sudden or loud noises, so don’t sound your horn or rev your engine.

prashna.text: You're about to overtake a group of horse riders. What's most likely to scare the horses?

options.description: A. Revving your engine
B. Riding slowly
C. Giving arm signals
D. Your dipped headlights

questions.explanation: Young and inexperienced motorcyclists are far more likely to be involved in incidents than more experienced riders. The reasons for this include natural exuberance, showing off, competitive behaviour and overconfidence. Don’t overestimate your abilities and never ride too fast for the conditions.

prashna.text: Young and new motorcyclists are involved in more incidents than other motorcyclists. Why is this?

options.description: A. They ride in bad weather conditions
B. They use borrowed equipment
C. They don't maintain their motorcycles
D. They lack experience and judgement

questions.explanation: Young and inexperienced motorcyclists often have more confidence than ability. It takes time to gain experience and become a good rider. Make sure you have the right attitude and put safety first.

prashna.text: What would make a young motorcyclist especially vulnerable?

options.description: A. Getting cheap insurance
B. Having faster reactions than older riders
C. Wearing newer gear than experienced riders
D. Overestimating their own ability

questions.explanation: Parking here will block the view of the road, endangering the lives of children crossing the road on their way to and from school.

prashna.text: The road outside this school is marked with yellow zigzag lines. What do these lines mean?

options.description: A. You may park on the lines when dropping off schoolchildren
B. You may park on the lines when picking up schoolchildren
C. You must stay with your motorcycle if you park here
D. You must not wait or park your motorcycle here

questions.explanation: Always check the road signs. Triangular signs are warning signs: they inform you about hazards ahead and help you to anticipate any problems. There are a number of different signs showing pedestrians. Learn the meaning of each one.

prashna.text: Which sign means that there may be people walking along the road?

questions.explanation: When you’re turning into a side road, pedestrians who are crossing have priority. You should wait to allow them to finish crossing safely. Be patient if they're slow or unsteady. Don't try to rush them by sounding your horn, flashing your lights, revving your engine or giving any other inappropriate signal.

prashna.text: You're turning left at a junction where pedestrians have started to cross. What should you do?

options.description: A. Sound your horn and proceed
B. Go around them, leaving plenty of room
C. Give way to them
D. Stop and wave at them to cross

questions.explanation: Make sure that you've reduced your speed and are in the correct gear for the turn. Look into the road before you turn and always give way to any pedestrians who are crossing.

prashna.text: You're turning left into a side road. What hazard should you be especially aware of?

options.description: A. Parked vehicles
B. One-way street
C. Traffic congestion
D. Pedestrians

questions.explanation: Never attempt to change direction to the right without first checking your right-hand mirror and blind spot. A motorcyclist might not have seen your signal and could be hidden by other traffic. This observation should become a matter of routine.

prashna.text: You intend to turn right into a side road. Why should you check for motorcyclists just before turning?

options.description: A. They may be following you closely
B. They may be overtaking on your left
C. They may be overtaking on your right
D. They may be emerging from the side road

questions.explanation: Toucan crossings are shared by pedestrians and cyclists, who are permitted to cycle across. They're shown the green light together. The signals are push-button-operated and there's no flashing amber phase.

prashna.text: Why is a toucan crossing different from other crossings?

options.description: A. Moped riders can use it
B. It's controlled by a traffic warden
C. Cyclists can use it
D. It's controlled by two flashing lights

questions.explanation: If a school crossing patrol steps out into the road with a 'stop' sign, you must stop. Don’t wave anyone across the road and don’t get impatient or rev your engine.

prashna.text: How will a school crossing patrol signal you to stop?

options.description: A. By pointing to children on the opposite pavement
B. By displaying a red light
C. By giving you an arm signal
D. By displaying a 'stop' sign

questions.explanation: Vehicles that are used to carry children to and from school will be travelling at busy times of the day. If you’re following a vehicle with this sign, be prepared for it to make frequent stops. It might pick up or set down passengers in places other than normal bus stops.

prashna.text: Where would you see this sign?

options.description: A. At playground areas
B. On the rear of a school bus or coach
C. At the side of the road
D. In the window of a car taking children to school

questions.explanation: This sign shows a shared route for pedestrians and cyclists: when it ends, the cyclists will be rejoining the main road.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. A route for cyclists only
B. A route for pedestrians only
C. A route for pedestrians and cyclists
D. No route for pedestrians and cyclists

questions.explanation: When someone is deaf as well as blind, they may carry a white stick with a red reflective band. They may not be aware that you're approaching and they may not be able to hear anything; so, for example, your horn would be ineffective as a warning to them.

prashna.text: You see a pedestrian carrying a white stick with a red band. What does this tell you?

options.description: A. They're deaf
B. They have limited mobility
C. They're deaf and blind
D. They're blind

questions.explanation: Be aware that older people might take a long time to cross the road. They might also be hard of hearing and not hear you approaching. Don’t hurry older people across the road by getting too close to them or revving your engine.

prashna.text: What action would you take when elderly people are crossing the road?

options.description: A. Tap the horn in case they're hard of hearing
B. Wave them across so they know that you've seen them
C. Be patient and allow them to cross in their own time
D. Rev the engine to let them know that you're waiting

questions.explanation: Older people may have impaired hearing, vision, concentration and judgement. They may also walk slowly and so could take a long time to cross the road.

prashna.text: What should you do when you see two elderly pedestrians about to cross the road ahead?

options.description: A. Be careful; they may misjudge your speed
B. Expect them to wait for you to pass
C. Stop and wave them across the road
D. Speed up to get past them quickly

questions.explanation: If you’re following a cyclist who’s signalling to turn right at a roundabout, leave plenty of room. Give them space and time to get into the correct lane.

prashna.text: You're coming up to a roundabout. A cyclist is signalling to turn right. What should you do?

options.description: A. Signal the cyclist to move across
B. Give the cyclist plenty of room
C. Overtake on the right
D. Give a warning with your horn

questions.explanation:
Don’t pass cyclists too closely, as they may
• need to veer around a pothole or other obstacle
• be buffeted by side wind
• be made unsteady by your vehicle.
Always leave as much room as you would for a car, and don’t cut in front of them.

prashna.text: Which of these should you allow extra room when overtaking?

options.description: A. Road-sweeping vehicle
B. Tractor
C. Bicycle
D. Lorry

questions.explanation: Cyclists and motorcyclists are smaller than other vehicles and so are more difficult to see. They can easily be hidden from your view by cars parked near a junction.

prashna.text: Why should you look particularly for motorcyclists and cyclists at junctions?

options.description: A. They might not see you turn
B. They're harder to see
C. They may slow down to let you turn
D. They may want to turn into the side road

questions.explanation: If you’re waiting to emerge from a side road, look carefully for motorcycles: they can be difficult to see. Be especially careful if there are parked vehicles or other obstructions restricting your view.

prashna.text: You’re waiting to come out of a side road. Why should you look carefully for motorcycles?

options.description: A. Motorcycles can easily be hidden behind obstructions
B. Motorcycles are usually faster than cars
C. Motorcycles have right of way
D. Police patrols often use motorcycles

questions.explanation: A motorcycle can be lost from sight behind another vehicle. The use of the headlights helps to make it more conspicuous and therefore more easily seen.

prashna.text: In daylight, an approaching motorcyclist is using dipped headlights. Why?

options.description: A. The rider is inviting you to proceed
B. So that the rider can be seen more easily
C. To improve the rider’s vision
D. To stop the battery overcharging

questions.explanation: Motorcycles and scooters are generally smaller than other vehicles and can be difficult to see. Wearing bright clothing makes it easier for other road users to see a motorcyclist approaching, especially at junctions.

prashna.text: Why should motorcyclists wear bright clothing?

options.description: A. They must do so by law
B. It helps keep them cool in summer
C. The colours are popular
D. Drivers often do not see them

questions.explanation: When a motorcyclist is travelling slowly, it's likely that they're looking for a turning or entrance. Be patient and stay behind them in case they stop or change direction suddenly.

prashna.text: You're unsure what a slow-moving motorcyclist ahead of you is going to do. What should you do?

options.description: A. Pass on the right
B. Pass on the left
C. Stay behind
D. Move closer

questions.explanation: When you see a motorcyclist take a glance over their shoulder, they're probably about to change direction. Recognising a clue like this helps you to anticipate their next action. This can improve road safety for you and others.

prashna.text: Why will a motorcyclist look round over their right shoulder just before turning right?

options.description: A. It helps them balance as they turn
B. To listen for following traffic
C. Motorcycles don't have mirrors
D. To check for traffic in their blind area

questions.explanation: Pedestrians and riders on two wheels can be harder to see than other road users. Make sure you look for them, especially at junctions. Effective observation, coupled with appropriate action, can save lives.

prashna.text: Which is the most vulnerable road user at road junctions?

options.description: A. Motorcyclist
B. Car driver
C. Lorry driver
D. Tractor driver

questions.explanation: Horse riders often keep to the outside of the roundabout even if they're turning right. Give them plenty of room and remember that they may have to cross lanes of traffic.

prashna.text: You're approaching a roundabout. There are horses just ahead of you. What should you do?

options.description: A. Treat them like any other vehicle
B. Sound your horn as a warning
C. Give them plenty of room
D. Accelerate past as quickly as possible

questions.explanation: If the lights turn to green, wait for any pedestrians to clear the crossing. Allow them to finish crossing the road in their own time, and don’t try to hurry them by revving your engine.

prashna.text: As you approach a pelican crossing, the lights change to green. What should you do if elderly people are halfway across?

options.description: A. Wait patiently because they'll probably take longer to cross
B. Rev your engine to make them hurry
C. Wave them to cross as quickly as they can
D. Flash your lights in case they haven't noticed you

questions.explanation: The flashing amber lights are switched on to warn you that children may be crossing near a school. Slow down and take extra care, as you may have to stop.

prashna.text: There are flashing amber lights under a school warning sign. What action should you take?

options.description: A. Increase your speed to clear the area quickly
B. Wait at the lights until they change to green
C. Keep up your speed and sound the horn
D. Reduce speed until you're clear of the area

questions.explanation:
The markings are there to show that the area must be kept clear. This is to allow an unrestricted view for
• approaching drivers and riders
• children wanting to cross the road.

prashna.text: Why must these road markings be kept clear?

options.description: A. To allow schoolchildren to be picked up
B. To allow a clear view of the crossing area
C. To allow teachers to park
D. To allow schoolchildren to be dropped off

questions.explanation: Watch out for children crossing the road from the other side of the bus.

prashna.text: Where would you see this sign?

options.description: A. On a school bus
B. Near a school crossing
C. At a playground entrance
D. At a ‘pedestrians only’ area

questions.explanation: Cyclists approaching a roundabout in the left-hand lane may be turning right but may not have been able to get into the correct lane due to heavy traffic. They may also feel safer keeping to the left all the way around the roundabout. Be aware of them and give them plenty of room.

prashna.text: You're following two cyclists. They approach a roundabout in the left-hand lane. In which direction should you expect the cyclists to go?

options.description: A. Right
B. Any direction
C. Left
D. Straight ahead

questions.explanation: Passing the moped and turning into the junction could mean that you cut across the front of the rider. This might force them to slow down, stop or even lose control. Stay behind the moped until it has passed the junction and then you can turn without affecting the rider.

prashna.text: You're travelling behind a moped. What should you do when you want to turn left just ahead?

options.description: A. Pull alongside the moped and stay level until just before the junction
B. Overtake the moped before the junction
C. Stay behind until the moped has passed the junction
D. Sound your horn as a warning and pull in front of the moped

questions.explanation: Allow the horse rider to enter and exit the roundabout in their own time. They may feel safer keeping to the left all the way around the roundabout. Don’t get up close behind or alongside them, because that would probably upset the horse and create a dangerous situation.

prashna.text: You see a horse rider as you approach a roundabout. What should you do if they're signalling right but keeping well to the left?

options.description: A. Cut in front of them
B. Keep close to them
C. Proceed as normal
D. Stay well back

questions.explanation: Learners might not have confidence when they first start to drive. Allow them plenty of room and don’t react adversely to their hesitation. We all learn from experience, but new drivers will have had less practice in dealing with all the situations that might occur.

prashna.text: How would you react to drivers who appear to be inexperienced?

options.description: A. Be patient and prepare for them to react more slowly
B. Sound your horn to warn them of your presence
C. Overtake them as soon as possible
D. Flash your headlights to indicate that it's safe for them to proceed

questions.explanation: Learning to drive is a process of practice and experience. Try to understand this and tolerate those who make mistakes while they’re learning.

prashna.text: What should you do when you’re following a learner driver who stalls at a junction?

options.description: A. Be patient, as you expect them to make mistakes
B. Immediately steer around them and drive on
C. Start to rev your engine if they take too long to restart
D. Stay very close behind and flash your headlights

questions.explanation: On a quiet country road, always be aware that there may be a hazard just around the next bend, such as a slow-moving vehicle or pedestrians. Pedestrians are advised to walk on the right-hand side of the road if there's no pavement, so they may be walking towards you on your side of the road.

prashna.text: You're on a country road. What should you expect to see coming towards you on your side of the road?

options.description: A. Pedestrians
B. Motorcycles
C. Horse riders
D. Bicycles

questions.explanation: You must show consideration to other road users. The reactions of older drivers may be slower and they might need more time to deal with a situation. Be tolerant and don’t lose patience or show annoyance.

prashna.text: What should you do when following a car driven by an elderly driver?

options.description: A. Expect the driver to drive badly
B. Be aware that their reactions may be slower than yours
C. Stay very close behind but be careful
D. Flash your lights and overtake

questions.explanation: Make allowances for cyclists, and give them plenty of room. Don’t overtake and then immediately turn left. Be patient and turn behind them when they've passed the junction.

prashna.text: You're following a cyclist. What should you do when you wish to turn left just ahead?

options.description: A. Go around the cyclist on the junction
B. Overtake the cyclist before you reach the junction
C. Hold back until the cyclist has passed the junction
D. Pull alongside the cyclist and stay level until after the junction

questions.explanation: Horses and their riders move more slowly than other road users. They might not have time to cut across heavy traffic to take up a position in the right-hand lane. For this reason, a horse and rider may approach a roundabout in the left-hand lane even though they’re turning right.

prashna.text: A horse rider is in the left-hand lane approaching a roundabout. Where should you expect the rider to go?

options.description: A. To the right
B. In any direction
C. Straight ahead
D. To the left

questions.explanation: Powered vehicles used by disabled people are small, low, hard to see and travel very slowly. On a dual carriageway, a flashing amber light will warn other road users.

prashna.text: Powered vehicles used by disabled people are small and hard to see. How do they give early warning when on a dual carriageway?

options.description: A. They'll have a flashing red light
B. They'll have a flashing amber light
C. They'll have a flashing green light
D. They'll have a flashing blue light

questions.explanation: If you want to turn left and there’s a cyclist in front of you, hold back. Wait until the cyclist has passed the junction and then turn left behind them. Don't try to intimidate them by driving too closely.

prashna.text: Where should you never overtake a cyclist?

options.description: A. On a dual carriageway
B. On a left-hand bend
C. Just before you turn left
D. On a one-way street

questions.explanation: Different coloured beacons warn of different types of vehicle needing special attention. Blue beacons are used on emergency vehicles that need priority. Green beacons are found on doctors' cars. Amber beacons generally denote slower moving vehicles, which are often large. These vehicles are usually involved in road maintenance or local amenities and make frequent stops.

prashna.text: What does a flashing amber beacon mean when it's on a moving vehicle?

options.description: A. The vehicle has broken down
B. The vehicle is slow moving
C. The vehicle belongs to a school crossing patrol
D. The vehicle is a doctor's car

questions.explanation: Usually, a picture of a cycle will also be painted on the road, and sometimes the lane will have a different coloured surface. Leave these areas clear for cyclists and don’t pass too closely when you overtake.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. With-flow cycle lane
B. No cycles or buses
C. Contraflow cycle lane
D. Cycles and buses only

questions.explanation: Be particularly careful when approaching horse riders – slow down and be prepared to stop. Always pass wide and slowly, and look out for signals given by the riders. Horses are unpredictable: always treat them as potential hazards and take great care when passing them.

prashna.text: You notice horse riders in front. What should you do first?

options.description: A. Accelerate around them
B. Signal right
C. Slow down and be ready to stop
D. Pull out to the middle of the road

questions.explanation: These markings are found on the road outside schools. Don't stop or park on them, even to set down or pick up children. The markings are there to ensure that drivers, riders, children and other pedestrians have a clear view of the road in all directions.

prashna.text: What's the purpose of these road markings?

options.description: A. To ensure delivery vehicles have easy access to the school
B. To ensure children can see and be seen when crossing the road
C. To enable teachers to have clear access to the school
D. To enable parents to pick up or drop off children safely

questions.explanation: Where street repairs have closed off pavements, proceed carefully and slowly, as pedestrians might have to walk in the road.

prashna.text: The left-hand pavement is closed due to street repairs. What should you do?

options.description: A. Watch out for pedestrians walking in the road
B. Speed up to get past the roadworks more quickly
C. Use your right-hand mirror more often
D. Position close to the left-hand kerb

questions.explanation: To avoid being unbalanced, a motorcyclist might swerve to avoid potholes and bumps in the road. Be prepared for this and allow them extra space.

prashna.text: What should you do when you're following a motorcyclist along a road that has a poor surface?

options.description: A. Follow closely so they can see you in their mirrors
B. Allow the same room as normal to avoid wasting road space
C. Allow extra room in case they swerve to avoid potholes
D. Overtake immediately to avoid delays

questions.explanation:
With people’s concern today for the environment, cycle routes are being extended in our towns and cities.
Respect the presence of cyclists on the road and give them plenty of room if you need to pass.

prashna.text: What does this sign tell you?

options.description: A. Cycle parking only
B. Cycle route ahead
C. End of cycle route
D. No cycling

questions.explanation: Cycling in today’s heavy traffic can be hazardous. Some cyclists may not feel happy about crossing the path of traffic to take up a position in an outside lane. Be aware of this and understand that, although they're in the left-hand lane, the cyclist might be turning right.

prashna.text: You're approaching this roundabout and see the cyclist signal right. Why is the cyclist keeping to the left?

options.description: A. It's a quicker route for the cyclist
B. The cyclist is slower and more vulnerable
C. The cyclist is going to turn left instead
D. The cyclist thinks The Highway Code doesn't apply to bicycles

questions.explanation: Be courteous and prepare to stop. Don't wave people across, because this could be dangerous if another vehicle is approaching the crossing.

prashna.text: What should you do when approaching this crossing?

options.description: A. Stop and wave the pedestrians across
B. Speed up and pass by quickly
C. Prepare to slow down and stop
D. Continue unless the pedestrians step out

questions.explanation: Dogs trained to help deaf people have a yellow or burgundy coat. If you see one, you should take extra care, as the pedestrian may not be aware of vehicles approaching.

prashna.text: You see a pedestrian with a dog wearing a yellow or burgundy coat. What does this indicate?

options.description: A. The pedestrian is a dog trainer
B. The pedestrian is deaf
C. The pedestrian is colour-blind
D. The pedestrian is elderly

questions.explanation: There are some crossings where cycle routes lead cyclists to cross at the same place as pedestrians. These are called toucan crossings. Always look out for cyclists, as they’re likely to be approaching faster than pedestrians.

prashna.text: Who may use toucan crossings?

options.description: A. Motorcyclists and cyclists
B. Only cyclists
C. Cyclists and pedestrians
D. Motorcyclists and pedestrians

questions.explanation: These are known as advanced stop lines. When the lights are red (or about to become red), you should stop at the first white line. However, if you've crossed that line as the lights change, you must stop at the second line even if it means you're in the area reserved for cyclists.

prashna.text: Some junctions controlled by traffic lights have a marked area between two stop lines. What's this for?

options.description: A. To allow cyclists and pedestrians to cross the road together
B. To allow taxis to position in front of other traffic
C. To allow cyclists to position in front of other traffic
D. To allow people with disabilities to cross the road

questions.explanation: Before overtaking, assess the situation. Look well ahead to see whether the cyclist will need to change direction. Be especially aware of a cyclist approaching parked vehicles, as they'll need to alter course. Don't pass too closely or cut in sharply.

prashna.text: When you're overtaking a cyclist, you should leave as much room as you would give to a car. What's the main reason for this?

options.description: A. The cyclist might get off their bike
B. The cyclist might swerve
C. The cyclist might speed up
D. The cyclist might have to make a left turn

questions.explanation: Slow down and be ready to stop if you see animals in the road ahead. Animals are easily frightened by noise and vehicles passing too close to them. Stop if signalled to do so by the person in charge.

prashna.text: What should you do when passing sheep on a road?

options.description: A. Herd them to the side of the road
B. Go very slowly
C. Pass quickly but quietly
D. Briefly sound your horn

questions.explanation: The people on the walk should be keeping to the left, but don’t assume this. Pass carefully, making sure you have time to do so safely. Be aware that the pedestrians have their backs to you and may not know that you’re there.

prashna.text: At night, you see a pedestrian wearing reflective clothing and carrying a bright red light. What does this mean?

options.description: A. You're approaching a slow-moving vehicle
B. You're approaching an organised walk
C. You're approaching a traffic danger spot
D. You're approaching roadworks

questions.explanation: New drivers and riders are often involved in a collision or incident early in their driving career. Due to a lack of experience, they may not react to hazards appropriately. Approved training courses are offered by driver and rider training schools for people who have passed their test but want extra training.

prashna.text: You’ve just passed your test. How can you reduce your risk of being involved in a collision?

options.description: A. By never going over 40 mph
B. By always staying close to the vehicle in front
C. By taking further training
D. By staying in the left-hand lane on all roads

questions.explanation: Long vehicles need more room than other vehicles to turn at junctions. The driver may take up a position that seems strange, but they have to do this to ensure their rear wheels don't mount the kerb as they turn. Don’t overtake on the left – the driver won't expect you to be there and may not see you. Staying well back will also give you a better view ahead.

prashna.text: You're riding behind a long vehicle. There's a mini-roundabout ahead. The vehicle is signalling left, but it's positioned to the right. What should you do?

options.description: A. Overtake on the left
B. Sound your horn
C. Flash your headlights
D. Keep well back

questions.explanation: Electric trams run on rails and can't deviate from the tracks. Keep a lookout for trams, as they move very quietly and can appear suddenly. Be particularly careful when crossing the rails – they can be very slippery, especially when wet.

prashna.text: Why should you be careful when riding on roads where electric trams operate?

options.description: A. They can't steer to avoid you
B. They give off harmful exhaust fumes
C. They can brake very quickly
D. They’re noisy and slow

questions.explanation: In windy weather, watch out for motorcyclists and also cyclists, as they can be blown sideways into your path. When you pass them, leave plenty of room and check their position in your mirror before pulling back in.

prashna.text: You're about to overtake a slow-moving motorcyclist. Which one of these signs would make you take special care?

questions.explanation: Large vehicles can hide other vehicles that are overtaking – especially motorcycles, which may be filtering past queuing traffic. You need to be aware of the possibility of hidden vehicles and not assume that it's safe to emerge.

prashna.text: You're waiting to emerge left from a minor road. A large vehicle is approaching from the right. You have time to turn, but you should wait. Why?

options.description: A. The large vehicle can easily hide an overtaking vehicle
B. The large vehicle can easily hide vehicles from the left
C. The large vehicle is difficult to steer in a straight line
D. The large vehicle can turn suddenly

questions.explanation: A long vehicle may need to swing out in the opposite direction as it approaches a turn, to allow the rear wheels to clear the kerb. Don’t try to filter through if you see a gap; as the lorry turns, the gap will close.

prashna.text: You're following a long vehicle. As it approaches a crossroads, it signals left but moves out to the right. What should you do?

options.description: A. Assume the signal is wrong and that it's turning right
B. Get closer in order to pass it quickly
C. Stay well back and give it room
D. Overtake it as it starts to slow down

questions.explanation: When a long vehicle is going to turn right, it may need to keep close to the left-hand kerb. This is to prevent the rear end of the trailer cutting the corner. You need to be aware of how long vehicles behave in such situations. Don’t overtake the lorry, because it could turn as you’re alongside. Stay behind and wait for it to turn.

prashna.text: You're following a long vehicle approaching a crossroads. The driver signals right but moves close to the left-hand kerb. What should you do?

options.description: A. Warn the driver about the wrong signal
B. Wait behind the long vehicle
C. Report the driver to the police
D. Overtake on the right-hand side

questions.explanation: At mini-roundabouts, there isn’t much room for a long vehicle to manoeuvre. It will have to swing out wide so that it can complete the turn safely. Keep well back and don’t try to move up alongside it.

prashna.text: You’re approaching a mini-roundabout. What should you do when you see the long vehicle in front signalling left but positioned over to the right?

options.description: A. Overtake on the left
B. Keep well back
C. Follow the same course as the lorry
D. Sound your horn

questions.explanation: When following a large vehicle, keep well back. If you’re too close, you won’t be able to see the road ahead and the driver of the long vehicle might not be able to see you in their mirrors.

prashna.text: Before overtaking a large vehicle, you should keep well back. Why is this?

options.description: A. To get the best view of the road ahead
B. To offer other drivers a safe gap if they want to overtake you
C. To leave a gap in case the vehicle stops and rolls back
D. To give acceleration space to overtake quickly on blind bends

questions.explanation:
There might be pedestrians crossing from in front of the bus. Look out for them if you intend to pass. Consider how many people are waiting to get on the bus - check the queue if you can. The bus might move off straight away if no-one is waiting to get on.
If a bus is signalling to pull out, give it priority if it’s safe to do so.

prashna.text: You're travelling behind a bus that pulls up at a bus stop. What should you do?

options.description: A. Accelerate past the bus
B. Sound your horn
C. Watch carefully for pedestrians
D. Pull in closely behind the bus

questions.explanation: Large vehicles throw up a lot of spray when it's wet. This makes it difficult for following drivers to see the road ahead. You'll be able to see more by dropping back further, out of the spray. This will also increase your separation distance, giving you more room to stop if you have to.

prashna.text: You're following a lorry on a wet road. What should you do when spray makes it difficult to see the road ahead?

options.description: A. Put your headlights on full beam
B. Keep close to the lorry, away from the spray
C. Drop back until you can see better
D. Speed up and overtake quickly

questions.explanation: Sometimes your separation distance is shortened by a driver moving into the gap you've allowed. When this happens, react positively, stay calm and drop further back to re-establish a safe following distance.

prashna.text: You keep well back while waiting to overtake a large vehicle. What should you do if a car moves into the gap?

options.description: A. Start to overtake
B. Sound your horn
C. Drop back further
D. Flash your headlights

questions.explanation: Try to give way to buses if you can do so safely, especially when the driver signals to pull away from a bus stop. Look out for people getting off the bus or running to catch it, because they may cross the road without looking. Don’t accelerate to get past the bus, and don't flash your lights, as this could mislead other road users.

prashna.text: What should you do when you're approaching a bus that's signalling to move away from a bus stop?

options.description: A. Get past before it moves
B. Allow it to pull away, if it's safe to do so
C. Flash your headlights as you approach
D. Signal left and wave the bus on

questions.explanation: When you're following a long vehicle, stay well back so that you can get a better view of the road ahead. The closer you get, the less you'll be able to see of the road. Be patient and don't take a gamble. Only overtake when you're certain that you can complete the manoeuvre safely.

prashna.text: How should you overtake a long, slow-moving vehicle on a busy road?

options.description: A. Follow it closely and keep moving out to see the road ahead
B. Flash your headlights for the oncoming traffic to give way
C. Stay behind until the driver waves you past
D. Keep well back until you can see that it's clear

questions.explanation: Although cars are the least likely to be affected, side winds can take anyone by surprise. This is most likely to happen after overtaking a large vehicle, when passing gaps between hedges or buildings, and on exposed sections of road.

prashna.text: Which of these is least likely to be affected by side winds?

options.description: A. Cars
B. High-sided vehicles
C. Motorcyclists
D. Cyclists

questions.explanation: When turning, long vehicles need much more room on the road than other vehicles. At junctions, they may take up the whole of the road space, so be patient and allow them the room they need.

prashna.text: What should you do as you approach this lorry?

options.description: A. Make the lorry wait for you
B. Move to the right-hand side of the road
C. Flash your lights at the lorry
D. Slow down and be prepared to wait

questions.explanation: Hold back and wait until the vehicle has turned before proceeding. Don't overtake, because the vehicle turning left could hide a vehicle emerging from the same junction.
