prashna.text: You're following a large vehicle approaching a crossroads. The driver signals to turn left. What should you do?

options.description: A. Overtake only if there are no oncoming vehicles
B. Overtake if you can leave plenty of room
C. Don't overtake until the vehicle begins to turn
D. Don't overtake as you approach or at the junction

questions.explanation: Some powered wheelchairs and mobility scooters are designed for use on the pavement only and cannot exceed 4 mph (6 km/h). Others can go on the road as well, and this category cannot exceed 8 mph (12 km/h). Take great care around these vehicles. They're extremely vulnerable because of their low speed and small size.

prashna.text: What's the maximum speed of powered wheelchairs or scooters used by disabled people?

options.description: A. 16 mph
B. 20 mph
C. 8 mph
D. 12 mph

questions.explanation: Depending on relative speed, it will usually take you longer to pass a lorry than other vehicles. Hazards to watch for include oncoming traffic, junctions ahead, bends or dips that could restrict your view, and signs or road markings that prohibit overtaking. Make sure you can see that it’s safe to complete the manoeuvre before you start to overtake.

prashna.text: Why is it more difficult to overtake a large vehicle than a car?

options.description: A. It will take longer to pass one
B. It will be slow climbing hills
C. It will have air brakes
D. It will be fitted with a speed limiter

questions.explanation: Before starting the engine, make sure the motorcycle is in neutral. Do this by checking that the neutral warning light is lit when you switch on the ignition. If no neutral light is fitted, push the motorcycle forward to check that the rear wheel turns freely.

prashna.text: What safety measure should you take before starting a motorcycle engine?

options.description: A. Select first gear and apply the front brake firmly
B. Select first gear and apply the rear brake lightly
C. Check that your dipped headlights and tail light are on
D. Check that the neutral lamp shows when the ignition is switched on

questions.explanation: Look out for road signs warning of side roads, even if you aren’t turning off. A driver who's emerging may not be able to see you due to parked cars or heavy traffic. Slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary. Remember, no-one has priority at an unmarked crossroads.

prashna.text: You’re the motorcyclist approaching this junction. What should you do?

options.description: A. Stop, as the car has right of way
B. Slow down and be ready to stop
C. Speed up to clear the junction without delay
D. Dip your headlights and keep near the left-hand kerb

questions.explanation: Always ride defensively. This means looking and planning ahead, as well as anticipating the actions of other road users.

prashna.text: What can motorcyclists do to improve their safety on the road?

options.description: A. Remain well below the speed limit
B. Anticipate the actions of others
C. Keep positioned close to the kerb
D. Stay just above the speed limit

questions.explanation: To keep control of your motorcycle and prevent skidding, you should plan well ahead and avoid late, harsh braking. Try to avoid braking while changing direction, as the tyres may not have enough grip to cope with both together. Always consider how the road and weather conditions may affect your tyres’ grip.

prashna.text: What can cause skidding?

options.description: A. Braking too gently
B. Staying upright when cornering
C. Braking too hard
D. Feathering the throttle

questions.explanation: Frozen rain on the road is called black ice. It can be hard to see, but it can be indicated by a lack of road noise and your steering may also feel very light. Reduce your speed and avoid harsh braking or steering. Riding in as high a gear as possible can help reduce the risk of wheelspin.

prashna.text: It's very cold and the road looks wet. What should you do if you can't hear any road noise as you ride?

options.description: A. Brake sharply to see if the road is slippery
B. Ride in as low a gear as possible
C. Ride slowly in as high a gear as possible
D. Continue riding at the same speed

questions.explanation: Protective clothing is designed to protect you from the cold and wet. It also gives you some protection from injury, so it's important that you always wear protective clothing when you ride.

prashna.text: When should you wear full protective clothing while riding a motorcycle?

options.description: A. Just on long journeys
B. At all times
C. Only during bad weather
D. Only on faster, open roads

questions.explanation: It's best to avoid riding in foggy weather. However, if you have to, there are some precautions you can take before setting off to help make your journey as safe as possible. These include checking that all your lights are clean and working, and that your visor is clean.

prashna.text: What should you do before you start a journey in foggy conditions?

options.description: A. Make sure that you have a warm drink with you
B. Make sure that you have a spare visor with you
C. Check that your lights are working
D. Check that the battery is fully charged

questions.explanation: Parking your motorcycle on soft ground might cause the stand to sink in, and the machine could fall over. The ground should be level, as well as firm, to keep the motorcycle stable. Use off-road parking or motorcycle parking areas when they're available.

prashna.text: Where's the best place to park your motorcycle?

options.description: A. On grass
B. On bumpy ground
C. On soft tarmac
D. On firm, level ground

questions.explanation: Strong winds can blow a motorcycle off course, and even across the road. In windy conditions, you need to slow down and avoid riding on exposed roads. You should also watch for gaps in buildings and hedges, where you may be affected by a sudden gust of wind.

prashna.text: What should you do when riding in windy conditions?

options.description: A. Stay close to large vehicles
B. Stay close to the gutter
C. Keep your speed down
D. Keep your speed up

questions.explanation: When you’re riding a motorcycle, it’s very important to ride where other road users can see you. In normal weather, you should ride in the centre of your lane. This will help you avoid uneven road surfaces in the gutter, and allow others to overtake on the right if they wish.

prashna.text: On the road, what should be your normal riding position?

options.description: A. On the right of your lane
B. Near the centre of the road
C. In the centre of your lane
D. Close to the kerb

questions.explanation: When you get onto a motorcycle, you should get on from the left side to avoid putting yourself in danger from passing traffic. You should also apply the front brake to prevent the motorcycle from rolling either forwards or backwards.

prashna.text: Your motorcycle is parked on a two-way road. How should you get on the machine?

options.description: A. From the right and leave the brakes alone
B. From the right and apply the rear brake
C. From the left and leave the brakes alone
D. From the left and apply the front brake

questions.explanation: All new motorcyclists must complete a course of basic training with an approved training body before going on the road. This training is given on a site that's been authorised by the Driver and Vehicle Standards Agency as being suitable for off-road training.

prashna.text: How should you gain basic skills in motorcycle riding?

options.description: A. Practise off-road with an approved training body
B. Ride on the road on the first dry day
C. Practise off-road in a public park or in a quiet cul-de-sac
D. Ride on the road as soon as possible

questions.explanation: Riding with the clutch lever pulled in is known as coasting. If you coast, you lose the benefits of engine braking and you'll have reduced control of your motorcycle.

prashna.text: What will happen if you ride with your clutch lever pulled in for longer than is necessary?

options.description: A. It will reduce the grip of the tyres
B. It will increase wear on the gearbox
C. It will reduce your control of the motorcycle
D. It will increase petrol consumption

questions.explanation: The handling of your motorcycle will be greatly affected by the road surface. Look well ahead and be especially alert if the road looks uneven or has loose chippings. Slow down in good time, as braking harshly in these conditions will cause you to skid. For the same reason, avoid making sudden changes of direction.

prashna.text: You're approaching a road with a surface of loose chippings. What should you do?

options.description: A. Slow down
B. Ride normally
C. Stop suddenly
D. Speed up

questions.explanation: Oil and rubber can build up on the road during long spells of dry weather. When it rains, this can make the road surface very slippery.

prashna.text: It rains after a long, dry, hot spell. How can this affect the road surface?

options.description: A. It can become covered in grit
B. It can give better grip
C. It can melt and break up
D. It can become unusually slippery

questions.explanation: Skids are a lot easier to get into than they are to get out of. Riding at a suitable speed for the conditions, planning, looking ahead for hazards and braking in good time will all help you to avoid skidding or losing control.

prashna.text: What’s most likely to cause a motorcycle to skid?

options.description: A. Catching your foot on the ground
B. Riding in wet weather
C. Riding in the winter
D. Cornering too fast

questions.explanation: You should plan ahead to avoid the need to stop suddenly, but if an emergency arises, you must be able to stop safely. Applying the front brake just before the rear brake will help you to stop safely and quickly.

prashna.text: Your motorcycle doesn't have linked brakes. In an emergency, what should you do to stop quickly?

options.description: A. Apply the front brake only
B. Apply the rear brake just before the front brake
C. Apply the rear brake only
D. Apply the front brake just before the rear brake

questions.explanation: When riding, look ahead and around you. Don’t look down at the front wheel, as this can severely upset your balance.

prashna.text: What will happen if you look down at the front wheel while riding?

options.description: A. It will make your steering lighter
B. It will improve your balance
C. You'll upset your balance
D. You'll use less fuel

questions.explanation: A motorcycle is most stable when it’s upright and moving in a straight line. This is the best time to brake. With independent front and rear brakes, both brakes should be used, with the front brake being applied just before the rear brake.

prashna.text: In normal riding conditions, how should you brake?

options.description: A. When the motorcycle is upright and moving in a straight line
B. By using the rear brake first and then the front
C. When the motorcycle is being turned or ridden through a bend
D. By pulling in the clutch before using the front brake

questions.explanation: Tyres are a major factor in the handling, stability and stopping distance of a motorcycle. Make sure they’re in a safe and legal condition. The weather and road surface also play a part. Always anticipate well ahead and take account of the conditions when you’re braking.

prashna.text: Which of these will affect the stopping distance of your motorcycle?

options.description: A. The drive-chain adjustment
B. The condition of the tyres
C. The street lighting
D. The time of day

questions.explanation: Always use your headlights at night on a motorway, unless you've had to stop on the hard shoulder. If you have to use the hard shoulder, switch off your headlights but leave your parking lights on, so that your motorcycle can be seen by other road users.

prashna.text: You're on a motorway at night. In which situation may you have your headlights switched off?

options.description: A. When the motorway is lit
B. When there are vehicles close in front of you
C. When your motorcycle is broken down on the hard shoulder
D. When you're travelling below 50 mph

questions.explanation: If you have to park on the road in foggy conditions, it’s important that your motorcycle can be seen by other road users. Try to find a place to park off the road. If this isn’t possible, leave your motorcycle facing in the same direction as the traffic. Make sure that your lights are clean and leave your parking lights on.

prashna.text: You have to park on the road in fog. What should you do?

options.description: A. Leave parking lights on
B. Leave dipped headlights on
C. Leave main-beam headlights on
D. Leave no lights on

questions.explanation: Your motorcycle will be very unstable if a tyre bursts. Try to keep a straight course and stop as gently as possible.

prashna.text: You ride over broken glass and get a puncture. What should you do?

options.description: A. Release your grip on the handlebars
B. Brake to a stop as quickly as possible
C. Steer from side to side to keep your balance
D. Close the throttle and roll to a stop

questions.explanation: This rainbow-coloured pattern can be seen much more easily on a wet road. You should avoid riding over spilt fuel if possible. If you have to go over it, do so with extreme caution, knowing the surface will be slippery.

prashna.text: Spilt fuel on the road can be very dangerous for a motorcyclist. How can this hazard be seen?

options.description: A. By a pitted road surface
B. By a highly polished road surface
C. By a rainbow-coloured pattern on the road surface
D. By a series of skid marks on the road surface

questions.explanation:
When riding, it’s important to look for
*  potholes
*  drain covers (especially when they're wet)
*  tar banding
*  oily and greasy surfaces
*  road markings
*  tram tracks
*  wet mud and leaves.
Keen observation will give you more time to brake or change course if you need to avoid these slippery surfaces.

prashna.text: Which type of road surface increases the risk of skidding for motorcyclists?

options.description: A. Concrete
B. Asphalt
C. Tar banding
D. Dry tarmac

questions.explanation: On wet roads, you'll need to brake earlier and more smoothly than on dry roads. Always try to brake when the motorcycle is upright. This is particularly important in wet conditions.

prashna.text: You're riding on a wet road. What technique should you use when braking?

options.description: A. Avoid using the rear brake at all
B. Apply the front brake just before the rear brake
C. Apply the rear brake well before the front brake
D. Avoid using the front brake at all

questions.explanation: When they're wet, painted road markings can be more slippery than the normal road surface. Other road-surface hazards that become slippery when wet include drain covers, leaves and mud. Take extra care when braking or cornering on these wet surfaces.

prashna.text: The road is wet. You're passing a line of queuing traffic and riding on the painted road markings. What should you take particular care in doing?

options.description: A. Braking
B. Carrying a passenger
C. Signalling
D. Checking your mirrors

questions.explanation: The smooth steel surface can be slippery and dangerous for motorcyclists, especially when it’s wet. Try to cross tram lines at right angles.

prashna.text: Why should you be careful when crossing tram lines?

options.description: A. Pedestrians will be crossing here
B. Trams will be stopping here
C. Tram lines are always ‘live’
D. The steel rails can be slippery

questions.explanation: If you skid as a result of braking harshly, you need to ease off the brakes to stop the skid. You should then reapply them progressively to stop.

prashna.text: You have to brake sharply and your motorcycle starts to skid. What should you do?

options.description: A. Apply the brakes harder for better grip
B. Select neutral and use the front brake only
C. Continue braking and select a low gear
D. Release and reapply the brakes

questions.explanation: If fuel, especially diesel, is spilt on the road, it will make the surface very slippery. In wet weather, it can be seen as a rainbow-coloured pattern on the road.

prashna.text: You see a rainbow-coloured pattern on the road. What will this warn you of?

options.description: A. A soft, uneven road surface
B. A polished road surface
C. Water on the road
D. Fuel spilt on the road

questions.explanation: TCS helps to prevent the rear wheel from spinning, especially when accelerating on a slippery surface.

prashna.text: Traction control systems (TCS) are fitted to some motorcycles. What do they help to prevent?

options.description: A. Wheelspin when accelerating
B. Uneven rear tyre wear
C. Skidding when braking too hard
D. Uneven front tyre wear

questions.explanation: Braking too hard will cause a skid. Release the brakes immediately to allow the wheels to turn, then reapply them as firmly as the road surface and conditions will allow.

prashna.text: Braking too hard has caused both wheels to skid. What should you do?

options.description: A. Release both brakes together
B. Release the front brake only
C. Release the rear brake only
D. Release the front brake, then the rear brake

questions.explanation: In normal riding, you should always use both brakes. Braking when the motorcycle is upright and travelling in a straight line helps you to keep control. If your motorcycle has linked brakes, refer to the vehicle handbook.

prashna.text: Your motorcycle doesn't have linked brakes. What should you do when braking normally to a stop?

options.description: A. Apply either of the brakes gently
B. Apply both brakes smoothly
C. Apply only the front brake
D. Apply only the rear brake

questions.explanation: When sitting astride a stationary motorcycle, you should be able to place both feet on the ground. This should enable you to keep your balance while using one foot to operate the foot controls.

prashna.text: You're sitting on a stationary motorcycle and checking your riding position. What should you be able to do?

options.description: A. Adjust your mirrors by stretching
B. Place both feet on the ground
C. Just touch the ground with your toes
D. Operate the centre stand

questions.explanation: During a long spell of hot, dry weather, the road surface will become coated with rubber and dust. When it rains after this, the road surface will be unusually slippery. Take extra care, particularly at junctions, bends and roundabouts, and allow double the usual stopping distance.

prashna.text: It's been raining after a long dry spell. How will this affect the road surface?

options.description: A. It will be rough
B. It will be sticky
C. It will be flooded
D. It will be slippery

questions.explanation: Cornering with the side stand down could lead to a serious crash. Many motorcycles have a device that stops the engine if you try to ride off with the side stand down, but don’t rely on this.

prashna.text: Riding with the side stand down could cause you to crash. When is this most likely to happen?

options.description: A. When you're cornering
B. When you're braking
C. When you're accelerating
D. When you're going uphill

questions.explanation: You may pass slower vehicles on their left while travelling along a one-way street. Be aware of drivers who may need to change lanes and may not expect faster traffic passing on their left.

prashna.text: When may you overtake another vehicle on the left?

options.description: A. When the vehicle in front is signalling to turn left
B. When you’re in a one-way street
C. When a slower vehicle is travelling in the right-hand lane of a dual carriageway
D. When approaching a motorway slip road where you’ll be turning off

questions.explanation: The road will be very wet and spray from other vehicles will reduce your visibility. Tyre grip will also be reduced, increasing your stopping distance. You should at least double your separation distance.

prashna.text: You're travelling in very heavy rain. How is this likely to affect your overall stopping distance?

options.description: A. It will be halved
B. It will be ten times greater
C. It will be no different
D. It will be doubled

questions.explanation: Don't overtake if there’s a possibility of a road junction, bend or brow of a bridge or hill ahead. There are many hazards that are difficult to see in the dark. Only overtake if you’re certain that the road ahead is clear. Don’t take a chance.

prashna.text: What should you do when you're overtaking at night?

options.description: A. Beware of bends in the road ahead
B. Sound your horn twice before moving out
C. Put your headlights on full beam
D. Wait until a bend so that you can see oncoming headlights

questions.explanation:
The purpose of a box junction is to keep the junction clear by preventing vehicles from stopping in the path of crossing traffic.
You mustn't enter a box junction unless your exit is clear. However, you may enter the box and wait if you want to turn right and are only prevented from doing so by oncoming traffic.

prashna.text: When may you wait in a box junction?

options.description: A. When oncoming traffic prevents you turning right
B. When you're stationary in a queue of traffic
C. When approaching a zebra crossing
D. When approaching a pelican crossing

questions.explanation:
Road humps are used to slow down traffic. They're found in places where there are often pedestrians, such as
• shopping areas
• near schools
• residential areas.
Watch out for people close to the kerb or crossing the road.

prashna.text: Which of these plates normally appears with this road sign?

questions.explanation: Traffic-calming measures make the roads safer for vulnerable road users, such as cyclists, pedestrians and children. These can be designed as chicanes, road humps or other obstacles that encourage drivers and riders to slow down.

prashna.text: What do traffic-calming measures do?

options.description: A. Make parking easier
B. Make overtaking easier
C. Stop road rage
D. Slow traffic down

questions.explanation:
Be especially careful if you’re on a motorway in fog. Reflective studs are there to help you in poor visibility. Different colours are used so that you’ll know which lane you're in. These are
• red on the left-hand edge of the carriageway
• white between lanes
• amber on the right-hand edge of the carriageway
• green between the carriageway and slip roads.

prashna.text: You're on a motorway in fog. The left-hand edge of the motorway can be identified by reflective studs. What colour are they?

options.description: A. Amber
B. Green
C. White
D. Red

questions.explanation: A rumble device consists of raised markings or strips across the road, designed to give drivers an audible, visual and tactile warning. These devices are used in various locations, including in the line separating the hard shoulder and the left-hand lane on the motorway and on the approach to some hazards, to alert drivers to the need to slow down.

prashna.text: What's a rumble device designed to do?

options.description: A. Give directions
B. Prevent cattle escaping
C. Alert you to a hazard
D. Alert you to low tyre pressure

questions.explanation: If you’re planning to make a journey when it’s foggy, listen to the weather reports. If visibility is very poor, avoid making unnecessary journeys. If you do travel, leave plenty of time – and if someone is waiting for you to arrive, let them know that your journey will take longer than normal. This will also take off any pressure you may feel to rush.

prashna.text: What should you do when making a journey in foggy conditions?

options.description: A. Avoid using dipped headlights
B. Leave plenty of time for your journey
C. Follow other vehicles’ tail lights closely
D. Keep two seconds behind the vehicle ahead

questions.explanation: To prevent your lights from dazzling the driver of the car in front, wait until you’ve passed them before switching to full beam.

prashna.text: What must you do when overtaking a car at night?

options.description: A. Select a higher gear
B. Flash your headlights before overtaking
C. Switch your lights to full beam before overtaking
D. Make sure you don't dazzle other road users

questions.explanation: Be patient and stay behind the car in front. You shouldn't normally overtake other vehicles in areas subject to traffic calming. If you overtake here, you may easily exceed the speed limit, defeating the purpose of the traffic-calming measures.

prashna.text: You're travelling on a road that has speed humps. What should you do when the driver in front is travelling more slowly than you?

options.description: A. Slow down and stay behind
B. Overtake as soon as you can
C. Sound your horn
D. Flash your headlights

questions.explanation: These lines may be painted on the road on the approach to a roundabout, a village or a particular hazard. The lines are raised and painted yellow, and their purpose is to make you aware of your speed. Reduce your speed in good time so that you avoid having to brake harshly over the last few metres before reaching the junction.

prashna.text: You see these markings on the road. Why are they there?

options.description: A. To make you aware of your speed
B. To warn you to change direction
C. To show a safe distance between vehicles
D. To keep the area clear of traffic

questions.explanation: Trams may run on roads used by other vehicles and pedestrians. The section of road used by trams is known as the reserved area and should be kept clear. It usually has a different surface, edged with white lane markings.

prashna.text: How would you identify a section of road used by trams?

options.description: A. There would be a different surface texture
B. There would be yellow hatch markings around it
C. There would be zigzag markings alongside it
D. There would be metal studs around it

questions.explanation: Take care when using single-track roads. It can be difficult to see around bends, because of hedges or fences, so expect to meet oncoming vehicles. Drive carefully and be ready to pull into or stop opposite a passing place, where you can pass each other safely.

prashna.text: What should you do when you meet an oncoming vehicle on a single-track road?

options.description: A. Switch on your hazard warning lights
B. Reverse back to the main road
C. Carry out an emergency stop
D. Stop at a passing place

questions.explanation: Other drivers or riders may have to change course due to the size or characteristics of their vehicle. Understanding this will help you to anticipate their actions. Motorcyclists and cyclists will be checking the road ahead for uneven or slippery surfaces, especially in wet weather. They may need to move across their lane to avoid surface hazards such as potholes and drain covers.

prashna.text: The road is wet. Why might a motorcyclist steer round drain covers on a bend?

options.description: A. To prevent the motorcycle sliding on the metal drain covers
B. To avoid puncturing the tyres on the edge of the drain covers
C. To help judge the bend using the drain covers as marker points
D. To avoid splashing pedestrians on the pavement

questions.explanation: A ford is a crossing over a stream that’s shallow enough to drive or ride through. After you’ve gone through a ford or deep puddle, your brakes will be wet and they won't work as well as usual. To dry them out, apply a light brake pressure while moving slowly. Don’t travel at normal speeds until you're sure your brakes are working properly again.

prashna.text: After this hazard you should test your brakes. Why is this?

options.description: A. You'll be going down a long hill
B. Your brakes will be soaking wet
C. You'll be on a slippery road
D. You'll have just crossed a long bridge

questions.explanation:
You won’t be able to see as far ahead in fog as you can on a clear day. You'll need to reduce your speed so that, if a hazard looms out of the fog, you have the time and space to take avoiding action.
Travelling in fog is hazardous. If you can, try to delay your journey until it has cleared.

prashna.text: Why should you always reduce your speed when travelling in fog?

options.description: A. The engine will take longer to warm up
B. It's more difficult to see what's ahead
C. The brakes don't work as well
D. You'll be dazzled by other headlights

questions.explanation: You mustn't stop on the hard shoulder, except in an emergency. Never use the hard shoulder to have a rest or a picnic, answer a mobile phone or check a road map. Also, you mustn't travel back along the hard shoulder if you've gone past your exit.

prashna.text: When may you stop on the hard shoulder of a motorway?

options.description: A. Only in an emergency
B. If you feel tired and need to rest
C. To answer your mobile phone
D. If you've gone past your exit

questions.explanation: You’ll see the first advance direction sign one mile from a motorway exit. If you’re travelling at 60 mph, you’ll only have about 50 seconds before you reach the countdown markers. There'll be another sign at the half-mile point. Move to the left-hand lane in good time. Don’t cut across traffic at the last moment and don’t risk missing your exit.

prashna.text: You're riding on the motorway. Well before you reach your intended exit, where should you position your motorcycle?

options.description: A. On the hard shoulder
B. In the middle lane
C. In the left-hand lane
D. In any lane

questions.explanation: Give way to vehicles that are already on the motorway, and join the left-hand lane when there’s a suitable gap in the traffic. Don’t expect traffic on the motorway to give way to you, but try to avoid stopping at the end of the slip road.

prashna.text: You're joining a motorway from a slip road. What should you do?

options.description: A. Expect drivers on the motorway to give way to you
B. Ride onto the hard shoulder until a gap appears
C. Adjust your speed to the speed of the traffic on the motorway
D. Accelerate as quickly as you can and ride straight out

questions.explanation: Riders of motorcycles with an engine smaller than 50 cc aren't allowed to use motorways, due to their restricted speed. They may cause a hazard – both for the rider and for drivers of other vehicles.

prashna.text: If you want to ride on the motorway, what's the minimum engine size your motorcycle must have?

options.description: A. 125 cc
B. 150 cc
C. 250 cc
D. 50 cc

questions.explanation: Use the left-hand lane if it’s free, regardless of the speed at which you’re travelling.

prashna.text: You're riding at 70 mph on a three-lane motorway. There's no traffic ahead. Which lane should you use?

options.description: A. The right-hand lane
B. Any lane
C. The left-hand lane
D. The middle lane

questions.explanation: The national speed limit of 70 mph applies to cars and motorcycles on the motorway, unless they're towing a trailer. On smart motorways, this speed limit can be reduced and overhead signs will show the new limit in force.

prashna.text: You're riding on a motorway. Unless signs show otherwise, what's the national speed limit?

options.description: A. 80 mph
B. 50 mph
C. 70 mph
D. 60 mph

questions.explanation: Before starting a motorway journey, make sure your motorcycle can cope with the demands of high-speed riding. Things you need to check include oil, water, tyres and fuel. When you’re travelling a long way, it’s a good idea to plan rest stops in advance.

prashna.text: Why is it particularly important to carry out a check of your motorcycle before making a long motorway journey?

options.description: A. You'll have to do more harsh braking on motorways
B. Continuous high speeds increase the risk of your motorcycle breaking down
C. The road surface will wear down the tyres faster
D. Motorway service stations don't deal with breakdowns

questions.explanation: You should give way to traffic already on the motorway. Where possible, traffic may move over to let you in, but don’t force your way into the traffic stream. Traffic could be travelling at high speed, so try to match your speed to filter in without affecting the traffic flow.

prashna.text: What should you do when you're joining a motorway?

options.description: A. Use the hard shoulder
B. Give way to traffic already on the motorway
C. Stop at the end of the acceleration lane
D. Slow to a stop before joining the motorway

questions.explanation: Travelling at the national speed limit doesn’t allow you to hog the right-hand lane. Always use the left-hand lane whenever possible. When leaving a motorway, get into the left-hand lane well before your exit. Reduce your speed on the slip road and look out for sharp bends or curves and traffic queuing at roundabouts.

prashna.text: What's the national speed limit on motorways for cars and motorcycles?

options.description: A. 50 mph
B. 30 mph
C. 60 mph
D. 70 mph

questions.explanation: On a motorway, all traffic should use the left-hand lane unless overtaking. When overtaking a number of slower vehicles, move back to the left-hand lane when you’re safely past. Check your mirrors frequently and don’t stay in the middle or right-hand lane if the left-hand lane is free.

prashna.text: Which vehicles should use the left-hand lane on a three-lane motorway?

options.description: A. Emergency vehicles only
B. Any vehicle
C. Large vehicles only
D. Slow vehicles only

questions.explanation: A vehicle with a trailer is restricted to 60 mph. For this reason, it isn’t allowed in the right-hand lane, as it might hold up faster-moving traffic that wishes to overtake in that lane.

prashna.text: Which of these isn't allowed to travel in the right-hand lane of a three-lane motorway?

options.description: A. A vehicle towing a trailer
B. A small delivery van
C. A motorcycle
D. A motorcycle and sidecar

questions.explanation: On a motorway, it's best to use a roadside emergency telephone so that the emergency services are able to find you easily. The location of the nearest telephone is shown by an arrow on marker posts at the edge of the hard shoulder. If you use a mobile, the operator will need to know your exact location. Before you call, find out the number on the nearest marker post. This number will identify your exact location.

prashna.text: You break down on a motorway. You need to call for help. Why may it be better to use an emergency roadside telephone rather than a mobile phone?

options.description: A. Using a mobile phone will distract other drivers
B. It connects you to a local garage
C. Mobile phones don't work on motorways
D. It allows easy location by the emergency services

questions.explanation: Signal your intention and build up sufficient speed on the hard shoulder so that you can filter into a safe gap in the traffic. Don't push your way in, causing other traffic to alter speed or direction.

prashna.text: You've had a breakdown on the hard shoulder of a motorway. When the problem has been fixed, how should you rejoin the main carriageway?

options.description: A. Move out onto the carriageway using your hazard warning lights
B. Move out onto the carriageway, then build up your speed
C. Wait on the hard shoulder until someone flashes their headlights at you
D. Gain speed on the hard shoulder before moving out onto the carriageway

questions.explanation: Large, slow-moving vehicles can hinder the progress of other traffic. On a steep gradient, an extra crawler lane may be provided for slow-moving vehicles to allow faster-moving traffic to flow more easily.

prashna.text: You're travelling along a motorway. Where would you find a crawler or climbing lane?

options.description: A. Before a junction
B. On a steep gradient
C. Along the hard shoulder
D. Before a service area

questions.explanation: The exit from a motorway is indicated by countdown markers. These are positioned 90 metres (100 yards) apart, the first being 270 metres (300 yards) from the start of the slip road. Move into the left-hand lane well before you reach the start of the slip road.

prashna.text: What do these motorway signs show?

options.description: A. They're countdown markers to the next exit
B. They warn of a police control ahead
C. They're distance markers to the next telephone
D. They're countdown markers to a bridge

questions.explanation: On motorways, reflective studs of various colours are fixed in the road between the lanes. These help you to identify which lane you're in when it's dark or in poor visibility. Amber-coloured studs are found on the right-hand edge of the main carriageway, next to the central reservation.

prashna.text: On which part of a motorway are amber reflective studs found?

options.description: A. Between the hard shoulder and the carriageway
B. Between the acceleration lane and the carriageway
C. Between the central reservation and the carriageway
D. Between each pair of lanes

questions.explanation: White studs are found between the lanes on motorways. They reflect back the light from your headlights. This is especially useful in bad weather, when visibility is restricted.

prashna.text: What colour are the reflective studs between the lanes on a motorway?

options.description: A. Red
B. Amber
C. White
D. Green

questions.explanation: The studs between the carriageway and the hard shoulder are normally red. These change to green where there's a slip road, helping you to identify slip roads when visibility is poor or when it's dark.

prashna.text: What colour are the reflective studs between a motorway and its slip road?

options.description: A. Green
B. White
C. Red
D. Amber

questions.explanation: Along the hard shoulder there are marker posts at 100-metre intervals. These will direct you to the nearest emergency telephone.

prashna.text: You've broken down on a motorway. In which direction should you walk to find the nearest emergency telephone?

options.description: A. In the direction shown on the marker posts
B. With the traffic flow
C. Facing oncoming traffic
D. In the direction of the nearest exit

questions.explanation: Try to join the motorway without affecting the progress of the traffic already travelling on it. Always give way to traffic already on the motorway. At busy times you may have to slow down to merge into slow-moving traffic.

prashna.text: You’re joining a motorway. Why is it important to make full use of the slip road?

options.description: A. To allow you direct access to the overtaking lanes
B. Because there is space available to turn round if you need to
C. Because you can continue on the hard shoulder
D. To build up a speed similar to traffic on the motorway

questions.explanation: Traffic is passing you at speed. If the draught from a large lorry catches you by surprise, it could blow you off balance and even onto the carriageway. By facing the oncoming traffic, you can see approaching lorries and so be prepared for their draught. You'll also be in a position to see other hazards approaching.

prashna.text: How should you use the emergency telephone on a motorway?

options.description: A. Face the oncoming traffic
B. Stay close to the carriageway
C. Keep your back to the traffic
D. Stand on the hard shoulder

questions.explanation: Red studs are placed between the edge of the carriageway and the hard shoulder. Where slip roads leave or join the motorway, the studs are green.

prashna.text: You're on a motorway. What colour are the reflective studs on the left of the carriageway?

options.description: A. Green
B. White
C. Red
D. Amber

questions.explanation: On a three-lane motorway, you should travel in the left-hand lane unless you’re overtaking. This applies regardless of the speed at which you’re travelling.

prashna.text: On a three-lane motorway, which lane should you normally use?

options.description: A. Either the right or centre
B. Left
C. Centre
D. Right

questions.explanation:
At roadworks, and especially where a contraflow system is operating, a speed restriction is likely to be in place. Keep to the lower speed limit and don't
• switch lanes
• get too close to the vehicle in front of you.
Be aware that there will be no permanent barrier between you and the oncoming traffic.

prashna.text: What should you do when going through a contraflow system on a motorway?

options.description: A. Keep a good distance from the vehicle ahead
B. Use dipped beam headlights
C. Stay close to the vehicle ahead to reduce queues
D. Switch lanes to keep the traffic flowing

questions.explanation:
The colours of the reflective studs on the motorway and their locations are
• red – between the hard shoulder and the carriageway
• white – between lanes
• amber – between the carriageway and the central reservation
• green – along slip-road exits and entrances
• bright green/yellow – at roadworks and contraflow systems.

prashna.text: You're on a three-lane motorway. There are red reflective studs on your left and white ones to your right. Which lane are you in?

options.description: A. On the hard shoulder
B. In the right-hand lane
C. In the left-hand lane
D. In the middle lane

questions.explanation: Collisions often happen at roadworks. Be aware of the speed limits, slow down in good time and keep your distance from the vehicle in front.

prashna.text: You're approaching roadworks on a motorway. What should you do?

options.description: A. Obey all speed limits
B. Stay very close to the vehicle in front
C. Speed up to clear the area quickly
D. Always use the hard shoulder

questions.explanation: Motorways mustn’t be used by pedestrians, cyclists, motorcycles under 50 cc, certain slow-moving vehicles without permission, and powered wheelchairs/mobility scooters.

prashna.text: Which vehicles are prohibited from using the motorway?

options.description: A. Double-deck buses
B. Powered mobility scooters
C. Motorcycles over 50 cc
D. Cars with automatic transmission

questions.explanation: Traffic on motorways usually travels faster than on other roads. You need to be looking further ahead to give yourself more time to react to any hazard that may develop.

prashna.text: What should you do when driving or riding along a motorway?

options.description: A. Travel much faster than you would on other roads
B. Look much further ahead than you would on other roads
C. Maintain a shorter separation distance than you would on other roads
D. Concentrate more than you would on other roads

questions.explanation: Stay in the left-hand lane long enough to get used to the higher speeds of motorway traffic before considering overtaking.

prashna.text: What should you do immediately after joining a motorway?

options.description: A. Re-adjust your mirrors
B. Try to overtake
C. Keep in the left-hand lane
D. Position your vehicle in the centre lane

questions.explanation: You should keep to the left and only use the right-hand lane if you’re passing slower-moving traffic.

prashna.text: What's the right-hand lane used for on a three-lane motorway?

options.description: A. Vehicles towing trailers
B. Emergency vehicles only
C. Overtaking
D. Coaches only

questions.explanation: Don’t use the hard shoulder for stopping unless it's an emergency. If you want to stop for any other reason, go to the next exit or service station.

prashna.text: What should you use the hard shoulder of a motorway for?

options.description: A. Leaving the motorway
B. Stopping when you're tired
C. Joining the motorway
D. Stopping in an emergency

questions.explanation: You must obey these signs even if there appear to be no problems ahead. There could be queuing traffic or another hazard which you can't yet see.

prashna.text: You're in the right-hand lane of a three-lane motorway. What do these overhead signs mean?

options.description: A. Leave the motorway at the next exit
B. Move to the left and reduce your speed to 50 mph
C. There are roadworks 50 metres (55 yards) ahead
D. Use the hard shoulder until you've passed the hazard

questions.explanation: You must stop if overhead gantry signs show flashing red lights above every lane on the motorway. If any of the other lanes doesn't show flashing red lights or a red cross, you may move into that lane and continue if it's safe to do so.

prashna.text: When are you allowed to stop on a motorway?

options.description: A. When you're signalled to do so by flashing red lights
B. When you need to walk and get fresh air
C. When you wish to pick up hitchhikers
D. When you need to use a mobile telephone

questions.explanation: Plan well ahead when approaching a slip road. If you see traffic joining the motorway, move to another lane if it's safe to do so. This can help the flow of traffic joining the motorway, especially at peak times.

prashna.text: You're travelling in the left-hand lane of a three-lane motorway. How should you react to traffic joining from a slip road?

options.description: A. Maintain a steady speed
B. Race the other vehicles
C. Move to another lane
D. Switch on your hazard warning lights

questions.explanation: You should normally travel in the left-hand lane unless you're overtaking a slower-moving vehicle. When you've finished overtaking, move back into the left-hand lane, but don’t cut across in front of the vehicle that you’ve overtaken.

prashna.text: What basic rule applies when you're using a motorway?

options.description: A. Use the lane that has the least traffic
B. Try to keep above 50 mph to prevent congestion
C. Keep to the left-hand lane unless overtaking
D. Overtake on the side that’s clearest

questions.explanation: Never overtake on the left, unless the traffic is moving in queues and the queue on your right is moving more slowly than the one you’re in.

prashna.text: You're travelling along a motorway. When are you allowed to overtake on the left?

options.description: A. When you can see well ahead that the hard shoulder is clear
B. When in queues and traffic to your right is moving more slowly than you are
C. When the traffic in the right-hand lane is signalling right
D. When you warn drivers behind by signalling left

questions.explanation: Emergency refuge areas are built at the side of the hard shoulder. If you break down, try to get your vehicle into the refuge, where there's an emergency telephone. The phone connects directly to a control centre. Remember to take care when rejoining the motorway, especially if the hard shoulder is being used as a running lane.

prashna.text: On a motorway, what's an emergency refuge area used for?

options.description: A. If you think you'll be involved in a road rage incident
B. For a police patrol to park and watch traffic
C. In cases of emergency or breakdown
D. For construction and road workers to store emergency equipment

questions.explanation: Traffic officers don't have enforcement powers but are able to stop and direct people on motorways and some 'A' class roads. They operate in England and Wales and work in partnership with the police at incidents, providing a highly trained and visible service. They're recognised by an orange-and-yellow jacket and their vehicle has yellow-and-black markings.

prashna.text: Traffic officers operate on motorways and some primary routes in England and Wales. What are they authorised to do?

options.description: A. Stop and direct anyone on a motorway
B. Repair broken-down vehicles on the motorway
C. Stop and arrest drivers who break the law
D. Issue fixed penalty notices

questions.explanation: Active traffic management operates on some motorways. Within these areas, at certain times, the hard shoulder will be used as a running lane. A red cross above the hard shoulder shows that this lane should only be used for emergencies and breakdowns.

prashna.text: You're on a motorway. A red cross is displayed above the hard shoulder. What does this mean?

options.description: A. This lane can be used if you need a rest
B. You shouldn't travel in this lane
C. Use this lane as a running lane
D. Pull up in this lane to answer your mobile phone

questions.explanation: A mandatory speed-limit sign above the hard shoulder shows that this part of the road can be used as a running lane between junctions. You must stay within the speed limit. Look out for vehicles that may have broken down and could be blocking the hard shoulder.

prashna.text: You're on a smart motorway. A mandatory speed limit is displayed above the hard shoulder. What does this mean?

options.description: A. You shouldn't travel in this lane
B. You can pull up in this lane to answer a mobile phone
C. The hard shoulder can be used as a running lane
D. You can park on the hard shoulder if you feel tired

questions.explanation: Smart motorway schemes are intended to reduce congestion and make journey times more reliable. In these areas, the hard shoulder may be used as a running lane to ease congestion at peak times or in the event of an incident. Variable speed limits are used to help keep the traffic moving and to avoid bunching.

prashna.text: What's the aim of a smart motorway?

options.description: A. To reduce congestion
B. To prevent tailgating
C. To reduce rest stops
D. To prevent overtaking

questions.explanation: When a smart motorway is operating, you must follow the mandatory signs on the gantries above each lane, including the hard shoulder. Variable speed limits help keep the traffic moving and also help to prevent bunching.

prashna.text: You're using a smart motorway. What happens when it's operating?

options.description: A. Speed limits above lanes are advisory
B. The national speed limit will apply
C. The speed limit is always 30 mph
D. You must obey the speed limits shown

questions.explanation: When traffic travels at a constant speed over a longer distance, journey times normally improve. You may feel that you could travel faster for short periods, but this generally leads to bunching and increased overall journey time.

prashna.text: Why can it be an advantage for traffic speed to stay constant over a longer distance?

options.description: A. Your overall journey time will normally improve
B. You'll use far more fuel
C. You'll do more stop–start driving
D. You'll be able to use more direct routes

questions.explanation: Normally, you should only use the hard shoulder for emergencies and breakdowns, and at roadworks when signs direct you to do so. Smart motorways use active traffic management to ease congestion. In these areas, the hard shoulder may be used as a running lane when speed-limit signs are shown directly above.

prashna.text: You shouldn't normally travel on the hard shoulder of a motorway. When can you use it?

options.description: A. When signs direct you to
B. When traffic is stopped
C. When taking the next exit
D. When traffic is slow moving

questions.explanation: Congestion can be reduced by keeping traffic at a constant speed. At busy times, maximum speed limits are displayed on overhead gantries. These can be varied quickly, depending on the amount of traffic. By keeping to a constant speed on busy sections of motorway, overall journey times are normally improved.

prashna.text: What's used to reduce traffic bunching on a motorway?

options.description: A. Contraflow systems
B. Variable speed limits
C. National speed limits
D. Lane closures

questions.explanation: You shouldn't normally stop on a motorway, but there may be occasions when you need to do so. If you're unfortunate enough to break down, make every effort to pull up on the hard shoulder.

prashna.text: When may you stop on a motorway?

options.description: A. In an emergency or breakdown
B. If your mobile phone rings
C. When you're tired and need a rest
D. If you have to read a map

questions.explanation: The national speed limit for a car or motorcycle on a motorway is 70 mph. Lower speed limits may be in force; for example, at roadworks. Variable speed limits also operate in some areas when the motorway is very busy. Cars or motorcycles towing trailers are subject to a lower speed limit.

prashna.text: Unless signs show otherwise, what's the national speed limit for a car or motorcycle on a motorway?

options.description: A. 60 mph
B. 70 mph
C. 50 mph
D. 80 mph

questions.explanation: When you’re on the hard shoulder, you’re at risk of being injured by motorway traffic. The safest place to wait is away from the carriageway, but near enough to see the emergency services arriving.

prashna.text: You stop on the hard shoulder of a motorway and use the emergency telephone. Where’s the best place to wait for help to arrive?

options.description: A. On the hard shoulder
B. Next to the phone
C. With your vehicle
D. Well away from the carriageway

questions.explanation: Red flashing lights above all lanes mean you must stop and wait. You'll also see a red cross lit up. Don't change lanes, don't continue and don't pull onto the hard shoulder (unless in an emergency).

prashna.text: You're on a motorway and there are red flashing lights above every lane. What must you do?

options.description: A. Leave at the next exit
B. Stop and wait
C. Pull onto the hard shoulder
D. Slow down and watch for further signals

questions.explanation: A red cross above the hard shoulder shows that it's closed as a running lane and should only be used for emergencies or breakdowns. On a smart motorway, the hard shoulder may be used as a running lane at busy times. This will be shown by a mandatory speed limit on the gantry above the hard shoulder.

prashna.text: You're on a three-lane motorway. A red cross is showing above the hard shoulder and mandatory speed limits above all other lanes. What does this mean?

options.description: A. The hard shoulder has a speed limit of 50 mph
B. The hard shoulder can be used as a rest area if you feel tired
C. The hard shoulder can be used as a normal running lane
D. The hard shoulder is for emergency or breakdown use only

questions.explanation: You must obey mandatory speed-limit signs above motorway lanes, including the hard shoulder. In this case, you can use the hard shoulder as a running lane but you should look for any vehicles that may have broken down and may be blocking the hard shoulder.

prashna.text: On a three-lane motorway, what does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Use the three right-hand lanes only
B. Use any lane except the hard shoulder
C. Use all the lanes, including the hard shoulder
D. Use the hard shoulder only

questions.explanation: If you feel tired, stop at the nearest service area. If that's too far away, leave the motorway at the next exit and find a safe place to stop. You mustn't stop on the carriageway or hard shoulder of a motorway except in an emergency, when in a traffic queue, or when signalled to do so by a police officer, a traffic officer or traffic signals. Plan your journey so that you have regular rest stops.

prashna.text: You're travelling along a motorway and feel tired. Where should you stop to rest?

options.description: A. On a slip road
B. At the nearest service area
C. On the hard shoulder
D. On the central reservation

questions.explanation: When riding slowly, you must remember to look out for cyclists - they can travel quickly and fit through surprisingly narrow spaces. Before you turn left in slow-moving traffic, it’s important to check that a cyclist isn’t trying to filter past on your left.

prashna.text: You're riding slowly in a town centre. Why should you glance over your left shoulder before turning left?

options.description: A. To check for potholes
B. To look for traffic signs
C. To help keep your balance
D. To check for cyclists

questions.explanation: Always plan ahead and be aware of lanes and areas designated for specific road users only. The restrictions are sometimes in force only at certain times of day, and signs will show when they apply. In some towns, motorcycles are permitted to use bus lanes – check the signs carefully.

prashna.text: Which lane mustn't you use when you’re riding your motorcycle?

options.description: A. Crawler lane
B. Acceleration lane
C. Overtaking lane
D. Tram lane

questions.explanation: In some towns and cities there are special areas reserved for parking motorcycles. Look out for these signs.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Parking for solo motorcycles
B. Police motorcycles only
C. Passing place for motorcycles
D. No parking for solo motorcycles

questions.explanation: Before changing direction, as well as using your mirrors, you may need to take a quick sideways glance to check for vehicles in your blind spots. These are the areas behind and to the side of you that aren't covered by your mirrors.

prashna.text: You're riding on a busy dual carriageway. What should you do before you change lanes?

options.description: A. Use mirrors and shoulder checks
B. Rely totally on your mirrors
C. Always increase your speed
D. Signal so that others will give way

questions.explanation: It's illegal to park in a space reserved for disabled users unless you're permitted to do so. These spaces are provided for people with limited mobility, who may need extra space to get into and out of their vehicle.

prashna.text: You're looking for somewhere to park your motorcycle. The area is full except for spaces marked ‘disabled use’. What can you do?

options.description: A. You can use one of the spaces as long as one is kept free
B. You can't park there, unless you're permitted to do so
C. You can use these spaces when elsewhere is full
D. You can park in one of these spaces if you stay with your motorcycle

questions.explanation: If you meet another vehicle on a narrow road and the passing place is on your left, pull into it. If the passing place is on your right, wait opposite it.

prashna.text: You're on a road with passing places. It's only wide enough for one vehicle. A car is coming towards you. What should you do?

options.description: A. Pull into a passing place on your right
B. Pull into a passing place on your left
C. Turn round and ride back to the main road
D. Force the other driver to reverse

questions.explanation: When turning right at this crossroads, you should keep the oncoming car to your right. This will give you a clear view of the road ahead and any oncoming traffic.

prashna.text: You're both turning right at this crossroads. Why is it safer to keep the car to your right?

options.description: A. So you can keep close to the kerb
B. So you can make oncoming vehicles stop
C. So you can keep clear of following traffic
D. So you can see approaching traffic

questions.explanation: Other road users may not expect or look for motorcycles filtering through slow-moving or stationary traffic. Your view will be reduced by the vehicles around you. Watch out for pedestrians walking between the vehicles, vehicles suddenly changing direction and vehicles turning into or out of side roads.

prashna.text: What should you do when filtering through slow-moving or stationary traffic?

options.description: A. Continually use your horn as a warning
B. Ride with your hazard warning lights on
C. Watch for vehicles emerging from side roads
D. Stand up on the footrests for a good view ahead

questions.explanation: You must obey all traffic signs and signals. Just because the lights are temporary, it doesn't mean that you can disregard them.

prashna.text: You're riding towards roadworks. The temporary traffic lights are on red. The road ahead is clear. What should you do?

options.description: A. Carry on if approaching cars have stopped
B. Ride on with extreme caution
C. Wait for the green light
D. Ride on at normal speed

questions.explanation: When abroad and riding on the right, deflectors are usually required to prevent your headlights from dazzling approaching drivers.

prashna.text: You intend to go abroad and will be riding on the right-hand side of the road. What should you fit to your motorcycle?

options.description: A. Twin headlights
B. Headlight deflectors
C. Tinted yellow brake lights
D. Tinted red indicator lenses

questions.explanation: Towing a trailer requires special care. You must obey the restrictions that apply when towing - including the 125 cc minimum size of your motorcycle engine and the reduced national speed limits. Don't forget the trailer is there, especially when negotiating bends and junctions.

prashna.text: You want to tow a trailer with your motorcycle. What's the minimum engine size required to do this?

options.description: A. 50 cc
B. 525 cc
C. 125 cc

questions.explanation: You don’t have to ride at the speed limit. Use your own judgement and ride at a speed that suits the prevailing road, weather and traffic conditions.

prashna.text: What's the national speed limit on a single carriageway?

options.description: A. 50 mph
B. 70 mph
C. 60 mph
D. 40 mph

questions.explanation:
Don’t stop or hold up traffic unnecessarily. However, there are occasions when you must stop by law. These include
*  when signalled to do so by a school crossing patrol, police officer or traffic officer
*  at a red traffic light
*  at a junction with a ‘stop’ sign.

prashna.text: When must you stop your motorcycle?

options.description: A. At an empty zebra crossing
B. At a junction with double broken white lines
C. At a clear pelican crossing when the amber light is flashing
D. When signalled to do so by a police officer

questions.explanation: This sign doesn’t tell you the speed limit in figures. You should know the speed limit for the type of road that you’re on and the type of vehicle that you're driving. Study your copy of The Highway Code.

prashna.text: What's the meaning of this sign?

options.description: A. No entry for vehicles
B. National speed limit applies
C. No waiting on the carriageway
D. Local speed limit applies

questions.explanation: Make sure that you know the speed limit for the road that you’re on. The speed limit on a dual carriageway or motorway is 70 mph for cars and motorcycles, unless signs indicate otherwise. The speed limits for different types of vehicle are listed in The Highway Code.

prashna.text: What's the national speed limit for cars and motorcycles on a dual carriageway?

options.description: A. 30 mph
B. 50 mph
C. 60 mph
D. 70 mph

questions.explanation: There's a 30 mph speed limit where there are street lights unless signs show another limit.

prashna.text: There are no speed-limit signs on the road. How is a 30 mph limit indicated?

options.description: A. By double or single yellow lines
B. By street lighting
C. By pedestrian islands
D. By hazard warning lines

questions.explanation: The presence of street lights generally indicates that there's a 30 mph speed limit, unless signs tell you otherwise.

prashna.text: You see street lights but no speed-limit signs. What will the speed limit usually be?

options.description: A. 40 mph
B. 50 mph
C. 30 mph
D. 60 mph

questions.explanation: The red slash through the sign indicates that the restriction has ended. In this case, the restriction was a minimum speed limit of 30 mph.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Minimum speed 30 mph
B. End of minimum speed
C. End of maximum speed
D. Maximum speed 30 mph

questions.explanation: Following a tractor can be frustrating, but never overtake if you’re unsure whether it’s safe. Ask yourself: 'Can I see far enough down the road to ensure that I can complete the manoeuvre safely?' It's better to be delayed for a minute or two than to take a chance that may cause a collision.

prashna.text: There's a tractor ahead. You want to overtake but you aren't sure whether it's safe. What should you do?

options.description: A. Sound your horn to make the tractor pull over
B. Stay behind the tractor if you're in any doubt
C. Speed past, flashing your lights at oncoming traffic
D. Follow another vehicle as it overtakes the tractor

questions.explanation: Long vehicles might have to take a slightly different position when approaching the roundabout or going around it. This is to stop the rear of the vehicle cutting in and mounting the kerb.

prashna.text: Which vehicle is most likely to take an unusual course at a roundabout?

options.description: A. Long lorry
B. Estate car
C. Milk float
D. Delivery van

questions.explanation: Clearways are in place so that traffic can flow without the obstruction of parked vehicles. Just one parked vehicle can cause an obstruction for all other traffic. You mustn't stop where a clearway is in force, not even to pick up or set down passengers.

prashna.text: When mustn't you stop on a clearway?

options.description: A. During daylight hours
B. When it's busy
C. At any time
D. In the rush hour

questions.explanation:
This sign indicates that there are waiting restrictions. It's normally accompanied by details of when the restrictions are in force.
Details of most signs in common use are shown in The Highway Code. For more comprehensive coverage, see Know Your Traffic Signs.

prashna.text: What's the meaning of this sign?

options.description: A. National speed limit
B. School crossing patrol
C. No entry
D. Waiting restrictions

questions.explanation: Red rear reflectors show up when headlights shine on them. These are useful when you're parked at night, but they'll only reflect if you park in the same direction as the traffic flow. Normally you should park on the left, but in a one-way street you may also park on the right-hand side.

prashna.text: When can you park on the right-hand side of a road at night?

options.description: A. When you have your sidelights on
B. When you're in a one-way street
C. When you're more than 10 metres (32 feet) from a junction
D. When you're under a lamppost

questions.explanation:
You should normally use the left-hand lane on any dual carriageway unless you're overtaking or turning right.
When overtaking on a dual carriageway, look for vehicles ahead that are turning right. They may be slowing or stopped. You need to see them in good time so that you can take appropriate action.

prashna.text: On a three-lane dual carriageway, what can the right-hand lane be used for?

options.description: A. Fast-moving traffic only
B. Overtaking only, never turning right
C. Overtaking or turning right
D. Turning right only, never overtaking

questions.explanation: There are times when road markings are obscured by queuing traffic, or you're unsure which lane to use. If, at the last moment, you find you're in the wrong lane, don’t cut across or bully other drivers to let you in. Follow the lane you’re in and find somewhere safe to turn around and rejoin your route.

prashna.text: You're approaching a busy junction. What should you do when, at the last moment, you realise you're in the wrong lane?

options.description: A. Force your way across
B. Use clear arm signals to cut across
C. Continue in that lane
D. Stop until the area has cleared

questions.explanation: You can overtake other traffic on either side when travelling in a one-way street. Make full use of your mirrors and ensure it’s clear all around before you attempt to overtake. Look for signs and road markings, and use the most suitable lane for your destination.

prashna.text: Where may you overtake on a one-way street?

options.description: A. On either the right or the left
B. Only on the right-hand side
C. Only on the left-hand side
D. Overtaking isn't allowed

questions.explanation: When going straight ahead at a roundabout, don’t signal as you approach it. Indicate left just after passing the exit before the one you wish to take.

prashna.text: How should you signal when going straight ahead at a roundabout?

options.description: A. Indicate right when approaching the roundabout
B. Don't indicate at any time
C. Indicate left before leaving the roundabout
D. Indicate left when approaching the roundabout

questions.explanation:
A long vehicle may have to straddle lanes either on or approaching a roundabout so that the rear wheels don’t hit the kerb.
If you’re following a long vehicle, stay well back and give it plenty of room.

prashna.text: Which vehicle might have to take a different course from normal at roundabouts?

options.description: A. Sports car
B. Estate car
C. Van
D. Long vehicle

questions.explanation: Yellow box junctions are marked on the road to prevent the road becoming blocked. Don’t enter the box unless your exit road is clear. You may wait in the box if you want to turn right and your exit road is clear but oncoming traffic or other vehicles waiting to turn right are preventing you from making the turn.

prashna.text: On which occasion may you enter a box junction?

options.description: A. When there are fewer than two vehicles ahead
B. When traffic signs direct you
C. When signalled by another road user
D. When your exit road is clear

questions.explanation: The purpose of yellow box markings is to keep junctions clear of queuing traffic. You may only wait in the marked area when you’re turning right and your exit lane is clear but you can’t complete the turn because of oncoming traffic or other traffic waiting to turning right.

prashna.text: When may you stop and wait in a box junction?

options.description: A. When you're in a queue of traffic turning left
B. When you're in a queue of traffic going ahead
C. When you're on a roundabout
D. When oncoming traffic prevents you from turning right

questions.explanation: You must obey signals to stop given by police and traffic officers, traffic wardens and school crossing patrols. Failure to do so is an offence and could lead to prosecution.

prashna.text: Which person's signal to stop must you obey?

options.description: A. A motorcyclist
B. A pedestrian
C. A bus driver
D. A police officer

questions.explanation: By standing on the pavement, the pedestrian is showing an intention to cross. By looking well ahead, you'll give yourself time to see the pedestrian, check your mirrors and respond safely.

prashna.text: You see a pedestrian waiting at a zebra crossing. What should you normally do?

options.description: A. Stop before you reach the zigzag lines and let them cross
B. Go on quickly before they step onto the crossing
C. Stop to let them cross and wait patiently
D. Ignore them as they're still on the pavement

questions.explanation: Toucan crossings are similar to pelican crossings but there's no flashing amber phase. Cyclists share the crossing with pedestrians and are allowed to cycle across when the green cycle symbol is shown.

prashna.text: Who can use a toucan crossing?

options.description: A. Buses and lorries
B. Cars and motorcycles
C. Cyclists and pedestrians
D. Trams and trains

questions.explanation: This light allows pedestrians already on the crossing to get to the other side in their own time, without being rushed. Don’t rev your engine or start to move off while they’re still crossing.

prashna.text: You’re waiting at a pelican crossing. What does it mean when the red light changes to flashing amber?

options.description: A. Get ready and go when the continuous amber light shows
B. Wait for pedestrians on the crossing to clear
C. Wait for the green light before moving off
D. Move off immediately without any hesitation

questions.explanation: You mustn't park or stop on a road marked with double white lines (even where one of the lines is broken) except to pick up or set down passengers.

prashna.text: When can you park on the left opposite these road markings?

options.description: A. When there are no yellow lines
B. During daylight hours only
C. If the line nearest to you is broken
D. To pick up or set down passengers

questions.explanation: When turning right at a crossroads where oncoming traffic is also turning right, it’s generally safer to turn behind the approaching vehicle. This allows you a clear view of approaching traffic and is called ‘turning offside to offside’. However, some junctions, usually controlled by traffic-light filters - are marked for vehicles to turn nearside to nearside.

prashna.text: You're turning right at a crossroads. An oncoming driver is also turning right. What's the advantage of turning behind the oncoming vehicle?

options.description: A. You'll use less fuel because you can stay in a higher gear
B. You'll have a clearer view of any approaching traffic
C. You'll have more time to turn
D. You'll be able to turn without stopping

questions.explanation:
Travel slowly and carefully near parked vehicles. Beware of
• vehicles pulling out, especially bicycles and motorcycles
• pedestrians, especially children, who may run out from between cars
• drivers opening their doors.

prashna.text: You're travelling along a street with parked vehicles on the left-hand side. Why should you keep your speed down?

options.description: A. There may be delivery lorries on the street
B. So that oncoming traffic can see you more clearly
C. Children may run out from between the vehicles
D. You may set off car alarms

questions.explanation: Take care if you have to pass a parked vehicle on your side of the road. Give way to oncoming traffic if there isn’t enough room for you both to continue safely.

prashna.text: What should you do when you meet an obstruction on your side of the road?

options.description: A. Carry on, as you have priority
B. Accelerate to get past first
C. Give way to oncoming traffic
D. Wave oncoming vehicles through

questions.explanation: Normally you should travel in the left-hand lane and only use the right-hand lane for overtaking or turning right. Move back into the left lane as soon as it’s safe but don’t cut in across the path of the vehicle you’ve just passed.

prashna.text: You're on a two-lane dual carriageway. Why would you use the right-hand lane?

options.description: A. For normal progress
B. When staying at the minimum allowed speed
C. To overtake slower traffic
D. To keep driving at a constant high speed

questions.explanation: Practise good observation in all directions before you emerge or make a turn. Proceed only when you’re sure it’s safe to do so.

prashna.text: Who has priority at an unmarked crossroads?

options.description: A. No-one has priority
B. The larger vehicle
C. The faster vehicle
D. The smaller vehicle

questions.explanation: Don’t park within 10 metres (32 feet) of a junction (unless in an authorised parking place). This is to allow drivers emerging from, or turning into, the junction a clear view of the road they're joining. It also allows them to see hazards such as pedestrians or cyclists at the junction.

prashna.text: What's the nearest you may park to a junction?

options.description: A. 20 metres (66 feet)
B. 10 metres (32 feet)
C. 15 metres (49 feet)
D. 12 metres (39 feet)

questions.explanation: It may be tempting to park where you shouldn’t while you run a quick errand. Careless parking is a selfish act and could endanger other road users. It’s important not to park at or near a bus stop, as this could inconvenience passengers and may put them at risk as they get on or off the bus.

prashna.text: Where shouldn't you park?

options.description: A. At or near a bus stop
B. On a road with a 40 mph speed limit
C. Within 20 metres (65 feet) of a junction
D. Where there's no pavement

questions.explanation: If the lights at a level crossing keep flashing after a train has passed, you should continue to wait, because another train might be coming. Time seems to pass slowly when you’re held up in a queue. Be patient and wait until the lights stop flashing.

prashna.text: You're waiting at a level crossing. A train passes but the lights keep flashing. What must you do?

options.description: A. Park and investigate
B. Phone the signal operator
C. Carry on waiting
D. Edge over the stop line and look for trains

questions.explanation: The blue-and-red circular sign on its own means that waiting restrictions are in force. This sign shows that you're leaving the controlled zone and waiting restrictions no longer apply.

prashna.text: What does this sign tell you?

options.description: A. End of traffic-calming zone
B. Free-parking zone ends
C. No-waiting zone ends
D. No through road

questions.explanation: Where there are extra hazards, such as at roadworks, it’s often necessary to slow traffic down by imposing a lower speed limit. These speed limits aren’t advisory; they must be obeyed.

prashna.text: What must you do when entering roadworks where a temporary speed limit is displayed?

options.description: A. Obey the speed limit
B. Obey the limit, but only during rush hour
C. Use your own judgment; the limit is only advisory
D. Ignore the displayed limit

questions.explanation: You may be difficult to see when you’re travelling at night, even on a well-lit road. If you use dipped headlights rather than sidelights, other road users should be able to see you more easily.

prashna.text: You're on a well-lit road at night, in a built-up area. How will using dipped headlights help?

options.description: A. You can switch to main beam quickly
B. You can be easily seen by others
C. You can see further along the road
D. You can go at a much faster speed

questions.explanation: When the central reservation is narrow, you should treat a dual carriageway as one road. Wait until the road is clear in both directions before emerging to turn right. If you try to treat it as two separate roads and wait in the middle, you're likely to cause an obstruction and possibly a collision.

prashna.text: The dual carriageway you're turning right onto has a very narrow central reservation. What should you do?

options.description: A. Stop in the first lane so that other vehicles give way
B. Proceed to the central reservation and wait
C. Emerge slightly to show your intentions
D. Wait until the road is clear in both directions

questions.explanation: Exceeding the speed limit is dangerous and can result in you receiving penalty points on your licence. It isn’t worth it. You should know the speed limit for the road that you’re on by observing the road signs. Different speed limits apply if you're towing a trailer.

prashna.text: What's the national speed limit on a single carriageway road for cars and motorcycles?

options.description: A. 30 mph
B. 70 mph
C. 50 mph
D. 60 mph

questions.explanation: You must use parking lights when parking at night on a road or in a lay-by on a road with a speed limit greater than 30 mph. You must also park in the direction of the traffic flow and not close to a junction.

prashna.text: You park at night on a road with a 40 mph speed limit. What should you do?

options.description: A. Park with dipped headlights on
B. Park near a street light
C. Park facing the traffic
D. Park with parking lights on

questions.explanation: If there's a bend just before a level crossing, you may not be able to see the level-crossing barriers or waiting traffic. These signs give you an early warning that you may find these hazards just around the bend.

prashna.text: Where will you see these red and white markers?

options.description: A. Approaching the end of a dual carriageway
B. Approaching a concealed speed-limit sign
C. Approaching the end of a motorway
D. Approaching a concealed level crossing

questions.explanation: You'll find traffic officers on motorways in England and Wales as well as some primary routes. They work in partnership with the police, helping to keep traffic moving and helping to make your journey as safe as possible. It's an offence not to comply with the directions given by a traffic officer.

prashna.text: You're travelling on a motorway in England. You must stop when signalled to do so by which of these?

options.description: A. A traffic officer
B. A driver who has broken down
C. Pedestrians on the hard shoulder
D. Flashing amber lights above your lane

questions.explanation: To go straight ahead at a roundabout, you should normally approach in the left-hand lane, but check the road markings.
