At some roundabouts, the left lane on approach is marked ‘left turn only’, so make sure you use the correct lane to go ahead. You won't normally need to signal as you approach, but signal before you leave the roundabout, as other road users need to know your intentions.

prashna.text: You're going straight ahead at a roundabout. How should you signal?

options.description: A. Signal right on the approach to the roundabout and keep the signal on
B. Signal right on the approach and then left to leave the roundabout
C. Signal left after you leave the roundabout and enter the new road
D. Signal left just after you pass the exit before the one you're going to take

questions.explanation: Arm signals can be effective during daylight, especially when you’re wearing bright clothing. Practise giving arm signals when you’re learning. You need to be able to keep full control of your motorcycle with one hand off the handlebars.

prashna.text: How should you give an arm signal to turn left?

questions.explanation: Consider giving an arm signal if it will help other road users; for example, in bright sunshine, when your indicators may be difficult to see. Don’t maintain an arm signal when turning, but return your hand to the handlebars to help you steer through the turn.

prashna.text: You're giving an arm signal, ready to turn left. Why shouldn't you continue with the arm signal while you turn?

options.description: A. Because you'll need to keep the clutch applied
B. Because you might hit a pedestrian on the corner
C. Because other motorists will think that you're stopping on the corner
D. Because you'll have less steering control

questions.explanation: Strong side winds can suddenly blow you off course. Keep your speed down when it’s very windy, especially on exposed roads.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Service area
B. Side winds
C. Slippery road
D. Airport

questions.explanation: Most regulatory signs are circular. A red circle tells you what you mustn't do.

prashna.text: Which of these signs are you allowed to ride past on a solo motorcycle?

questions.explanation: Arm signals can be given to reinforce your flashing indicators, especially if the indicator signal could cause confusion; for example, if you intend to pull up close to a side road.

prashna.text: Which of these signals should you give when slowing or stopping your motorcycle?

questions.explanation: Always check that you've cancelled your indicators after turning. Failing to cancel your indicators could lead to a serious or even fatal collision. Other road users might pull out in front of you if they think you're going to turn off before you reach them.

prashna.text: Why should you make sure that you cancel your indicators after turning?

options.description: A. To avoid flattening the battery
B. To avoid misleading other road users
C. To avoid damage to the indicator relay
D. To avoid dazzling other road users

questions.explanation: Arm signals should be used to confirm your intentions when you aren’t sure that your indicators can be seen by other road users. Use the signals shown in The Highway Code and return your hand to the handlebars before you turn.

prashna.text: Your indicators are difficult to see due to bright sunshine. What should you do to let other road users know your intentions?

options.description: A. Sound your horn
B. Keep both hands on the handlebars
C. Flash your headlights
D. Give an arm signal

questions.explanation: If this vehicle is in your lane, you'll have to move to the left. Use your mirrors and signal if necessary. When it’s safe, move into the lane on your left. You should always look well ahead so that you can spot such hazards early, giving yourself time to react safely.

prashna.text: You're riding on a motorway. There's a slow-moving vehicle ahead. On the back, you see this sign. What should you do?

options.description: A. Leave at the next exit
B. Pass on the left
C. Pass on the right
D. Drive no further

questions.explanation: There are three basic types of traffic sign: those that warn, those that inform and those that give orders. Generally, triangular signs warn, rectangular signs give information or directions and circular signs give orders. An exception is the eight-sided ‘stop’ sign.

prashna.text: How can you identify traffic signs that give orders?

options.description: A. They're rectangular with a yellow border
B. They're circular with a red border
C. They're triangular with a blue border
D. They're square with a brown border

questions.explanation: Road signs in the shape of a circle give orders. Those with a red circle are mostly prohibitive. The ‘stop’ sign is octagonal to give it greater prominence. Signs giving orders must always be obeyed.

prashna.text: Traffic signs giving orders are generally which shape?

questions.explanation: Signs in the shape of a circle give orders. A sign with a red circle means that you aren’t allowed to do something. Study Know Your Traffic Signs to ensure that you understand what the different traffic signs mean.

prashna.text: Which type of sign tells you not to do something?

questions.explanation:
If you’re in a place where there are likely to be pedestrians (for example, outside a school, near a park, in a residential area or in a shopping area), you should be cautious and keep your speed down.
Many local authorities have taken steps to slow traffic down by creating traffic-calming measures such as speed humps. They're there for a reason; slow down.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Only 20 cars allowed at any one time
B. Minimum speed limit with traffic calming
C. Maximum speed limit with traffic calming
D. ‘20 cars only’ parking zone

questions.explanation: You'll generally see this sign at the approach to a pedestrian-only zone.

prashna.text: Which sign means no motor vehicles are allowed?

questions.explanation: Where you see this sign, the 20 mph restriction ends. Check all around for possible hazards and only increase your speed if it’s safe to do so.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. New speed limit 20 mph
B. End of 20 mph zone
C. Minimum speed limit 30 mph
D. No vehicles over 30 tonnes

questions.explanation: A sign will indicate which types of vehicles are prohibited from certain roads. Make sure that you know which signs apply to the vehicle you’re using.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. No overtaking
B. Cars and motorcycles only
C. No motor vehicles
D. Clearway (no stopping)

questions.explanation: ‘No entry’ signs are used in places such as one-way streets to prevent vehicles driving against the traffic. To ignore one would be dangerous, both for yourself and for other road users, as well as being against the law.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. No entry
B. No parking
C. No through road
D. No road markings

questions.explanation: The ‘no right turn’ sign may be used to warn road users that there's a ‘no entry’ prohibition on a road to the right ahead.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Road on the right closed
B. No traffic from the right
C. Bend to the right
D. No right turn

questions.explanation: Look for and obey traffic signs. Disobeying or not seeing a sign could be dangerous. It may also be an offence for which you could be prosecuted.

prashna.text: Which sign means ‘no entry’?

questions.explanation: Avoid blocking tram routes. Trams are fixed on their route and can’t manoeuvre around other vehicles or pedestrians. Modern trams travel quickly and are quiet, so you might not hear them approaching.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Parking for buses only
B. Route for buses only
C. Parking for trams only
D. Route for trams only

questions.explanation: The triangular shapes above and below the dimensions indicate a height restriction that applies to the road ahead.

prashna.text: Which type of vehicle does this sign apply to?

options.description: A. Wide vehicles
B. Long vehicles
C. High vehicles
D. Heavy vehicles

questions.explanation: This sign is used to enable pedestrians to walk free from traffic. It’s often found in shopping areas.

prashna.text: Which sign means no motor vehicles allowed?

questions.explanation: Road signs that prohibit overtaking are placed in locations where passing the vehicle in front is dangerous. If you see this sign, don’t attempt to overtake. The sign is there for a reason; you must obey it.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. No motor vehicles
B. You have priority
C. No overtaking
D. Two-way traffic

questions.explanation: There'll be a plate or additional sign to tell you when the restrictions apply.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Waiting restrictions apply
B. Clearway (no stopping)
C. National speed limit applies
D. Waiting permitted

questions.explanation: Even though you've left the restricted area, make sure that you park where you won’t endanger other road users or cause an obstruction.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. End of clearway
B. End of cycle route
C. End of restricted parking area
D. End of restricted speed area

questions.explanation: Stopping where this clearway restriction applies is likely to cause congestion. Allow the traffic to flow by obeying the signs.

prashna.text: Which sign means ‘no stopping’?

questions.explanation: Clearways are stretches of road where you aren’t allowed to stop unless it’s an emergency. Stopping where these restrictions apply may be dangerous and is likely to cause an obstruction. Restrictions might apply for several miles and this may be indicated on the sign.

prashna.text: You see this sign ahead. What does it mean?

options.description: A. No entry
B. National speed limit applies
C. No stopping
D. Waiting restrictions apply

questions.explanation: If you intend to stop and rest, this sign allows you time to reduce speed and pull over safely.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Distance to public house ahead
B. Distance to public telephone ahead
C. Distance to parking place ahead
D. Distance to passing place ahead

questions.explanation: In order to keep roads free from parked cars, there are some areas where you’re allowed to park on the verge. Only do this where you see the sign. Parking on verges or footways anywhere else could lead to a fine.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Vehicles may not park on the verge or footway
B. Vehicles may park fully on the verge or footway
C. Vehicles may park on the right-hand side of the road only
D. Vehicles may park on the left-hand side of the road only

questions.explanation:
Priority signs are normally shown where the road is narrow and there isn’t enough room for two vehicles to pass. Examples are narrow bridges, roadworks and where there’s a width restriction.
Make sure you know who has priority; don’t force your way through. Show courtesy and consideration to other road users.

prashna.text: What does this traffic sign mean?

options.description: A. Two-way traffic
B. One-way traffic only
C. Give priority to oncoming traffic
D. No overtaking allowed

questions.explanation: Don’t force your way through. Show courtesy and consideration to other road users. Although you have priority, make sure oncoming traffic is going to give way before you continue.

prashna.text: What's the meaning of this traffic sign?

options.description: A. You have priority over vehicles coming towards you
B. Give priority to vehicles coming towards you
C. Bus lane ahead
D. End of two-way road

questions.explanation: To make it easy to recognise, the ‘stop’ sign is the only sign of this shape. You must stop and take effective observation before proceeding.

prashna.text: What shape is a 'stop' sign at a junction?

questions.explanation: The 'stop' sign is the only road sign that's octagonal. This is so that it can be recognised and obeyed even if it's obscured (for example, by snow).

prashna.text: At a junction, you see this sign partly covered by snow. What does it mean?

options.description: A. Give way
B. Crossroads
C. Turn right
D. Stop

questions.explanation: This sign is shown where slow-moving vehicles would impede the flow of traffic; for example, in tunnels. However, if you need to slow down or even stop to avoid an incident or potential collision, you should do so.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Lay-by 30 miles ahead
B. Minimum speed 30 mph
C. Service area 30 miles ahead
D. Maximum speed 30 mph

questions.explanation: These signs are often seen in one-way streets that have more than one lane. When you see this sign, use the route that’s the most convenient and doesn’t require a late change of direction.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Give way to oncoming vehicles
B. Turn off at the next available junction
C. Approaching traffic passes you on both sides
D. Pass either side to get to the same destination

questions.explanation: Take extra care when you encounter trams. Look out for road markings and signs that alert you to them. Modern trams are very quiet and you may not hear them approaching.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Route for buses
B. Give way to trams
C. Give way to buses
D. Route for trams

questions.explanation: Signs with blue circles mostly give a positive instruction. These are often found in urban areas and include signs for mini-roundabouts and directional arrows.

prashna.text: What does a circular traffic sign with a blue background do?

options.description: A. Give an instruction
B. Give directions to a car park
C. Give motorway information
D. Give warning of a motorway ahead

questions.explanation: The traffic permitted to use a contraflow lane travels in the opposite direction to traffic in the other lanes on the road.

prashna.text: Where would you see a contraflow bus and cycle lane?

options.description: A. On a dual carriageway
B. On a roundabout
C. On an urban motorway
D. On a one-way street

questions.explanation: There will also be markings on the road surface to indicate the bus lane. You mustn't use this lane for parking or overtaking.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. With-flow bus lane
B. Bus station on the right
C. Give way to buses
D. Contraflow bus lane

questions.explanation: Signs with a brown background give directions to places of interest. They're often seen on a motorway, directing you along the easiest route to the attraction.

prashna.text: What does a sign with a brown background show?

options.description: A. Motorway routes
B. Primary roads
C. Tourist directions
D. Minor roads

questions.explanation: These signs indicate places of interest and are designed to guide you by the easiest route. They're particularly useful when you're unfamiliar with the area.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Beware of trams
B. Level crossing
C. Beware of trains
D. Tourist attraction

questions.explanation: This type of sign warns you of hazards ahead. Make sure you look at each sign that you pass on the road, so that you don't miss any vital instructions or information.

prashna.text: What are triangular signs for?

options.description: A. To give warnings
B. To give information
C. To give orders
D. To give directions

questions.explanation: This type of sign warns you of hazards ahead. Make sure you look at each sign and road marking that you pass, so that you don't miss any vital instructions or information. This particular sign shows there's a T-junction with priority over vehicles from the right.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Turn left ahead
B. T-junction
C. No through road
D. Give way

questions.explanation: It will take up to ten times longer to stop when it’s icy. Where there's a risk of icy conditions, you need to be aware of this and take extra care. If you think the road may be icy, don’t brake or steer harshly, as your tyres could lose their grip on the road.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Risk of ice
B. Six roads converge
C. Multi-exit roundabout
D. Place of historical interest

questions.explanation: The priority through the junction is shown by the broader line. You need to be aware of the hazard posed by traffic crossing or pulling out onto a major road.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Level crossing without gate
B. Ahead only
C. Crossroads
D. Level crossing with gate

questions.explanation: As you approach a roundabout, look well ahead and check all signs. Decide which exit you wish to take and move into the correct position as you approach the roundabout, signalling as required.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Mini-roundabout
B. Ring road
C. Roundabout
D. No vehicles

questions.explanation: Warning signs are there to make you aware of potential hazards on the road ahead. Take note of the signs so you're prepared and can take whatever action is necessary.

prashna.text: What information would be shown in a triangular road sign?

options.description: A. Keep left
B. Minimum speed
C. Ahead only
D. Road narrows

questions.explanation: Where there’s a cycle route ahead, a sign will show a bicycle in a red warning triangle. Watch out for children on bicycles and cyclists rejoining the main road.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Cycles aren't allowed
B. Cyclists must dismount
C. Cycle in single file
D. Cycle route ahead

questions.explanation: When you pass pedestrians in the road, leave plenty of room. You might have to use the right-hand side of the road, so look well ahead, as well as in your mirrors, before pulling out. Take great care if a bend in the road obscures your view ahead.

prashna.text: Which sign means that pedestrians may be walking along the road?

questions.explanation: Triangular signs give you a warning of hazards ahead. They're there to give you time to prepare for the hazard; for example, by adjusting your speed.

prashna.text: Which of these signs means there's a double bend ahead?

questions.explanation: Obey the ‘give way’ signs. Trams are unable to steer around you if you misjudge when it's safe to enter the junction.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Wait at the barriers
B. Give way to farm vehicles
C. Wait at the crossroads
D. Give way to trams

questions.explanation: These humps have been put in place to slow the traffic down. They’re usually found in residential areas. Slow down to an appropriate speed.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Hump bridge
B. Soft verges
C. Entrance to tunnel
D. Humps in the road

questions.explanation: If you’re overtaking, make sure you move back safely into the left-hand lane before you reach the end of the dual carriageway.

prashna.text: Which of these signs means the end of a dual carriageway?

questions.explanation: Don’t wait until the last moment before moving into the left-hand lane. Plan ahead and don’t rely on other traffic letting you in.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. End of narrow bridge
B. Tall bridge
C. Road narrows
D. End of dual carriageway

questions.explanation: A warning sign with a picture of a windsock indicates that there may be strong side winds. This sign is often found on exposed roads.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Airport
B. Adverse camber
C. Road noise
D. Side winds

questions.explanation: This sign is there to alert you to the likelihood of danger ahead. It may be accompanied by a plate indicating the type of hazard. Be ready to reduce your speed and take avoiding action.

prashna.text: What does this traffic sign mean?

options.description: A. Danger ahead
B. Slippery road ahead
C. Tyres liable to punctures ahead
D. Service area ahead

questions.explanation:
You won’t be able to see any hazards that might be hidden in the dip. As well as oncoming traffic, the dip may conceal
• cyclists
• horse riders
• parked vehicles
• pedestrians
in the road.

prashna.text: You’re about to overtake. What should you do when you see this sign?

options.description: A. Hold back until you can see clearly ahead
B. Switch your headlights on before overtaking
C. Move to the right to get a better view
D. Overtake the other driver as quickly as possible

questions.explanation: Some crossings have gates but no attendant or signals. You should stop, look both ways, listen and make sure that no train is approaching. If there's a telephone, contact the signal operator to make sure it’s safe to cross.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Gated road ahead
B. Cattle grid ahead
C. Level crossing with gate or barrier
D. Level crossing without gate or barrier

questions.explanation: This sign tells you to beware of trams. If you don’t usually drive in a town where there are trams, remember to look out for them at junctions and look for tram rails, signs and signals.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Trams only
B. No trams ahead
C. Trams crossing ahead
D. Oncoming trams

questions.explanation: This sign gives you an early warning that the road ahead will slope downhill. Prepare to alter your speed and gear. Looking at the sign from left to right will show you whether the road slopes uphill or downhill.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Steep hill upwards
B. Uneven road
C. Steep hill downwards
D. Adverse camber

questions.explanation: This sign is found where a shallow stream crosses the road. Heavy rainfall could increase the flow of water. If the water looks too deep or the stream has spread over a large distance, stop and find another route.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Uneven road surface
B. Water across the road
C. Road ahead ends
D. Bridge over the road

questions.explanation: This sign shows you that you can’t get through to another route by turning left at the junction ahead.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Turn left for parking area
B. Turn left for ferry terminal
C. No through road on the left
D. No entry for traffic turning left

questions.explanation: You won't be able to find a through route to another road. Use this road only for access.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Toilet ahead
B. Telephone box ahead
C. No through road
D. T-junction

questions.explanation: This sign is found at the entrance to a road that can only be used for access.

prashna.text: Which sign means ‘no through road’?

questions.explanation: Ring roads are designed to relieve congestion in towns and city centres.

prashna.text: Which is the sign for a ring road?

questions.explanation: Yellow-and-black temporary signs may be used to inform you about roadworks or lane restrictions. Look well ahead. If you have to change lanes, do so in good time.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Right-hand lane for turning right
B. The right-hand lane is closed
C. Right-hand lane for buses only
D. The right-hand lane ahead is narrow

questions.explanation: If you use the right-hand lane in a contraflow system, you’ll be travelling with no permanent barrier between you and the oncoming traffic. Observe speed limits and keep a good distance from the vehicle ahead.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Contraflow system
B. Change to the left lane
C. Leave at the next exit
D. One-way street

questions.explanation: Where there’s a long, steep, uphill gradient on a motorway, a crawler lane may be provided. This helps the traffic to flow by diverting the slower heavy vehicles into a dedicated lane on the left.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Leave motorway at next exit
B. All lorries use the hard shoulder
C. Lane for heavy and slow vehicles
D. Rest area for lorries

questions.explanation: Whatever light is showing, you should know which light is going to appear next and be able to take appropriate action. For example, when amber is showing on its own, you’ll know that red will appear next. This should give you ample time to anticipate and respond safely.

prashna.text: What does a red traffic light mean?

options.description: A. You must stop and wait behind the stop line
B. Stop, if you're able to brake safely
C. Proceed with care
D. You should stop unless turning left

questions.explanation: When the amber light is showing on its own, the red light will follow next. The amber light means stop, unless you've already crossed the stop line or you're so close to it that stopping may cause a collision.

prashna.text: At traffic lights, what does it mean when the amber light shows on its own?

options.description: A. Stop at the stop line
B. Prepare to go
C. Go if no pedestrians are crossing
D. Go if the way is clear

questions.explanation: As you approach the lights, look into the road you wish to take. Only proceed if your exit road is clear. If the road is blocked, hold back, even if you have to wait for the next green signal.

prashna.text: You're at a junction controlled by traffic lights. When shouldn't you proceed at green?

options.description: A. When your exit from the junction is blocked
B. When you intend to turn right
C. When you think the lights may be about to change
D. When pedestrians are waiting to cross

questions.explanation: At some junctions, there may be separate signals for different lanes. These are called ‘filter’ lights. They’re designed to help traffic flow at major junctions. Make sure that you’re in the correct lane and proceed if the way is clear and the green light shows for your lane.

prashna.text: You're in the left-hand lane at traffic lights, waiting to turn left. At which of these traffic lights mustn't you move on?

questions.explanation: You might see this sign where traffic lights are out of order. Proceed with caution, as nobody has priority at the junction.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Amber signal out of order
B. New traffic lights ahead
C. Traffic lights out of order
D. Temporary traffic lights ahead

questions.explanation: When traffic lights are out of order, you should treat the junction as an unmarked crossroads. Be cautious, as you may need to give way or stop. Look for traffic attempting to cross the junction, unaware that it doesn’t have priority.

prashna.text: When traffic lights are out of order, who has priority?

options.description: A. Traffic turning left
B. Nobody
C. Traffic going straight on
D. Traffic turning right

questions.explanation: These signals are found at level crossings, swing or lifting bridges, some airfields and emergency access sites. The flashing red lights mean stop whether or not the way seems to be clear.

prashna.text: These flashing red lights mean that you must stop. Where would you find them?

options.description: A. Zebra crossings
B. Level crossings
C. Motorway exits
D. Pelican crossings

questions.explanation: The approach to, and exit from, a pedestrian crossing is marked with zigzag lines. You mustn't park on them or overtake the leading vehicle when approaching the crossing. Parking here would block the view for pedestrians and approaching traffic.

prashna.text: What do these zigzag lines at pedestrian crossings mean?

options.description: A. No parking at any time
B. Parking allowed only for a short time
C. Sounding horns isn't allowed
D. Slow down to 20 mph

questions.explanation: You may cross the solid white line to pass a stationary vehicle or to pass a pedal cycle, horse or road maintenance vehicle if it's travelling at 10 mph or less. You may also cross the solid white line to enter a side road or access a property.

prashna.text: When may you cross a double solid white line in the middle of the road?

options.description: A. To pass a car signalling to turn left ahead
B. To pass traffic that's queuing back at a junction
C. To pass a road maintenance vehicle travelling at 10 mph or less
D. To pass a vehicle that's towing a trailer

questions.explanation: Road markings will warn you of a hazard ahead. A single broken line along the centre of the road, with long markings and short gaps, is a hazard warning line. Don’t cross it unless you can see that the road is clear well ahead.

prashna.text: What does this road marking mean?

options.description: A. No overtaking allowed
B. No stopping allowed
C. Don't cross the line
D. You're approaching a hazard

questions.explanation: Because the road has a dark colour, changes in level aren’t easily seen. White triangles painted on the road surface give you an indication of where there are road humps.

prashna.text: Where would you see this road marking?

options.description: A. Near a level crossing
B. On road humps
C. At a box junction
D. At traffic lights

questions.explanation: You need to know the difference between the normal centre line and a hazard warning line. If there's a hazard ahead, the markings are longer and the gaps shorter. This gives you advance warning of an unspecified hazard.

prashna.text: Which of these is a hazard warning line?

questions.explanation: If your view at a road junction is restricted, you must stop. There may also be a ‘stop’ sign. Don’t emerge until you’re sure no traffic is approaching. If you don't know, don't go.

prashna.text: At this junction, there's a 'stop' sign and a solid white line on the road surface. Why is there a 'stop' sign here?

options.description: A. Visibility along the major road is restricted
B. There are hazard warning lines in the centre of the road
C. Speed on the major road is derestricted
D. It's a busy junction

questions.explanation: Slow down as you approach the roundabout and check for traffic from the right. If you need to stop and give way, stay behind the broken line until it's safe to emerge onto the roundabout.

prashna.text: You see this line across the road at the entrance to a roundabout. What does it mean?

options.description: A. Stop at the line
B. Give way to traffic from the right
C. Traffic from the left has right of way
D. You have right of way

questions.explanation: You must obey signals given by the police. If a police officer in a patrol vehicle wants you to pull over, they'll indicate this without causing danger to you or other traffic.

prashna.text: How will a police officer in a patrol vehicle normally get you to stop?

options.description: A. Wait until you stop, then approach you
B. Use the siren, overtake, cut in front and stop
C. Pull alongside you, use the siren and wave you to stop
D. Flash the headlights, indicate left and point to the left

questions.explanation: When a police officer or traffic warden is directing traffic, you must obey them. They'll use the arm signals shown in The Highway Code. Learn what these signals mean and obey them.

prashna.text: You're approaching a junction where the traffic lights aren't working. What should you do when a police officer gives this signal?

options.description: A. Continue ahead only
B. Turn left only
C. Stop at the stop line
D. Turn right only

questions.explanation: There might be an occasion where another driver uses an arm signal. This may be because the vehicle’s indicators are obscured by other traffic. In order for such signals to be effective, all drivers should know their meaning. Be aware that the ‘left turn’ signal might look similar to the ‘slowing down’ signal.

prashna.text: The driver of the car in front is giving this arm signal. What does it mean?

options.description: A. The driver wishes to overtake
B. The driver intends to turn left
C. The driver is slowing down
D. The driver intends to turn right

questions.explanation: When driving on a motorway or slip road, you mustn't enter an area marked with chevrons and bordered by a solid white line for any reason, except in an emergency.

prashna.text: Where would you see these road markings?

options.description: A. At a level crossing
B. At a pedestrian crossing
C. On a motorway slip road
D. On a single-track road

questions.explanation:
On the motorway, signs sometimes show temporary warnings due to traffic or weather conditions. They may be used to indicate
• lane closures
• temporary speed limits
• weather warnings.

prashna.text: What does this motorway sign mean?

options.description: A. Pull up on the hard shoulder
B. Change to the lane on your left
C. Change to the opposite carriageway
D. Leave the motorway at the next exit

questions.explanation: Look out for signs above your lane or on the central reservation. These will give you important information or warnings about the road ahead. To allow for the high speed of motorway traffic, these signs may light up some distance from any hazard. Don’t ignore the signs just because the road looks clear to you.

prashna.text: What does this motorway sign mean?

options.description: A. Obstruction 50 metres (164 feet) ahead
B. Temporary maximum speed 50 mph
C. Temporary minimum speed 50 mph
D. No services for 50 miles

questions.explanation: You should change lanes as directed by the sign. Here, the right-hand lane is closed but the left-hand and centre lanes are available. Merging in turn is recommended when it’s safe and traffic is going slowly; for example, at roadworks or a road traffic incident. When vehicles are travelling at speed, this isn't advisable and you should move into the appropriate lane in good time.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. 11 tonne weight limit
B. Right-hand lane T-junction only
C. Right-hand lane closed ahead
D. Through traffic to use left lane

questions.explanation: Before you set out on your journey, use a road map to plan your route. When you see an advance warning of your junction, make sure you get into the correct lane in plenty of time. Last-minute harsh braking and cutting across lanes at speed is extremely hazardous.

prashna.text: What does ‘25’ mean on this motorway sign?

options.description: A. The distance to the nearest town
B. The route number of the road
C. The number of the next junction
D. The speed limit on the slip road

questions.explanation: You should stay in the left-hand lane of a motorway unless you're overtaking another vehicle. The right-hand lane of a motorway is an overtaking lane; it isn't the ‘fast lane’. After overtaking, move back to the left when it's safe to do so.

prashna.text: How should the right-hand lane of a three-lane motorway be used?

options.description: A. As a high-speed lane
B. As an acceleration lane
C. As a right-turn lane
D. As an overtaking lane

questions.explanation: At night or in poor visibility, reflective studs on the road help you to judge your position on the carriageway.

prashna.text: Where can you find reflective amber studs on a motorway?

options.description: A. Separating the lanes
B. Separating the slip road from the motorway
C. On the right-hand edge of the road
D. On the left-hand edge of the road

questions.explanation: Knowing the colours of the reflective studs on the road will help you judge your position, especially at night, in foggy conditions or when visibility is poor.

prashna.text: Where on a motorway would you find green reflective studs?

options.description: A. Between the carriageway and the central reservation
B. Separating driving lanes
C. Between the hard shoulder and the carriageway
D. At slip-road entrances and exits

questions.explanation: You’ll see this sign if the motorway is closed ahead. Pull into the left-hand lane as soon as it's safe to do so. Don’t wait until the last moment before you move across, because the lane may be busy and you'll have to rely on another driver making room for you.

prashna.text: What should you do when you see this sign as you travel along a motorway?

options.description: A. Leave the motorway at the next exit
B. Turn left immediately
C. Change lane
D. Move onto the hard shoulder

questions.explanation: When you leave the motorway, make sure that you check your speedometer. You may be going faster than you realise. Slow down and look for speed-limit signs.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. No motor vehicles
B. End of bus lane
C. End of motorway
D. No through road

questions.explanation: You should know the speed limit for the road on which you're travelling and the vehicle that you're driving. The different speed limits are shown in The Highway Code.

prashna.text: Which of these signs means that the national speed limit applies?

questions.explanation: If you’re travelling on a dual carriageway that becomes a single carriageway road, reduce your speed gradually so that you aren’t exceeding the limit as you enter. There might not be a sign to remind you of the limit, so make sure you know the speed limits for different types of road and vehicle.

prashna.text: What's the maximum speed on a single carriageway road?

options.description: A. 40 mph
B. 50 mph
C. 60 mph
D. 70 mph

questions.explanation: Temporary restrictions on motorways are shown on signs that have flashing amber lights. At the end of the restriction, you'll see this sign without any flashing lights.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Lane ends ahead
B. Free recovery ends
C. End of restriction
D. End of motorway

questions.explanation: When a diversion route has been put in place, drivers are advised to follow a symbol, which may be a black triangle, square, circle or diamond shape on a yellow background.

prashna.text: What does this sign indicate?

options.description: A. A cycle route
B. A diversion route
C. A picnic area
D. A pedestrian zone

questions.explanation: In the interests of road safety, temporary mandatory speed limits are imposed at all major roadworks. Signs like this, giving advance warning of the speed limit, are normally placed about three-quarters of a mile ahead of where the speed limit comes into force.

prashna.text: What does this temporary sign indicate?

options.description: A. A mandatory speed-limit change ahead
B. An advisory change of speed limit ahead
C. A variable speed limit ahead
D. The speed-limit change at the end of the motorway

questions.explanation: The sign gives you an early warning of a speed restriction. If you're travelling at a higher speed, slow down in good time. You could come across queuing traffic due to roadworks or a temporary obstruction.

prashna.text: What does this traffic sign mean?

options.description: A. Compulsory minimum speed limit
B. Advisory maximum speed limit
C. Compulsory maximum speed limit
D. Advised separation distance

questions.explanation: When traffic lights are out of order, treat the junction as an unmarked crossroads. Be very careful and be prepared to stop; no-one has priority.

prashna.text: What should you do when you see this sign at a crossroads?

options.description: A. Find another route
B. Carry on with great care
C. Maintain the same speed
D. Telephone the police

questions.explanation: In some situations, you may feel your indicators can't be seen by other road users. If you think you need to make your intention more obvious, give the arm signal shown in The Highway Code.

prashna.text: You're signalling to turn right in busy traffic. How would you confirm your intention safely?

options.description: A. Sound the horn
B. Flash your headlights
C. Give an arm signal
D. Position over the centre line

questions.explanation: You must comply with all traffic signs and be especially aware of those signs that apply specifically to the type of vehicle you're using.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. No cars
B. Motorcycles only
C. Cars only
D. No motorcycles

questions.explanation: Sometimes work is carried out on the motorway without closing the lanes. When this happens, signs are mounted on the back of lorries to warn other road users of the roadworks ahead.

prashna.text: You're on a motorway. A lorry has stopped in the right-hand lane. What should you do when you see this sign on the lorry?

options.description: A. Leave the motorway at the next exit
B. Move into the right-hand lane
C. Pass the lorry on the left
D. Stop behind the flashing lights

questions.explanation: Flashing red lights above your lane show that your lane is closed. You should move into another lane as soon as you can do so safely.

prashna.text: You're on a motorway. Red flashing lights appear above your lane only. What should you do?

options.description: A. Move into another lane in good time
B. Pull onto the hard shoulder
C. Continue in that lane and look for further information
D. Stop and wait for an instruction to proceed

questions.explanation: Never sound the horn aggressively. You mustn't sound it when driving in a built-up area between 11.30 pm and 7.00 am, or when you're stationary, unless another road user poses a danger. Don't scare animals by sounding your horn.

prashna.text: When may you sound the horn?

options.description: A. To attract a friend’s attention
B. To make slower drivers move over
C. To warn others of your presence
D. To give you right of way

questions.explanation: When your vehicle is stationary, only sound the horn if you think there's a risk of danger from another road user. Don’t use it just to attract someone’s attention. This causes unnecessary noise and could be misleading.

prashna.text: Your vehicle is stationary. When may you use its horn?

options.description: A. When signalling that you've just arrived
B. When another road user poses a danger
C. When the road is blocked by queuing traffic
D. When it's used only briefly

questions.explanation: Urban clearways are provided to keep traffic flowing at busy times. You may stop only briefly to set down or pick up passengers. Times of operation will vary from place to place, so always check the signs.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. You can park on the days and times shown
B. End of the urban clearway restrictions
C. No parking on the days and times shown
D. No parking at all from Monday to Friday

questions.explanation: You should be careful in these locations, as the road surface is likely to be wet and slippery. There may be a steep drop to the water, and there may not be a barrier along the edge of the road.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Steep hill downwards
B. Uneven road surface
C. Road liable to flooding
D. Quayside or river bank

questions.explanation: Even though you have priority, be prepared to give way if other drivers don’t. This will help to avoid congestion, confrontation or even a collision.

prashna.text: Which sign means you have priority over oncoming vehicles?

questions.explanation: The centre of the road is usually marked by a broken white line, with lines that are shorter than the gaps. When the lines become longer than the gaps, this is a hazard warning line. Look well ahead for these, especially when you're planning to overtake or turn off.

prashna.text: What does this white line along the centre of the road mean?

options.description: A. Hazard warning
B. Give way warning
C. Bus lane marking
D. Lane marking

questions.explanation: Yellow ‘box junctions’ like this are often used where it’s busy. Their purpose is to keep the junction clear for crossing traffic. Don’t enter the painted area unless your exit is clear. The one exception is when you're turning right and are only prevented from doing so by oncoming traffic or by other vehicles waiting to turn right.

prashna.text: What's the reason for the yellow crisscross lines painted on the road here?

options.description: A. To mark out an area for trams only
B. To warn you of the tram lines crossing the road
C. To prevent queuing traffic from blocking the junction on the left
D. To mark the entrance lane to a car park

questions.explanation: Areas of ‘hatched markings’ such as these separate traffic streams that could be a danger to each other. They're often seen on bends or where the road becomes narrow. If the area is bordered by a solid white line, you mustn't enter it except in an emergency.

prashna.text: What's the reason for the hatched area along the centre of this road?

options.description: A. It's a temporary marking to warn of the roadworks
B. It separates traffic flowing in opposite directions
C. It marks an area to be used by overtaking motorcyclists
D. It separates the two sides of the dual carriageway

questions.explanation: If other drivers flash their headlights, this isn’t a signal to show priority. The flashing of headlights has the same meaning as sounding the horn: it’s a warning of their presence.

prashna.text: Other drivers may sometimes flash their headlights at you. In which situation are they allowed to do this?

options.description: A. To let you know there's a fault with your vehicle
B. To warn of a radar speed trap ahead
C. To warn you of their presence
D. To show that they're giving way to you

questions.explanation: In some built-up areas, you may find the speed limit reduced to 20 mph. Driving at a slower speed will help give you the time and space to see and deal safely with hazards such as pedestrians and other vulnerable road users.

prashna.text: What speed limit is often found in narrow residential streets?

options.description: A. 20 mph
B. 35 mph
C. 25 mph
D. 40 mph

questions.explanation: The white light shows that trams must stop. The green light shows that other vehicles can go if the way is clear. Trams are being introduced into more cities, so you're likely to come across them and you should learn which signs apply to them.

prashna.text: What does this signal mean?

options.description: A. Both trams and cars must stop
B. Both trams and cars can continue
C. Cars must stop
D. Trams must stop

questions.explanation: These markings show the direction in which the traffic should go at a mini-roundabout.

prashna.text: Where would you find these road markings?

options.description: A. At a railway crossing
B. On a pedestrian crossing
C. At a mini-roundabout
D. On a motorway

questions.explanation: You must pull up on the left as soon as it’s safe to do so and switch off your engine.

prashna.text: A police car is following you. The police officer flashes the headlights and points to the left. What should you do?

options.description: A. Stop immediately
B. Turn left at the next junction
C. Pull up on the left
D. Move over to the left

questions.explanation:
At junctions controlled by traffic lights, you must stop behind the white line until the lights change to green. A red light, an amber light, and red and amber lights showing together all mean stop.
You may proceed when the light is green unless your exit road is blocked or pedestrians are crossing in front of you.
If you’re approaching traffic lights that are visible from a distance and the light has been green for some time, be ready to slow down and stop, because the lights are likely to change.

prashna.text: You see this amber traffic light ahead. Which light, or lights, will come on next?

options.description: A. Green alone
B. Red and amber together
C. Red alone
D. Green and amber together

premium.explanation:
You'll see this sign if there has been an incident ahead and the motorway is closed. You must obey the sign. Make sure that you prepare to leave in good time.
Don’t cause drivers to take avoiding action by cutting in at the last moment.

prashna.text: You see this signal overhead on the motorway. What does it mean?

options.description: A. Stop: all lanes ahead closed
B. All vehicles use the hard shoulder
C. Leave the motorway at the next exit
D. Sharp bend to the left ahead

premium.explanation:
'Stop' signs are situated at junctions where visibility is restricted or where there's heavy traffic. They must be obeyed: you must stop.
Take good all-round observation before moving off.

prashna.text: What must you do when you see this sign?

options.description: A. Stop even if the road is clear
B. Stop only if children are waiting to cross
C. Stop only if traffic is approaching
D. Stop only if a red light is showing

premium.explanation: Other warning signs are the same shape and colour, but the ‘give way’ triangle points downwards. When you see this sign, you must give way to traffic on the road that you're about to enter.

prashna.text: Which shape is used for a ‘give way’ sign?

premium.explanation: When you see this sign, look out for any direction signs and judge whether you need to signal your intentions. Do this in good time so that other road users approaching the roundabout know what you’re planning to do.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Ring road
B. Keep right
C. Mini-roundabout
D. Buses turning

premium.explanation: Be prepared for traffic approaching from junctions on either side of you. Try to avoid unnecessary changing of lanes just before the junction.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Two-way traffic crosses a one-way road
B. Two-way traffic crosses a two-way road
C. Two-way traffic over a bridge
D. Two-way traffic straight ahead

premium.explanation: This sign may be at the end of a dual carriageway or a one-way street. It's there to warn you of oncoming traffic.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Two-way traffic crosses a one-way road
B. Traffic approaching you has priority
C. Motorway contraflow system ahead
D. Two-way traffic straight ahead

premium.explanation: You'll need to slow down. At hump bridges, your view ahead will be restricted and the road will often be narrow. If the bridge is very steep, sound your horn to warn others of your approach. Going over the bridge too fast is highly dangerous to other road users and could even cause your wheels to leave the road, with a resulting loss of control.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Uneven road
B. Low bridge
C. Traffic-calming hump
D. Hump bridge

premium.explanation: This sign is found at the entrance to a road that can only be used for access.

prashna.text: Which sign informs you that you're coming to a ‘no through road’?

premium.explanation:
To ease the congestion in town centres, some cities and towns provide park-and-ride schemes. These allow you to park in a designated area and ride by bus into the centre.
Park-and-ride schemes are usually cheaper and easier than car parking in the town centre.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Parking area for cars and coaches
B. Direction to park-and-ride car park
C. No parking for buses or coaches
D. Direction to bus and coach park

premium.explanation: Be aware that other traffic might still be clearing the junction as you approach. A green light means you may go on, but only if the way is clear.

prashna.text: What should you do when approaching traffic lights where red and amber are showing together?

options.description: A. Pass the lights if the road is clear
B. Wait for the green light
C. Take care because there's a fault with the lights
D. Stop because the lights are changing to red

premium.explanation: This road marking means you should give way to traffic on the main road. It might not be used at junctions where there isn't much traffic. However, if there's a double broken line across the junction, the ‘give way’ rules still apply.

prashna.text: Where does this marking normally appear on a road?

options.description: A. Just before a 'no entry' sign
B. Just before a 'give way' sign
C. Just before a 'no through road' sign
D. Just before a 'stop' sign

premium.explanation: You must always obey red flashing stop lights. If a train passes but the lights continue to flash, another train will be passing soon. Cross only when the lights go off and the barriers open.

prashna.text: At a railway level crossing, the red lights continue to flash after a train has gone by. What should you do?

options.description: A. Phone the signal operator
B. Proceed with caution
C. Alert drivers behind you
D. Wait

premium.explanation: If you have to leave your vehicle and get out of a tunnel by an emergency exit, do so as quickly as you can. Follow the signs directing you to the nearest exit point. If there are several people using the exit, don’t panic but try to leave in a calm and orderly manner.

prashna.text: You're in a tunnel and you see this sign. What does it mean?

options.description: A. Beware of pedestrians crossing ahead
B. No access for pedestrians
C. Direction to emergency pedestrian exit
D. Beware of pedestrians: no footpath ahead

premium.explanation: If the road has two lanes, you can use either lane and overtake on either side. Use the lane that’s more convenient for your destination unless signs or road markings indicate otherwise.

prashna.text: Which of these signs shows that you're entering a one-way system?

premium.explanation: Buses and cycles can travel in this lane. In this example, they'll flow in the same direction as other traffic. If it’s busy, they may be passing you on the left, so watch out for them. Times on the sign will show the lane's hours of operation; if no times are shown, or there's no sign at all, this means the lane is in operation 24 hours a day. In some areas, other vehicles, such as taxis and motorcycles, are allowed to use bus lanes. The sign will show if this is the case.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Contraflow bus and cycle lane
B. No buses and cycles allowed
C. No waiting for buses and cycles
D. With-flow bus and cycle lane

premium.explanation: Look well ahead and check the pavements and surrounding areas for pedestrians. Look for anyone walking towards the crossing. Check your mirrors for traffic behind, in case you have to slow down or stop.

prashna.text: Which of these signs warns you of a zebra crossing?

premium.explanation: Look well ahead and be ready to stop for any pedestrians crossing, or about to cross, the road. Also check the pavements for anyone who looks like they might step or run into the road.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Zebra crossing ahead
B. School crossing patrol
C. No pedestrians allowed
D. Pedestrian zone – no vehicles

premium.explanation: This sign is found in or at the end of a one-way system. It warns you that traffic will be crossing your path from both directions.

prashna.text: Which sign means there will be two-way traffic crossing your route ahead?

premium.explanation: There may be occasions when drivers need to give an arm signal to confirm their intentions. This could include in bright sunshine, at a complex road layout, when stopping at a pedestrian crossing or when turning right just after passing a parked vehicle. You should understand what each arm signal means. If you give arm signals, make them clear, correct and decisive.

prashna.text: Which arm signal tells you that the car you're following is going to pull up?

premium.explanation: Blue circles tell you what you must do and this sign gives a clear instruction to turn left ahead. You should be looking out for signs at all times and know what they mean.

prashna.text: Which of these signs means turn left ahead?

premium.explanation: In a one-way system, traffic may pass you on either side. Always be aware of all traffic signs and understand their meaning. Look well ahead and react to them in good time.

prashna.text: What should you be aware of if you’ve just passed this sign?

options.description: A. All traffic is going one way
B. Only one lane is in use
C. You can’t stop on this road
D. This is a single-track road

premium.explanation: If you know which light is going to show next, you can plan your approach accordingly. This can help prevent excessive braking or hesitation at the junction.

prashna.text: You're approaching a red traffic light. What will the signal show next?

options.description: A. Green alone
B. Amber alone
C. Green and amber
D. Red and amber

premium.explanation: When approaching a tunnel, switch on your dipped headlights. Be aware that your eyes might need to adjust to the sudden darkness. You may need to reduce your speed.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Low bridge ahead
B. Tunnel ahead
C. Traffic danger spot ahead
D. Ancient monument ahead

premium.explanation: Every vehicle should have a registration document showing the registered keeper. It's your legal responsibility to make sure all the information is correct. This includes make, model and engine size. If you buy a new vehicle, the dealer will register it with DVLA, who will send the registration document to you.

prashna.text: What information is found on a vehicle registration document?

options.description: A. The make and model
B. The original purchase price
C. The service history
D. The ignition-key security number

premium.explanation: CBT courses can only be given by training bodies that are approved by DVSA. The standard of training is monitored by DVSA examiners. The course is designed to give you basic skills before riding on the road.

prashna.text: Who can carry out compulsory basic training (CBT)?

options.description: A. Any Driver and Vehicle Standards Agency (DVSA)-approved training body
B. Any motorcycle main dealer
C. Any road safety officer
D. Any approved driving instructor (ADI)

premium.explanation: If you borrow a motorcycle, you must make sure that you're insured to ride it. It's better to find this out for yourself, rather than taking somebody else's word for it.

prashna.text: What should you be sure of before riding anyone else’s motorcycle?

options.description: A. That the owner has third-party insurance cover
B. That the motorcycle is insured for your use
C. That the owner has the insurance documents with them
D. That your own motorcycle has insurance cover

premium.explanation: Any motorcycle you ride must be in good condition and roadworthy. If it's over three years old, it must have a valid MOT test certificate (unless it's exempt from the MOT test - see GOV.UK).

prashna.text: How long after first registration must a motorcycle have its first MOT test?

options.description: A. Seven years
B. One year
C. Three years
D. Five years

premium.explanation: Every vehicle on the road has a registration document. This records any change of ownership and gives specific information relating to the vehicle and owner. This includes the date of first registration, the registration number, the make and colour of the vehicle, and the registered keeper’s name.

prashna.text: What information can be found on a motorcycle’s registration document?

options.description: A. The registered keeper’s name
B. The type of insurance cover required
C. The service history
D. The date of the MOT

premium.explanation: DVLA need to keep their records up to date. They'll send you a reminder when you need to tax your vehicle. To do this, they need your current address. Every vehicle in the country is registered so that its history can be traced.

prashna.text: You own a motorcycle licensed in the UK. When do you have a duty to contact the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA)?

options.description: A. When you go abroad on holiday
B. When your job involves riding abroad
C. When you change your job status
D. When your permanent address changes

premium.explanation: Third-party insurance is usually cheaper than comprehensive insurance. It covers injuries to other people and damage to their property, but it doesn’t cover any damage to your own motorcycle or property. Nor does it provide cover if your motorcycle is stolen.

prashna.text: Your motorcycle is insured third-party only. What does this cover?

options.description: A. Injury to others
B. Injury to yourself
C. All damage and injury
D. Damage to your motorcycle

premium.explanation: The minimum insurance cover required by law is third-party only. This covers the other people and vehicles involved in a collision, but not you or your vehicle. Also, basic third-party insurance won’t cover you for theft or fire damage. Make sure you read your policy carefully and understand what it covers.

prashna.text: What's the legal minimum insurance cover you must have to ride on public roads?

options.description: A. Comprehensive
B. Third-party, fire and theft
C. Third-party only
D. Personal injury cover

premium.explanation: A motorcycle registration document contains a number of details that are unique to a particular vehicle. You must notify DVLA of any changes to, for example, the registered keeper or registration number. You must also tell them about any modifications made to the motorcycle.

prashna.text: What does a motorcycle registration document show?

options.description: A. The tyre sizes
B. The service history
C. The year of first registration
D. The purchase price

premium.explanation: It's your responsibility to make sure that any motorcycle you ride is in a roadworthy condition. Any faults that develop should be corrected promptly. If your motorcycle fails an MOT test, it shouldn't be used on the road unless you’re taking it to have the faults repaired or for a previously arranged retest.

prashna.text: What's the purpose of an MOT test?

options.description: A. To prove you own the motorcycle
B. To make sure your motorcycle is roadworthy
C. To allow you to park in restricted areas
D. To certify how many miles per gallon it does

premium.explanation: The purpose of a CBT course is to teach you basic theory and practical skills before you ride on the road, on your own, for the first time. CBT courses can only be given by approved training bodies (ATBs).

prashna.text: What do you need before you can take a practical motorcycle test?

options.description: A. A valid full car licence
B. A valid full moped licence
C. 12 months’ riding experience
D. A valid compulsory basic training (CBT) certificate

premium.explanation: The licensing authorities hold the records of all vehicles, drivers and riders in Great Britain and Northern Ireland. They need to keep their records up to date and you must notify them if any aspect of your health affects your ability to ride your motorcycle.

prashna.text: When must you notify the licensing authority?

options.description: A. When you intend to take your motorcycle abroad on holiday
B. When you wish to renew your motorcycle’s MOT certificate
C. When your insurance is due for renewal
D. When you have a medical condition that affects your riding

premium.explanation: If the number of points on your licence reaches six or more during your first two years of holding a full licence, your licence will be revoked. This includes offences you committed before you passed your test. You may ride only as a learner until you pass both the theory and practical tests again.

prashna.text: You've just passed your practical motorcycle test. This is your first full licence. What will you have to do if you gather six or more penalty points within the next two years?

options.description: A. Reapply for your full licence immediately
B. Retake only your theory test
C. Retake only your practical test
D. Reapply for your provisional licence

premium.explanation: Provisional entitlement means that restrictions apply to your use of motorcycles. For example, you may not ride on a motorway or carry a passenger. The requirements are there to protect you and other road users. Make sure you're aware of all the restrictions that apply before you ride your motorcycle on the road.

prashna.text: You hold a provisional motorcycle licence. What does this licence restrict you from doing?

options.description: A. Carrying a pillion passenger
B. Riding after dark
C. Riding on a dual carriageway
D. Exceeding 30 mph

premium.explanation: When you pass your test on a motorcycle between 120 cc and 125 cc, you'll be issued with a full light motorcycle licence of category A1. You'll then be allowed to ride any motorcycle up to 125 cc and with a power output not exceeding 11 kW (14.6 bhp).

prashna.text: What's the maximum engine size a full category A1 motorcycle licence will allow you to ride?

options.description: A. 125 cc
B. 425 cc
C. 350 cc
D. 250 cc

premium.explanation: When training under the direct access scheme, you must be accompanied by an instructor on another motorcycle, who must be in radio contact with you. You must display red L plates to the front and rear of your motorcycle and follow all normal learner restrictions.

prashna.text: Do you need to display L plates when learning to ride a motorcycle under the direct access scheme?

options.description: A. No, you don't need L plates if you've passed a car test
B. No, you don't need L plates if you've passed a moped test
C. Yes, you need L plates while learning with a qualified instructor
D. Yes, you need L plates only when learning on your own machine

premium.explanation: Before carrying a passenger on a motorcycle, the rider must hold a full licence for the category of motorcycle being ridden. They must also ensure that a proper passenger seat and footrests are fitted.

prashna.text: A motorcyclist is riding a motorcycle that has an engine larger than 50 cc. When may they carry a pillion passenger?

options.description: A. When the rider holds a full licence for the category of motorcycle they’re riding
B. When the rider has successfully completed CBT (compulsory basic training)
C. When the rider has a full car licence and is over 21
D. When no sidecar is fitted to the machine

premium.explanation: All new learner motorcycle and moped riders must complete a CBT course before riding on the road. This can only be given by an approved training body (ATB). If you don’t pass your practical test within two years, you'll need to retake and pass CBT to continue riding.

prashna.text: You have a CBT (compulsory basic training) certificate. How long is it valid?

options.description: A. Four years
B. Two years
C. One year
D. Three years

premium.explanation: You'll normally be sent a reminder automatically by DVLA close to the time of renewal. Make sure that all your documentation is correct, up to date and valid. You can renew online, by phone or at certain post offices.

prashna.text: Your vehicle tax is due to expire. To renew it, you'll need a renewal form, the fee and a valid MOT (if applicable). What else will you need?

options.description: A. A CBT certificate
B. A complete service record
C. A valid certificate of insurance
D. Proof of purchase

premium.explanation: As a learner motorcyclist, you aren't allowed to carry a pillion passenger, even if they hold a full motorcycle licence. You mustn't carry a passenger, or tow a trailer, until you've passed your test.

prashna.text: What must you have to legally carry a pillion passenger on your motorcycle?

options.description: A. A motorcycle with an engine larger than 125 cc
B. A full motorcycle licence
C. A passenger who holds a full motorcycle licence
D. Three years’ motorcycle riding experience

premium.explanation: By law, you can only carry a pillion passenger after you've gained a full motorcycle licence. It makes no difference if the passenger holds a full licence. As a learner, you're also prohibited from towing a trailer or riding on motorways.

prashna.text: A friend asks you to give them a lift on your motorcycle. What conditions apply?

options.description: A. Your motorcycle must be larger than 125 cc
B. The pillion passenger must hold a full motorcycle licence
C. You must have a full motorcycle licence
D. You must have three years’ motorcycle riding experience

premium.explanation: This is a method used by insurance companies to keep annual premiums down. Generally, the higher the excess you choose to pay, the lower the annual premium you'll be charged.

prashna.text: Your motorcycle insurance policy has an excess of £100. What does this mean?

options.description: A. The insurance company will pay the first £100 of any claim
B. You'll have to pay the first £100 of any claim
C. You'll be paid £100 if you don't have a crash
D. Your motorcycle is insured for a value of £100 if it's stolen

premium.explanation: Some garages will remind you that your vehicle is due for its annual MOT test, but not all do. To ensure continuous cover, you may take your vehicle for its MOT up to one month before its existing MOT certificate runs out. The expiry date on the new certificate will be 12 months after the expiry date on the old certificate.

prashna.text: For how long is an MOT certificate normally valid?

options.description: A. 10,000 miles
B. Three years after the date it was issued
C. 30,000 miles
D. One year after the date it was issued

premium.explanation: Sometimes an insurance company will issue a temporary insurance certificate called a cover note. It gives you the same insurance cover as your certificate but lasts for a limited period, usually one month.

prashna.text: What is a cover note?

options.description: A. A document issued before you receive your MOT certificate
B. A document issued before you receive your insurance certificate
C. A document issued before you receive your driving licence
D. A document issued before you receive your registration document

premium.explanation: If you accumulate six or more penalty points within two years of gaining your first full licence, it will be revoked. The six or more points include any gained due to offences you committed before passing your test. If this happens, you may only drive as a learner until you pass both the theory and practical tests again.

prashna.text: You've just passed your practical test. You don't hold a full licence in another category. Within two years you get six penalty points on your licence. What will you have to do?

options.description: A. Retake only your practical test
B. Retake only your theory test
C. Retake your theory and practical tests
D. Reapply for your full licence immediately

premium.explanation: A SORN allows you to keep a vehicle off-road and untaxed. SORN will end when the vehicle is taxed, sold or scrapped.

prashna.text: For how long is a Statutory Off-Road Notification (SORN) valid?

options.description: A. Until the vehicle is used on the road
B. Until the vehicle is insured and MOT’d
C. Until the vehicle is taxed, sold or scrapped
D. Until the vehicle is repaired or modified

premium.explanation: If you want to keep a vehicle untaxed and off the public road, you must make a SORN. It's an offence not to do so. Your SORN is valid until your vehicle is taxed, sold or scrapped.

prashna.text: What is a Statutory Off-Road Notification (SORN)?

options.description: A. Information held by insurance companies to check a vehicle is insured
B. A notification to tell DVSA that a vehicle doesn't have a current MOT
C. Information kept by the police about the owner of a vehicle
D. A notification to tell DVLA that a vehicle isn't being used on the road

premium.explanation: Driving without insurance is a serious offence. As well as an unlimited fine, you may be disqualified or incur penalty points.

prashna.text: What's the maximum fine for driving without insurance?

options.description: D. Unlimited

premium.explanation: It's your legal responsibility to keep the details on your vehicle registration certificate (V5C) up to date. You should tell the licensing authority about any changes. These include your name, address or vehicle details. If you don’t do this, you may have problems when you try to sell your vehicle.

prashna.text: Who's legally responsible for ensuring that a vehicle registration certificate (V5C) is updated?

options.description: A. Your insurance company
B. The registered vehicle keeper
C. The licensing authority
D. The vehicle manufacturer

premium.explanation: You must produce a valid insurance certificate when requested by a police officer. If you can’t do this immediately, you may be asked to take it to a police station. Other documents you may be asked to produce are your driving licence and the vehicle's MOT certificate.

prashna.text: In which of these circumstances must you show your insurance certificate?

options.description: A. When having an MOT inspection
B. When making a SORN
C. When a police officer asks you for it
D. When buying or selling a vehicle

premium.explanation: Your vehicle must have valid insurance cover before you can tax it. If required, it will also need to have a valid MOT certificate. You can tax your vehicle online, by phone or at certain post offices.

prashna.text: Your vehicle must have valid insurance cover before you can do what?

options.description: A. Make a SORN
B. Scrap the vehicle
C. Tax the vehicle
D. Sell the vehicle

premium.explanation: If your vehicle is required to have an MOT certificate, you'll need to make sure this is current before you're able to tax your vehicle. You can do this online, by phone or at certain post offices.

prashna.text: Your vehicle needs a current MOT certificate. What will the MOT certificate enable you to do?

options.description: A. Tax your vehicle
B. Notify a change of address
C. Change your insurance company
D. Renew your driving licence

premium.explanation:
Using a vehicle on the road illegally carries a heavy fine and can lead to penalty points on your driving licence. You must have
• a valid driving licence
• paid the appropriate vehicle tax
• proper insurance cover.

prashna.text: Which of these is needed before you can legally use a vehicle on the road?

options.description: A. A vehicle handbook
B. Proof of your identity
C. A valid driving licence
D. Breakdown cover

premium.explanation: You can renew your vehicle tax online, at post offices and vehicle registration offices, or by phone. When applying, make sure you have all the relevant valid documents, including a valid MOT test certificate where applicable.

prashna.text: What must you have when you apply to renew your vehicle tax?

options.description: A. A valid driving licence
B. The vehicle's chassis number
C. Valid insurance
D. The handbook

premium.explanation: You don’t have to carry around your vehicle's documents wherever you go. If a police officer asks to see them and you don’t have them with you, you may be asked to produce them at a police station within 7 days.

prashna.text: A police officer asks to see your documents. You don't have them with you. Within what time must you produce them at a police station?

options.description: A. 14 days
B. 21 days
C. 7 days
D. 5 days

premium.explanation: As the registered keeper of a vehicle, it's up to you to inform DVLA of any changes in your details; for example, your name or address. You do this by completing and sending off the relevant section of the registration certificate.

prashna.text: When should you update your vehicle registration certificate?

options.description: A. When your vehicle needs an MOT
B. When you move house
C. When you pass your driving test
D. When you have a collision

premium.explanation: If you break down on a motorway, pull onto the hard shoulder and stop as far over to the left as you can. Switch on your hazard warning lights (if fitted) and go to the nearest emergency telephone. Marker posts spaced every 100 metres will show you where the nearest telephone is.

prashna.text: Your motorcycle has broken down on a motorway. How will you know the direction of the nearest emergency telephone?

options.description: A. By walking against the flow of traffic
B. By remembering where the last phone was
C. By walking with the flow of traffic
D. By following an arrow on a marker post

premium.explanation: Most motorcycles are fitted with an engine cut-out switch. This is designed to stop the engine in an emergency and so reduce the risk of electrical sparks starting a fire.

prashna.text: When should you use the engine cut-out switch?

options.description: A. To start the engine if you lose the key
B. To save wear on the ignition switch
C. To stop the engine after a short journey
D. To stop the engine in an emergency

premium.explanation: Drivers and riders may switch on their hazard warning lights to warn following traffic of an obstruction or danger ahead. This only applies on motorways and dual carriageways that are subject to the national speed limit. The hazard warning lights should be turned off again when it's clear the warning has been seen.

prashna.text: You're riding on a motorway. The car in front switches on its hazard warning lights while it's moving. What does this mean?

options.description: A. The driver is trying to change lanes
B. There's danger ahead
C. The driver is going to take the next exit
D. There's a police car ahead

premium.explanation: Have information about your motorcycle and the number of the phone you’re using ready before you call from an emergency telephone. For your own safety, face the traffic during the call.

prashna.text: What will you be asked when you use the emergency telephone on a motorway?

options.description: A. The number of the telephone you're using
B. The route you were taking before the breakdown
C. The name of your vehicle insurance company
D. The number on your driving licence

premium.explanation: Briefly using your hazard warning lights will warn the traffic behind you that there's a hazard ahead. Turn them off again when following drivers have seen and responded to your signal.

prashna.text: You're on a motorway. When can you use hazard warning lights?

options.description: A. When you're being towed by another vehicle
B. When you slow down quickly because of danger ahead
C. When a vehicle is following too closely
D. When you're riding on the hard shoulder

premium.explanation: If your motorcycle breaks down in a tunnel, it could present a danger to other traffic. First switch on your hazard warning lights and then call for help from an emergency telephone point. Don’t rely on being found by the police or being seen by a CCTV camera.

prashna.text: You're riding through a tunnel. What should you do if your motorcycle breaks down?

options.description: A. Wait for the police to find you
B. Switch on hazard warning lights
C. Remain on your motorcycle
D. Rely on CCTV cameras seeing you

premium.explanation: If any of your luggage falls onto the road, pull onto the hard shoulder near an emergency telephone and call for assistance. Don’t stop on the carriageway or attempt to retrieve anything.

prashna.text: You're on a motorway. Luggage falls from your motorcycle. What should you do?

options.description: A. Walk back up the motorway to pick it up
B. Stop at the next emergency telephone and report the hazard
C. Pull up on the hard shoulder and wave traffic down
D. Stop on the motorway and put on hazard warning lights while you pick it up

premium.explanation: If you're involved in a collision where someone is injured, your first priority is to warn other traffic and call the emergency services. Make sure you have all the information you need before you leave the scene - such as the other driver's name, phone number and insurance details. Don’t ride your motorcycle if it's unroadworthy.

prashna.text: You're involved in a collision with another vehicle. Someone is injured and your motorcycle is damaged. What should you find out?

options.description: A. Whether the driver owns the other vehicle involved
B. The other driver’s vehicle insurance details
C. Whether the other driver is licensed to drive
D. The occupation of the other driver
