premium.explanation: If a disabled driver’s vehicle breaks down and they're unable to walk to an emergency phone, they're advised to stay in their car and switch on the hazard warning lights. They may also display a 'help' pennant in their vehicle.

prashna.text: You see a car on the hard shoulder of a motorway with a 'help' pennant displayed. What does this mean?

options.description: A. The driver is likely to be a disabled person
B. The driver is a foreign visitor
C. The driver is a rescue patrol officer
D. The driver is first-aid trained

premium.explanation:
You mustn't use hazard warning lights while moving, except to warn traffic behind when you slow suddenly on a motorway or unrestricted dual carriageway.
Never use hazard warning lights to excuse dangerous or illegal parking.

prashna.text: When are you allowed to use hazard warning lights?

options.description: A. When travelling slowly because you're lost
B. When stopped and temporarily obstructing traffic
C. When travelling during darkness without headlights
D. When parked on double yellow lines to visit a shop

premium.explanation: It’s important to keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front at all times. This still applies in congested tunnels, even if you're moving very slowly or have stopped. If the vehicle in front breaks down, you may need room to manoeuvre past it.

prashna.text: You're going through a congested tunnel and have to stop. What should you do?

options.description: A. Ignore any message signs, as they're never up to date
B. Keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front
C. Pull up very close to the vehicle in front to save space
D. Make a U-turn and find another route

premium.explanation: The hard shoulder should only be used in a genuine emergency. If possible, and if it's safe, use a roadside telephone to call for help. This will give your exact location to the operator. Never cross the carriageway or a slip road to use a telephone on the other side of the road.

prashna.text: On a motorway, when should the hard shoulder be used?

options.description: A. When an emergency arises
B. When answering a mobile phone
C. When checking a road map
D. When taking a short rest

premium.explanation: If possible, lay the casualty down. Protect yourself from exposure to blood and, when you're sure there's nothing in the wound, apply firm pressure to it using clean material.

prashna.text: You arrive at the scene of a crash where someone is bleeding heavily from a wound in their arm. Nothing is embedded in the wound. What could you do to help?

options.description: A. Apply pressure over the wound
B. Walk them around and keep them talking
C. Dab the wound
D. Get them a drink

premium.explanation: If a casualty is unconscious, you need to check that they're breathing normally. Look for chest movements, look and listen for breathing, and feel for breath on your cheek.

prashna.text: You're at an incident. What could you do to help a casualty who's unconscious?

options.description: A. Move them to somewhere more comfortable
B. Check that they're breathing normally
C. Take photographs of the scene
D. Splash their face with cool water

premium.explanation: Check the casualty for shock and, if possible, try to cool the burn for at least 10 minutes using clean, cool water.

prashna.text: Following a collision, someone has suffered a burn. The burn needs to be cooled. What's the shortest time it should be cooled for?

options.description: A. 10 minutes
B. 15 minutes
C. 5 minutes
D. 20 minutes

premium.explanation: If a casualty isn't breathing normally, cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) may be needed to maintain circulation. Place two hands on the centre of the chest and press down hard and fast –  around 5–6 centimetres and about twice a second.

prashna.text: A casualty isn't breathing normally and needs CPR. At what rate should you press down and release on the centre of their chest?

options.description: A. 240 times per minute
B. 120 times per minute
C. 10 times per minute
D. 60 times per minute

premium.explanation: The effects of shock may not be immediately obvious. Warning signs are rapid pulse, sweating, pale grey skin and rapid shallow breathing.

prashna.text: A person has been injured. They may be suffering from shock. What are the warning signs to look for?

options.description: A. Warm dry skin
B. Pale grey skin
C. Slow pulse
D. Flushed complexion

premium.explanation: After a casualty has been placed in the recovery position, make sure their airway remains open and monitor their condition until medical help arrives. Where possible, don't move a casualty unless there’s further danger.

prashna.text: An injured person has been placed in the recovery position. They're unconscious but breathing normally. What else should be done?

options.description: A. Check their airway remains open
B. Place their arms by their side
C. Press firmly between their shoulders
D. Give them a hot sweet drink

premium.explanation: If someone has been injured, the sooner proper medical attention is given the better. Ask someone to phone for help or do it yourself. An injured person should only be moved if they’re in further danger. An injured motorcyclist’s helmet shouldn't be removed unless it's essential.

prashna.text: An injured motorcyclist is lying unconscious in the road. The traffic has stopped and there's no further danger. What should you do to help?

options.description: A. Seek medical assistance
B. Remove their leather jacket
C. Remove their safety helmet
D. Move the person off the road

premium.explanation: Lorry drivers can be unaware of objects falling from their vehicles. If you see something fall onto a motorway, look to see if the driver pulls over. If they don’t stop, don't attempt to retrieve the object yourself. Pull onto the hard shoulder near an emergency telephone and report the hazard.

prashna.text: What should you do if you see a large box fall from a lorry onto the motorway?

options.description: A. Stop close to the box until the police arrive
B. Pull over to the hard shoulder, then remove the box
C. Catch up with the lorry and try to get the driver’s attention
D. Go to the next emergency telephone and report the hazard

premium.explanation: Follow the instructions given by the signs or by tunnel officials. In congested tunnels, a minor incident can soon turn into a major one, with serious or even fatal results.

prashna.text: You're going through a long tunnel. What will warn you of congestion or an incident ahead?

options.description: A. Hazard warning lines
B. Other drivers flashing their lights
C. Variable message signs
D. Areas with hatch markings

premium.explanation: An adult casualty isn't breathing normally. To maintain circulation, place two hands on the centre of the chest. Then press down hard and fast – around 5–6 centimetres and about twice a second.

prashna.text: An adult casualty isn't breathing. To maintain circulation, CPR should be given. What's the correct depth to press down on their chest?

options.description: A. 1 to 2 centimetres
B. 15 to 20 centimetres
C. 5 to 6 centimetres
D. 10 to 15 centimetres

premium.explanation: At a crash scene you can help in practical ways, even if you aren’t trained in first aid. Call the emergency services and make sure you don't put yourself or anyone else in danger. The safest way to warn other traffic is by switching on your hazard warning lights.

prashna.text: You're the first to arrive at the scene of a crash. What should you do?

options.description: A. Flag down other motorists to help you
B. Call the emergency services promptly
C. Leave as soon as another motorist arrives
D. Drag all casualties away from the vehicles

premium.explanation: If you’re the first to arrive at a crash scene, the first concerns are the risk of further collision and fire. Ensuring that vehicle engines are switched off will reduce the risk of fire. Use hazard warning lights so that other traffic knows there’s a need for caution. Make sure the emergency services are contacted; don’t assume this has already been done.

prashna.text: You're the first person to arrive at an incident where people are badly injured. You’ve switched on your hazard warning lights and checked all engines are stopped. What else should you do?

options.description: A. Try and get people who are injured to drink something
B. Stop other cars and ask the drivers for help
C. Make sure that an ambulance is called for
D. Move the people who are injured clear of their vehicles

premium.explanation: Don't remove a motorcyclist’s helmet unless it's essential. Remember they may be suffering from shock. Don’t give them anything to eat or drink, but do reassure them confidently.

prashna.text: You arrive at the scene of a motorcycle crash. The rider is injured. When should their helmet be removed?

options.description: A. Only when the motorcyclist asks
B. Only when it's essential
C. Always, unless they're in shock
D. Always straight away

premium.explanation: At the scene of an incident, always be aware of danger from further collisions or fire. The first priority when dealing with an unconscious person is to ensure they're breathing normally. If they’re having difficulty breathing, follow the DR ABC code.

prashna.text: You arrive at an incident. There's no danger from fire or further collisions. What's your first priority when attending to an unconscious motorcyclist?

options.description: A. Check whether they have any bruising
B. Check whether they're breathing normally
C. Check whether they have any broken bones
D. Check whether they're bleeding

premium.explanation: Remember this procedure by saying DR ABC. This stands for Danger, Response, Airway, Breathing, Circulation. Give whatever first aid you can and stay with the injured person until the emergency services arrive.

prashna.text: At an incident, someone is unconscious. What would your priority be?

options.description: A. Make them comfortable
B. Wake them up
C. Find out their name
D. Check their airway is open

premium.explanation: There are a number of things you can do to help, even without expert training. Be aware of further danger from other traffic and fire; make sure the area is safe. People may be in shock. Don’t give them anything to eat or drink. Keep them warm and comfortable and reassure them. Don’t move injured people unless there’s a risk of further danger.

prashna.text: You've stopped at an incident to give help. What should you do?

options.description: A. Keep injured people warm and comfortable
B. Give injured people a warm drink
C. Keep injured people on the move by walking them around
D. Give injured people something to eat

premium.explanation: A casualty suffering from shock may have injuries that aren't immediately obvious. Call the emergency services, then stay with the person in shock, offering reassurance until the experts arrive.

prashna.text: There's been a collision. A driver is suffering from shock. What should you do?

options.description: A. Ask who caused the incident

C. Offer them a cigarette
D. Give them a drink

premium.explanation: The motorcyclist is in an extremely vulnerable position, exposed to further danger from traffic. Approaching vehicles need advance warning in order to slow down and safely take avoiding action or stop. Don’t put yourself or anyone else at risk. Use the hazard warning lights on your vehicle to alert other road users to the danger.

prashna.text: You arrive at the scene of a motorcycle crash. No other vehicle is involved. The rider is unconscious and lying in the middle of the road. What's the first thing you should do at the scene?

options.description: A. Clear the road of debris

C. Move the rider out of the road

premium.explanation: If a young child has stopped breathing, first check that their airway is open and then begin CPR. With a young child, you may only need to use one hand and you shouldn’t press down as far as you would with an adult. Continue the procedure until the child is breathing again or until a medical professional takes over.

prashna.text: At an incident, a small child isn't breathing. What should you do to try and help?

options.description: A. Talk to them confidently until an ambulance arrives

C. Put them in the recovery position and slap their back

premium.explanation: It’s important to ensure that the airway is open before you start CPR. To open the casualty’s airway, place your fingers under their chin and lift it forward.

prashna.text: At an incident, a casualty isn't breathing. What should you do while helping them to start breathing again?

options.description: A. Tilt their head back gently
B. Shake them firmly
C. Roll them onto their side
D. Put their arms across their chest

premium.explanation: Your priority is to cool the burns with clean, cool water. Its coolness will help take the heat out of the burns and relieve the pain. Keep the wound doused for at least 10 minutes. If blisters appear, don’t attempt to burst them, as this could lead to infection.

prashna.text: At an incident, someone is suffering from severe burns. What should you do to help them?

options.description: A. Burst any blisters
B. Remove anything sticking to the burns
C. Douse the burns with clean, cool water
D. Apply lotions to the injury

premium.explanation: If there’s nothing in the wound, applying firm pressure using a pad of clean cloth or bandage will help stem the bleeding. Don’t tie anything tightly round the leg, as this will restrict circulation and could result in long-term injury.

prashna.text: You arrive at an incident. A pedestrian is bleeding heavily from a leg wound. The leg isn't broken and there's nothing in the wound. How could you help?

options.description: A. Keep the casualty's legs flat on the ground
B. Apply firm pressure over the wound
C. Dab the wound to stop the bleeding
D. Fetch them a warm drink

premium.explanation: Don't move a casualty unless there's further danger; for example, from other traffic or fire. They may have unseen or internal injuries. Moving them unnecessarily could cause further injury. Don't remove a motorcyclist’s helmet unless it’s essential.

prashna.text: At an incident, a casualty is unconscious but breathing. When should you move them?

options.description: A. When an ambulance is on its way
B. When bystanders advise you to

premium.explanation: When the area is safe and there’s no danger from other traffic or fire, it’s better not to move casualties. Moving them may cause further injury.

prashna.text: At an incident, it's important to look after any casualties. What should you do with them when the area is safe?

options.description: A. Keep them where they are
B. Give them something to eat
C. Move them away from the vehicles
D. Ask them how it happened

premium.explanation: There will be an orange label on the side and rear of the tanker. Look at this carefully and report what it says when you phone the emergency services. Details of hazard warning plates are given in The Highway Code.

prashna.text: A tanker is involved in a collision. Which sign shows that it's carrying dangerous goods?

premium.explanation: You must stop if you've been involved in a collision which results in injury or damage. The police may ask to see your driving licence and insurance details at the time or later at a police station.

prashna.text: You're involved in a collision. Afterwards, which document may the police ask you to produce?

options.description: A. Driving licence

D. Theory test certificate

premium.explanation: It's important to make sure that the emergency services arrive as soon as possible. When a person is unconscious, they could have serious injuries that aren't immediately obvious.

prashna.text: After a collision, someone is unconscious in their vehicle. When should you call the emergency services?

options.description: A. Only as a last resort
B. After checking for broken bones
C. After you've woken them up
D. As soon as possible

premium.explanation: The most immediate danger is further collisions and fire. You could warn other traffic by switching on hazard warning lights, displaying an advance warning triangle or sign (but not on a motorway), or by any other means that doesn’t put you or others at risk.

prashna.text: A collision has just happened. An injured person is lying in a busy road. What’s the first thing you should do to help?

options.description: A. Place them in the recovery position
B. Treat the person for shock
C. Warn other traffic
D. Make sure the injured person is kept warm

premium.explanation: The DR ABC code has been devised by medical experts to give the best outcome until the emergency services arrive and take care of casualties.

prashna.text: At an incident, what should you do with a casualty who has stopped breathing?

options.description: A. Try to give them something to drink
B. Follow the DR ABC code

D. Keep their head tilted forwards as far as possible

premium.explanation: If someone is suffering from shock, try to keep them warm and as comfortable as you can. Don’t give them anything to eat or drink but reassure them confidently and try not to leave them alone.

prashna.text: You’re at the scene of an incident. Someone is suffering from shock. How should you treat them?

options.description: A. Offer them some food
B. Reassure them confidently

premium.explanation: When someone is injured, any movement that isn't absolutely necessary should be avoided, since it could make the injuries worse. Unless it's essential to remove a motorcyclist's helmet, it’s generally safer to leave it in place.

premium.explanation: Don’t be tempted to use harsh braking to stop swerving or snaking, as this could make things worse. You should reduce your speed gradually by easing off the throttle.

premium.explanation: A motorcycle with a sidecar, or a trike, will feel very different to ride than a solo motorcycle. Keep your speed down until you get used to the outfit, especially when negotiating bends and junctions.

prashna.text: What should you be aware of when you ride a sidecar outfit for the first time?

options.description: A. You need time to get used to it

premium.explanation: Don’t risk losing any luggage while riding: it could fall into the path of following vehicles and cause danger. It's an offence to travel with an insecure load.

premium.explanation: Pillion passengers must sit astride the motorcycle, on a proper passenger seat, and passenger footrests must be fitted. They must also wear a correctly fastened motorcycle helmet.

prashna.text: What does a person need to do when they ride as a pillion passenger?

premium.explanation: When you tow a trailer, remember that you must obey the reduced speed limits of 50 mph on a single carriageway and 60 mph on a dual carriageway or motorway. premium.explanation: Carrying a heavy load in your top box could make your motorcycle unstable, because the weight is high up and at the very back of the machine.

premium.explanation: Correct loading is the responsibility of the rider. Overloading a motorcycle can seriously affect the control and handling. It could result in a crash, with serious or even fatal consequences.

prashna.text: What should you do before fitting a sidecar to a motorcycle?

options.description: A. Your ability to accelerate

premium.explanation: Before you can carry a pillion passenger, the law requires you to have a full licence for the category of motorcycle you're using.

premium.explanation: Take care if you're carrying a heavy load on your motorcycle. Try to carry the weight as low down as possible – ideally in panniers, with the weight evenly spread on each side. prashna.text: When can you carry a child as a pillion passenger?

premium.explanation: When carrying a passenger or other extra weight, you may need to make adjustments, particularly to the rear shock absorber(s), tyre pressures and headlight alignment. Check your vehicle handbook for details.

prashna.text: You're carrying a pillion passenger. What should you adjust to allow for the extra weight?

premium.explanation: When you’re towing a trailer, you must remember that you may not be able to filter through traffic. Don’t forget that the trailer is there, especially when riding round bends and negotiating junctions.

premium.explanation: To tow a trailer behind a motorcycle, you must have a full motorcycle licence and a motorcycle with an engine larger than 125 cc. Motorcycle trailers mustn't exceed 1 metre (3 feet 3 inches) in width.

prashna.text: What applies when you tow a trailer with your motorcycle?

premium.explanation: A sidecar will alter the handling considerably. Give yourself time to adjust to the different characteristics and allow a greater stopping distance.

prashna.text: You have a sidecar fitted to your motorcycle. What effect will it have?

premium.explanation:
Learner motorcyclists aren’t allowed to
*  tow a trailer

prashna.text: How is a learner motorcyclist’s licence restricted?

When you tow a trailer, you need to be aware that lower speed limits apply and the trailer must be no more than 1 metre wide. The trailer’s laden weight should be no more than 150 kg or two-thirds of the kerbside weight of the motorcycle - whichever is less.

prashna.text: What should you do if you want to tow a trailer behind your motorcycle?

premium.explanation: When carrying a pillion passenger, you should explain to them that they must keep their feet on the footrests. Also check that they aren’t wearing anything long or loose that could get caught in the rear wheel or drive chain.

prashna.text: What should your motorcycle have if you want to carry a pillion passenger?

premium.explanation: Carrying a heavy weight high up and at the very back of the motorcycle can cause problems in maintaining control, particularly when riding at speed. If you have heavy items to carry, it's better to carry them in panniers and keep the weight roughly the same on either side.

prashna.text: What kind of items should you carry in a top box?

premium.explanation: You aren't allowed to carry a pillion passenger until you hold a full motorcycle licence. This gives you time to gain riding experience. premium.explanation: Any load will affect the handling of your motorcycle by changing its centre of gravity. When using panniers, spread the weight evenly on each side. Avoid carrying heavy items in a top box, as this could make your steering dangerously light.

prashna.text: What may be seriously affected if you overload your motorcycle?

premium.explanation:
